results.46567:
On May 5, 2025, a Venezuelan asylum applicant detained at the Wyatt Detention Facility in Central Falls, Rhode Island, filed a habeas petition and complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island challenging the federal government’s plan to summarily remove him under a Presidential Proclamation invoking the Alien Enemies Act (AEA). The case is before Judge Melissa R. DuBose (Magistrate Judge Patricia A. Sullivan is also assigned). The petitioner, proceeding under a pseudonym, is represented by the ACLU Foundation, the ACLU Foundation of Rhode Island (with cooperating counsel), and pro hac vice national ACLU counsel. The respondents are federal officials and agencies responsible for immigration enforcement and detention, including the President (official capacity, declaratory relief only sought), the Attorney General, DHS and ICE leadership (including the Boston Field Office), the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Defense, the Department of Defense, and the warden of Wyatt.

The suit arises from a March 2025 Presidential Proclamation titled “Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren de Aragua.” The Proclamation designates Venezuelan nationals age 14 and over alleged to be members of the Tren de Aragua (TdA) gang (excluding lawful permanent residents) as “alien enemies,” authorizing immediate removal without the procedures of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). The petitioner alleges that DHS has accused him—based on tattoos and an “Alien Enemy Validation Guide” checklist—as a TdA member; he denies any gang affiliation, has no known criminal history, and has a pending asylum, withholding, and Convention Against Torture (CAT) application. He was arrested at work on March 26, 2025, and his bond was denied on May 1, 2025, after DHS asserted TdA affiliation; he was not permitted to testify at that hearing. He fears imminent AEA designation and removal, potentially to El Salvador’s CECOT prison, citing prior removals carried out on March 15, 2025, when at least 137 Venezuelan men were sent to El Salvador.

Legal foundation and claims: The petition proceeds under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 (habeas), the AEA (50 U.S.C. §§ 21–24), the INA (8 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq.), the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act/CAT (8 U.S.C. § 1231 note), the All Writs Act (28 U.S.C. § 1651), the Declaratory Judgment Act (28 U.S.C. § 2201), and the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause. Causes of action include: (1) ultra vires action under the AEA because TdA is not a “foreign nation or government” and there is no “declared war,” “invasion,” or “predatory incursion” within the Act’s terms (50 U.S.C. § 21); (2) violation of the INA’s “sole and exclusive” removal procedures (8 U.S.C. § 1229a(a)(3)); (3) interference with the statutory right to apply for asylum (8 U.S.C. § 1158); (4) violation of mandatory withholding of removal protections (8 U.S.C. § 1231(b)(3)); (5) violation of FARRA/CAT (8 U.S.C. § 1231 note); (6) violation of the AEA’s departure/grace period requirement (50 U.S.C. § 22); (7) Fifth Amendment due process violations (lack of adequate notice and opportunity to contest designation); and (8) violation of the right to habeas corpus and the Suspension Clause. The petitioner does not seek release from detention or to halt his immigration court proceedings; he challenges only removal under the AEA.

Remedies sought include: a temporary restraining order and injunction barring his removal under the Proclamation and barring transfer out of the District; a writ of habeas corpus enjoining removal under the AEA; a declaration that the Proclamation is unlawful; an order requiring at least 30 days’ advance notice and an opportunity to respond to any AEA designation before removal; and attorneys’ fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act.

Proceedings: The petition and an emergency TRO motion were filed May 5, 2025. That same day, Judge DuBose issued an order requiring at least 48 hours’ advance notice to the Court before moving the petitioner outside the District of Rhode Island. After a public hearing on May 7, 2025, the Court amended the order to require at least 72 hours’ advance notice to both the Court and the petitioner, calculated only on business days, before any move outside the District, “until otherwise ordered.” The Court has not yet ruled on the TRO’s merits. Government counsel entered appearances on May 13 and 15, 2025. A transcript of the May 7 hearing was filed on May 19, 2025.

Factual context: The petitioner asserts that the AEA Proclamation was published March 15, 2025, and that DHS attempted and, in at least one instance, completed removals before publication. He alleges the Proclamation provides no process to contest gang “membership,” displaces statutory protections under the INA and CAT, and relies on an English-only notice process that gives only 12 hours’ warning of removal and 24 hours to file habeas if the detainee expresses intent to file—procedures the petitioner contends do not satisfy due process. He also alleges the government is using a point-based “Alien Enemy Validation Guide” focused on tattoos and similar attributes to identify TdA “members,” and that experts have questioned the reliability of those criteria.

Related cases: The filings cite multiple decisions addressing the same Proclamation and issues. Notably, the Supreme Court vacated a nationwide TRO but emphasized detainees’ entitlement to due process and advance notice sufficient to “actually” seek habeas relief before removal, Trump v. J.G.G., 145 S. Ct. 1003, 1006 (Apr. 7, 2025). Other cited rulings include district court decisions granting TROs or preliminary injunctions and finding the Proclamation likely exceeds AEA authority or violates due process, such as J.A.V. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1257450 (S.D. Tex. May 1, 2025); D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1163530 (D. Colo. Apr. 22, 2025), and G.F.F. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1166480 (S.D.N.Y. Apr. 9, 2025), amended by 2025 WL 1166911 (Apr. 11, 2025). The D.C. Circuit denied a stay of a TRO before the Supreme Court’s vacatur, J.G.G. v. Trump, 2025 WL 914682 (D.C. Cir. Mar. 26, 2025).

Current status and interim relief: No final ruling has issued on the TRO or the merits. The operative order requires at least 72 hours’ business-day notice to the Court and the petitioner before any move outside the District of Rhode Island, preserving the Court’s ability to adjudicate the habeas petition.
results.46582:
On April 30, 2025, a Palestinian national in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) custody filed a verified petition for writ of habeas corpus and complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Dallas Division (Case No. 3:25-cv-01072-L-BT). She is confined at the Prairieland Detention Facility in Alvarado, Texas. The respondents are federal immigration and law-enforcement officials (including the heads of the Department of Homeland Security and ICE), the U.S. Attorney General, the acting director of ICE’s Dallas Field Office, and the Prairieland warden. The petitioner is represented by private counsel with civil-rights organizations (Waters Kraus Paul & Siegel; Texas Civil Rights Project; Southern Poverty Law Center; CUNY School of Law; Muslim Advocates). This is an individual action, not a class case.

The petition alleges that the government detained her on March 14, 2025—one day after she voluntarily appeared at ICE’s Newark office—because she had participated in an April 2024 demonstration near Columbia University and once sent $1,000 to a relative in Palestine (February 2022). She had lawfully entered the United States in 2016 (initially in B-2 status, then F-1) and contends she withdrew from her student program in 2022 based on erroneous advice. According to the petition, federal agents in March 2025 investigated her social media and personal contacts and found no “national security” violations beyond the single remittance to a family member. After serving her with a Notice to Appear for immigration court in Batavia, New York, ICE transferred her overnight to Texas. The petition asserts this transfer contravened ICE’s own detainee-transfer policy because she had immediate family and counsel in the Northeast and no documented need for an inter-field-office transfer.

The petitioner alleges that her confinement is a product of a broader federal initiative announced in early March 2025 to target noncitizens perceived to support Palestinian rights. She cites executive orders issued in January 2025 and public statements by senior officials as evidence of viewpoint-based targeting. She further alleges that, during her detention, she has been denied halal meals and basic prayer accommodations, that men enter her dorm without notice while she is not wearing a hijab, and that the facility is overcrowded with poor sanitation and inoperable fixtures. She reports substantial weight loss and adverse health effects. The petition states that an immigration judge granted her release on April 3, 2025, upon a $20,000 bond—finding she was neither a flight risk nor a danger—but that ICE appealed and invoked the automatic stay provisions of 8 C.F.R. § 1003.19(i), preventing her release pending the Board of Immigration Appeals’ review.

Causes of action and legal bases: (1) habeas under 28 U.S.C. § 2241; (2) First Amendment (retaliation for speech and association related to Palestinian-rights advocacy); (3) Fifth Amendment procedural due process (challenging the automatic-stay regime that prevents effectuation of the immigration judge’s bond order without contemporaneous neutral review); (4) Fifth Amendment substantive due process (alleged lack of a permissible, nonpunitive justification for continued civil detention after the bond grant); and (5) the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), 42 U.S.C. § 2000bb-1(c), against the facility warden and ICE field-office director for substantially burdening her religious exercise (halal meals and prayer accommodations). The petition invokes the Suspension Clause, the All Writs Act, and the Declaratory Judgment Act. Remedies sought include a writ of habeas corpus ordering immediate release; preliminary injunctive release pending final judgment; declarations that the detention violates the First and Fifth Amendments and RFRA; injunctive relief requiring religious accommodations; and an order restricting re-detention absent notice and a clear-and-convincing showing.

Proceedings: The court referred the case to Magistrate Judge Rebecca Rutherford; District Judge Sam A. Lindsay is the presiding district judge. On May 5, 2025, the petitioner moved for a preliminary injunction ordering release pending final judgment. The court set and held a hearing on June 5, 2025 (no witness testimony; attorney argument only). The court allowed public remote audio access and permitted the petitioner to attend remotely from the facility, but declined to issue a writ for her physical presence. On June 27, 2025, Magistrate Judge Rutherford issued Findings, Conclusions, and a Recommendation (FCR) that the district court grant the motion and order the petitioner’s immediate release from immigration detention pending a final judgment on the habeas claims. The court also issued an Order to Show Cause requiring the government to answer the habeas petition. Both sides filed objections and responses. On July 16, 2025, Judge Lindsay recommitted the matter to the magistrate judge to address new issues raised after the FCR. The court subsequently modified the briefing schedule (amended pleadings due August 18, 2025; responses due September 2, 2025; replies due September 9, 2025). As of the latest docket entries, the preliminary-injunction motion remains pending before the district court, and the merits have not been adjudicated.

Administrative immigration context: The petitioner alleges ICE’s own Risk Classification Assessment rated her a low public-safety and low flight risk; an immigration judge granted bond; and ICE’s appeal triggered an automatic stay that may extend up to 90–130 days without contemporaneous neutral review, during which she remains detained in Texas far from her home and counsel.

Related or cited matters: The petition cites contemporaneous litigation involving other noncitizens or residents allegedly targeted in similar circumstances, including Öztürk v. Trump, 2025 WL 1145250 (D. Vt. Apr. 18, 2025) and Mahdawi v. Trump, 2025 WL 1243135 (D. Vt. Apr. 30, 2025), among others. These cases are not consolidated with this action.

Judge information: Magistrate Judge Rebecca Rutherford (hearing and FCR); District Judge Sam A. Lindsay (orders and recommittal). No trial has been held, and no appeal has been taken. No settlement or monitoring arrangement has been entered.
results.46496:
On April 24, 2025, three nonprofit organizations—a human rights advocacy group based in Washington, D.C., a coalition of organizations serving U.S.–Mexico border communities, and a New York legal services provider—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Secretary of Homeland Security. The case was assigned to Judge Ana C. Reyes.

The suit challenges DHS’s March 21, 2025 shutdown of three DHS oversight offices established by Congress: the Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL), the Office of the Citizenship and Immigration Services Ombudsman (CIS Ombudsman), and the Office of the Immigration Detention Ombudsman (OIDO). According to the complaint, DHS placed virtually all staff of the three offices on administrative leave with separation dates of May 23, 2025, halted their work (including complaint intake and investigations), and terminated related contracts. The nonprofits allege they regularly used these offices to file complaints, obtain case assistance, and advocate for clients and communities, and that the shutdown forces them to divert resources to more costly, less effective avenues.

Legal foundation and claims. The nonprofits bring (1) a non‑statutory ultra vires claim alleging DHS exceeded its authority by eliminating or disabling offices that Congress created and funded; and (2) Administrative Procedure Act claims under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(C) (agency action in excess of statutory authority) and § 706(2)(A) (arbitrary and capricious action). The complaint cites the statutes establishing and governing the three offices—6 U.S.C. § 345 and 42 U.S.C. § 2000ee‑1 (CRCL), 6 U.S.C. § 272 (CIS Ombudsman), and 6 U.S.C. § 205 (OIDO)—and alleges the closures also implicate separation‑of‑powers concerns by nullifying congressional directives. In seeking preliminary relief, the nonprofits also argued the actions violated the Impoundment Control Act and the Anti‑Deficiency Act. They request declaratory and injunctive relief setting aside DHS’s actions, reinstating employees and contractors necessary to perform the offices’ statutory functions, prohibiting further steps that hinder those functions, and preserving federal records; they also seek fees and costs.

Factual context. The pleading describes the statutory duties of each office: CRCL’s civil rights/civil liberties complaint intake, oversight, training, and reporting to Congress; the CIS Ombudsman’s case assistance and systemic‑recommendations role with USCIS and annual reporting; and OIDO’s independent detention‑conditions complaint work, unannounced inspections, recommendations to ICE and CBP, and annual reporting. Congress specifically appropriated funds for these offices in FY 2024. The complaint alleges that, on March 21, 2025, nearly all staff in the three offices received reduction‑in‑force notices (with May 23 separation dates) reflecting “dissolution” of their offices, pending complaints were frozen, and outside observers—including members of Congress—raised concerns. A DHS spokesperson publicly stated the offices were closed because they obstructed immigration enforcement.

Proceedings. On May 8, 2025, the nonprofits moved for a preliminary injunction to stop DHS from terminating the offices’ functions, to reinstate employees/contractors, to resume complaint processing, to preserve records, and to restore removed materials to the offices’ websites. Judge Reyes set expedited briefing, held an evidentiary hearing on May 19–20, and took the motion under advisement. On May 23, with RIF separations imminent, the nonprofits also sought a temporary restraining order (TRO). After a same‑day hearing with testimony from DHS officials, the Court denied the TRO without prejudice but ordered the parties to provide concrete updates on posting vacancies and restaffing to enable performance of statutory functions.

Status reports filed May 27 and June 2 reflected DHS’s position that, following the RIF, the offices could post new positions, were seeking detailees, and were moving to restaff; the nonprofits expressed concern that staffing remained insufficient to perform statutory duties and that job postings restricted eligibility to current DHS employees. The nonprofits also alerted the Court that DHS’s FY 2026 congressional budget justification stated OIDO “has been eliminated in its entirety” and projected only “interim” funding focused on severance and leave payouts for the other two offices, which they argued conflicted with DHS’s assurances in this litigation. The Court held a status conference on June 12 and ordered DHS to explain whether and how it communicated with the Executive regarding the budget language; DHS submitted an ex parte declaration on June 16, and a redacted version was filed publicly. The nonprofits responded on June 18, noting continued inconsistencies between public statements and litigation positions and reporting that detention facilities had removed posted information on contacting CRCL and OIDO.

Amicus participation. Multiple states and the District of Columbia filed an amicus brief supporting the nonprofits’ motion for preliminary injunction.

Rulings and current posture. On July 11, 2025, the Court granted a joint motion setting an expedited schedule for discovery and cross‑motions for summary judgment and denied the preliminary‑injunction motion as moot in light of that schedule. The Court ordered the administrative record be filed by August 22, 2025 (filed), set motions to compel by September 5, 2025, and scheduled summary‑judgment briefing through December 2025, with argument to be set for January 2026. On August 1, 2025, the nonprofits moved for partial reconsideration of the order denying their preliminary‑injunction motion as moot; briefing on that request concluded by August 22, 2025. No reported opinions have issued, there has been no trial, and there are no appeals.

Context and alleged harms. The nonprofits describe specific pre‑ and post‑shutdown matters they would have brought to the oversight offices, including civil rights complaints regarding detention conditions, medical care, alleged retaliation against detainees, and confidentiality violations under 8 U.S.C. § 1367, as well as routine USCIS case‑assistance needs. They assert the shutdown has halted statutory complaint intake, inspections, recommendations, and annual reporting; increased their costs; and deprived affected individuals and communities of congressionally mandated oversight mechanisms. DHS maintains the offices continue to exist and are being restaffed; the nonprofits contest that assertion, citing the RIF notices, restrictions in job postings, the FY 2026 budget language, and continued delays in core functions.
results.46432:
On April 18, 2025, a Bangladeshi F‑1 student at Minnesota State University, Mankato filed a habeas petition in the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota challenging his immigration detention. He sued federal executive officials responsible for immigration enforcement (including the President, the Attorney General, the heads of DHS, State, and ICE and local ICE officials) and local jail officials (the county sheriff and jail administrator holding him under an ICE contract). He was represented by a private law firm together with civil‑rights and human‑rights organizations (ACLU of Minnesota; The Advocates for Human Rights) and a law school clinic. The federal defendants were represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office; the sheriff by the county attorney.

The petition was brought under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and alleged three primary grounds: (1) a First Amendment violation—retaliatory arrest and detention for his protected political speech in support of Palestinian human rights; (2) a Fifth Amendment due process violation—detention without individualized justification and use of procedures that deprived him of liberty without adequate process; and (3) an Administrative Procedure Act violation—arbitrary and unlawful termination of his SEVIS student status. He sought a writ ordering release, as well as temporary relief barring transfer or removal.

The factual record showed he lawfully entered on an F‑1 visa in 2021 and was in good standing until DHS officers arrested him on March 28, 2025, shortly after he posted pro‑Palestinian content on social media. Immediately thereafter, his SEVIS record was terminated, initially citing failure to maintain status and a “foreign policy” ground, which later shifted in SEVIS to “OTHER – Individual identified in criminal records check and/or has had their visa revoked.” The State Department issued a March 23, 2025 memo revoking his visa “effective immediately” in response to DHS’s request, based on an old misdemeanor disorderly conduct matter; the memo indicated DHS intended to “immediately pursue removal.” In immigration court, an Immigration Judge on April 9, 2025 found he was not dangerous and ordered release on a $7,500 bond, but DHS appealed and invoked the automatic stay under 8 C.F.R. § 1003.19(i)(2), preventing release without any additional showing. DHS later withdrew the original removability charge (failure to maintain status) and proceeded solely on visa revocation under INA § 237(a)(1)(B). While detained, the student reported worsening hernia symptoms and missed a scheduled surgical consultation.

Judge Jerry W. Blackwell expedited the case. On April 22, 2025, the court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) barring the government from removing or transferring the student from the District of Minnesota to preserve jurisdiction and prevent irreparable harm. The court ordered the government to answer by April 25 and allowed a reply by April 29. After full briefing, on May 5, 2025, the court granted release on bail pending adjudication (applying Martin v. Solem, 801 F.2d 324 (8th Cir. 1986)), finding substantial constitutional claims and exceptional circumstances (unrebutted medical issues, an IJ order finding no danger, shifting government rationales, and the risk that transfer or removal would frustrate judicial review). The release order required immediate release subject to the IJ’s prior bond conditions, including the $7,500 bond, and release to counsel or an approved responsible adult. The TRO preventing transfer/removal was extended on May 5, May 20, and June 3, 2025. No evidentiary hearing was held; both sides agreed the record was sufficient for decision.

On June 17, 2025, the court granted the habeas petition. First, it held habeas jurisdiction existed because the student challenged only the legality of his detention, not any discretionary decision or a final removal order, and the INA’s jurisdiction‑stripping provisions did not bar review. On the merits, the court sustained all three claims. On the First Amendment claim, the court found by a preponderance of the evidence that the student was targeted, arrested, and detained because of his protected political speech; the government’s reliance on visa revocation did not break the causal link given the sequence of events, shifting justifications, the DHS‑initiated revocation, the lack of contemporaneous individualized danger evidence, and disparate treatment compared to similarly situated international students. On the Fifth Amendment claim, the court found the detention punitive and not justified by the permissible aims of immigration detention (ensuring appearance and protecting the community), especially in light of the IJ’s bond decision and the government’s use of the automatic stay to continue detention without any individualized showing—a procedure the court deemed arbitrary as applied. On the APA claim, the court held DHS’s termination of SEVIS status was arbitrary and not in accordance with law: the stated reasons shifted, did not fit the regulatory grounds, lacked required Federal Register notice where applicable, and contravened DHS policy that visa revocation alone does not justify SEVIS termination, with no evidence of a status‑violating offense or regulatory basis under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1 or § 214.2.

As a remedy, the court ordered that the student remain released from custody subject to the IJ’s existing bond conditions. Judgment entered on June 18, 2025. The federal defendants noticed an appeal to the Eighth Circuit on July 29, 2025 (No. 25‑2516); the appeal remains pending.

Decree and interim relief terms and durations: The April 22 TRO barred removal or transfer from the District of Minnesota for 14 days; it was extended on May 5 (to May 20), May 20 (to June 3), and June 3 (to June 17), maintaining the status quo through final adjudication. The May 5 bail order required immediate release subject to the IJ’s $7,500 bond and approved custodian. The June 17 final order granted the writ and continued release on the same bond conditions.

Important filings and rulings:
- April 18, 2025: Petition filed under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 alleging First Amendment, Fifth Amendment, and APA violations, and seeking release.
- April 22, 2025: TRO granted prohibiting transfer/removal; expedited answer order issued.
- April 25/29, 2025: Government filed answer; student filed reply.
- May 5, 2025: Bail pending adjudication granted; TRO extended.
- May 20 and June 3, 2025: TRO extended twice more.
- June 17, 2025: Habeas petition granted on all claims; release continued on IJ bond.
- June 18, 2025: Judgment entered.
- July 29, 2025: Appeal noticed to the Eighth Circuit.

Context and factual basis: The court credited evidence that the student’s arrest and detention followed his public pro‑Palestinian speech; DHS initiated a visa revocation that State then issued; removal charges and SEVIS termination reasons shifted over time; an IJ had already found him not dangerous and set bond; and detention continued solely via an automatic stay without individualized findings. Medical evidence of multiple hernias and missed care, and the risk of transfer/removal undermining judicial review, supported interim release and the TRO.

Related cases (not consolidated) cited by the court include similar student‑detention challenges: Aditya W. H. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1420131 (D. Minn. May 14, 2025); Mahdawi v. Trump, 2025 WL 1243135 (D. Vt. Apr. 30, 2025); Ozturk v. Trump, 2025 WL 1145250 (D. Vt. Apr. 18, 2025); Doe v. Noem, 2025 WL 1203472 (S.D. Iowa Apr. 24, 2025); Shaik v. Noem, 2025 WL 1170447 (D. Minn. Apr. 22, 2025); Arizona Student DOE #1 v. Trump, 2025 WL 1192826 (D. Ariz. Apr. 24, 2025); and John Roe v. Noem, 2025 WL 1114694 (D. Mont. Apr. 15, 2025). No settlement or monitoring was ordered in this case.
results.46477:
On April 14, 2025, thirty-one international students and recent graduates (initially ten, later expanded) studying at public universities and vocational programs in Michigan and several other states filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan against the Department of Homeland Security’s leadership—specifically the DHS Secretary, the Acting ICE Director, and the Detroit ICE Field Office Director. The students, many on F‑1 (and one on M‑1) nonimmigrant status, including several engaged in post-completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) or STEM‑OPT, were represented by private counsel. They alleged that DHS/ICE’s Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) had unilaterally changed their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records to “terminated,” often with the notation that the student had been identified in a criminal records check and/or had a revoked visa. Their institutions then told them to cease work and/or depart immediately. Plaintiffs asserted no one had been convicted of a qualifying violent crime and they did not challenge any separate visa revocations—only the SEVIS terminations.

The complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief for violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), alleging the actions were arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law, and for violations of the U.S. Constitution’s Due Process Clause. The case was assigned to Judge Jane M. Beckering. It is not a class action.

On April 15, 2025, plaintiffs moved for an emergency TRO and preliminary injunction. After briefing and an April 22 hearing, the court granted a TRO on April 23, 2025. The TRO: (1) required the DHS Secretary and Acting ICE Director to set aside the SEVIS termination decisions and (2) restore each plaintiff’s F‑1 record in SEVIS retroactive to the termination date; (3) barred those officials from terminating plaintiffs’ F‑1 records absent a valid regulatory basis under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d) or § 214.2(f) and adherence to plaintiffs’ constitutional and statutory rights; (4) prohibited revocation of plaintiffs’ OPT employment authorizations; (5) prohibited arresting, detaining, or transferring plaintiffs without prior notice to the court and counsel and time to contest; and (6) prohibited initiating removal or deportation based on the SEVIS terminations. The court waived Rule 65(c) security and set the TRO to expire in 14 days unless extended or by consent. The court’s accompanying opinion held plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA claim and rejected jurisdictional defenses, finding (a) sovereign immunity did not bar review, (b) the SEVIS terminations were “final agency action” with immediate legal consequences and no administrative review mechanism, and (c) any exhaustion requirement did not bar suit. The court concluded the record did not show any of the limited agency grounds for status termination under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d) and no qualifying convictions under 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(g). It found irreparable harm (loss of academic and employment progress and uncertain legal status with risk of arrest/removal), and that the public interest and equities favored injunctive relief.

Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on April 25, 2025 adding additional students. After the TRO issued, DHS restored plaintiffs’ SEVIS records, though SEVIS continued to display a “terminated” event in the history visible to Designated School Officials (DSOs). SEVP added internal notations indicating retroactive restoration, but those were not visible to DSOs. Plaintiffs’ first contempt motion regarding TRO compliance was withdrawn once restoration occurred; their second was denied without prejudice on May 7, 2025, but the court ordered DHS to file, by May 13, 2025, a notice confirming a retroactivity notation was on each plaintiff’s record and addressing whether that notation could be made visible to DSOs.

On May 7, 2025, after a May 6 hearing, the court granted a preliminary injunction, again waiving security. The court reiterated plaintiffs’ likelihood of success under the APA, rejecting DHS’s reliance on 8 U.S.C. § 1372 (which authorizes collecting student information) as a source of authority to terminate status, given the specific limits in 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d). The court declined to reach the due process claims at that stage. On irreparable harm and mootness, the court held DHS’s restoration did not moot the case under the voluntary-cessation doctrine, particularly in light of an April 26, 2025 ICE “Broadcast Message” authorizing SEVIS terminations for, among other reasons, “evidence of a failure to comply with the terms of nonimmigrant status” and immediate terminations upon visa revocation. The court found the government had not shown the challenged conduct could not reasonably be expected to recur and that the same harms persisted without an injunction. The preliminary injunction preserves the status quo established by the TRO—maintaining restored records and restricting future adverse actions absent a lawful basis.

Key proceedings and orders:
- April 14, 2025: Complaint filed seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.
- April 23, 2025: TRO granted; opinion issued; security waived; TRO effective for 14 days.
- May 7, 2025: Preliminary injunction granted; opinion issued; second show-cause motion denied; DHS ordered to confirm retroactivity notations and address DSO visibility.
- May 13, 2025: DHS filed notice with supporting declarations regarding SEVIS notations.
- July 7, 2025: Defendants filed a notice of interlocutory appeal from the preliminary injunction to the Sixth Circuit (No. 25-1611). Outcome not reflected in the record provided.

Legal foundation:
- Cause of action: APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2) (arbitrary, capricious, contrary to law); constitutional Due Process Clause.
- Statutory/regulatory context: 8 U.S.C. § 1372; 8 C.F.R. §§ 214.1(d), 214.1(g), 214.2(f) & (m).
- Remedy sought: declaratory and injunctive relief (no damages).

Factual basis:
Beginning in late March/early April 2025, SEVP unilaterally changed plaintiffs’ SEVIS records to “terminated,” typically noting a criminal records check and/or a visa revocation. Institutions notified students, instructed them to stop working, and in some instances to depart. Plaintiffs—students and recent graduates across multiple states—asserted they had no qualifying violent-crime convictions and had complied with immigration status requirements. The court found the agency action likely unlawful under the APA, imposed TRO and preliminary injunctive relief to restore and protect their student status and employment authorizations, and enjoined further adverse actions absent lawful grounds.

Judge: Jane M. Beckering, U.S. District Judge, Western District of Michigan, Southern Division.

Class status: Individual plaintiffs; not a class action.

Counsel: Private counsel for plaintiffs.

Consolidation/related cases: None consolidated; the court noted similar cases nationwide but did not consolidate this action.

Decrees’ duration: TRO effective April 23, 2025 for 14 days; preliminary injunction entered May 7, 2025 remains in effect pending adjudication on the merits.
results.46239:
On March 17, 2025, a New York county filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Corporation for National and Community Service (AmeriCorps) and its interim agency head in her official capacity. The county, represented by private counsel, challenged AmeriCorps’ new certification demand tied to two January 2025 executive orders concerning “DEI,” asserting the agency abruptly imposed vague, unauthorized conditions on an already-awarded Retired and Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP) grant. The federal defendants were represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office. Chief Judge James E. Boasberg presided.

The dispute arose after the county applied in October 2023 for a three‑year RSVP grant (about $250,000) and received an award in January 2024. AmeriCorps’ long‑standing RSVP regulation, adopted in 1999 after notice and comment, requires sponsors to establish an advisory council “of a diverse composition that reflects the demographics of the service area” (45 C.F.R. § 2553.24(a)(5)). The county’s application, consistent with the program’s notices and guidance, described efforts to reach diverse communities and to recruit a diverse advisory council. Following Executive Orders 14151 (Jan. 20, 2025) and 14173 (Jan. 21, 2025), AmeriCorps on February 14, 2025, told the county to either: (1) certify by set language that the RSVP grant “complies with all administration Executive Orders and does not include any activities that promote DEI activities,” (2) amend the award to remove or update “out of compliance” language, or (3) relinquish the award, warning that nonresponse could lead to termination. AmeriCorps later acknowledged a District of Maryland preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the executive orders in other litigation, told the county it could continue activities for the existing award, but on March 12, 2025, required action on the county’s FY 2025 continuation application. On March 18, 2025, the Fourth Circuit stayed the Maryland injunction pending appeal.

The county brought two claims: (1) under the Administrative Procedure Act, alleging AmeriCorps’ new certification requirement was a final agency action that was arbitrary and capricious because it contradicted AmeriCorps’ own RSVP regulation and was imposed without notice and comment (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A)); and (2) under the Spending Clause, alleging the agency conditioned funds on a fatally vague and unrelated “promotes DEI” prohibition (U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 1). The county sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the new requirements and enforcement of the executive-order–based restrictions. On March 21, 2025, it moved for a preliminary injunction directing AmeriCorps to deem it compliant and to disburse funds without requiring the DEI certification.

Defendants opposed on April 4, 2025, arguing the county faced no imminent irreparable harm; the claims were unripe; sovereign immunity barred review because the challenged actions were committed to agency discretion in administering discretionary grants and, alternatively, belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act as a contract dispute; and the merits failed because no conflict with 45 C.F.R. § 2553.24(a)(5) was shown and grantees could amend applications. The court set a briefing schedule and a hearing for April 25, 2025, but no merits ruling issued.

On April 14, 2025, the county voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice, stating AmeriCorps had changed its certification requirements since the suit was filed. The preliminary‑injunction motion was withdrawn, the scheduled hearing was vacated, and the case was closed. No opinions were issued. Related litigation noted in the filings included National Association of Diversity Officers in Higher Education v. Trump, No. 25‑cv‑333 (D. Md.) (preliminary injunction entered Feb. 21, 2025) and the Fourth Circuit’s stay pending appeal, No. 25‑1189 (Mar. 18, 2025). The case did not involve class claims, went no further than preliminary‑injunction briefing, and ended without settlement or decree. The factual backdrop concerned the RSVP program’s senior‑volunteer services and AmeriCorps’ post‑order request for a DEI‑related certification that the county alleged conflicted with AmeriCorps’ existing RSVP diversity regulation.
results.46230:
Filed March 14, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this case was brought by twelve nonprobationary career civil servants in the Department of Veterans Affairs’ Veterans Benefits Administration, formerly assigned to the Office of Equity Assurance (OEA). They sued the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in his official capacity. The employees alleged that after the January 20–21, 2025 issuance of Executive Order 14151 (ending federal DEI/DEIA programs) and subsequent Office of Personnel Management (OPM) guidance, the VA improperly designated OEA as a DEIA office, shut it down on January 22, 2025, placed its staff on paid administrative leave, cut off their network access, and later initiated reduction-in-force (RIF) actions limited to OEA. Plaintiffs were represented by private counsel; the Secretary was represented by the U.S. Department of Justice.

Legal foundation. Plaintiffs proceeded under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 704, 706, and the U.S. Constitution. They alleged that designating OEA as a DEIA office and the cascading actions violated the First Amendment (viewpoint discrimination and retaliation based on perceived association) and the Fifth Amendment (due process—property and liberty interests—and equal protection). They also alleged arbitrary and capricious agency action under the APA. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief (including orders barring the “DEIA” designation for OEA and themselves, restoring network and employment benefits access, and requiring public recantation of the designation), and recovery of fees and costs; the complaint also referenced compensatory damages.

Factual basis. OEA was established in 2023 within VBA to identify and address disparities in access to VA benefits (e.g., rural and geographically isolated veterans) and to validate or rebut findings such as those in GAO-23-106097 concerning race-based disparities in claims outcomes. After EO 14151, OPM issued memoranda directing prompt termination, to the maximum extent permitted by law, of DEI/DEIA offices and advising agencies to place DEIA-office employees on administrative leave and to define RIF competitive areas solely as the DEIA office where the employee worked. On January 22, 2025, the VA’s Acting Secretary emailed VA personnel that DEIA offices would be closed and contracts terminated; OEA was closed that day, its employees were placed on administrative leave, and their access to VA systems was revoked. VA issued a January 27 press release stating nearly 60 employees solely focused on DEI/DEIA had been placed on leave and that DEI-related contracts were being canceled.

Plaintiffs alleged they were excluded from opportunities available to other active employees (including a January 28, 2025 deferred resignation program email they could not receive because their access had been revoked) and that their attempts to secure reassignment to funded vacancies within VBA were foreclosed by OPM’s direction to proceed by RIF. On February 14, 2025, they received “Specific RIF” notices after the stated effective time, without the usual 60 days’ notice or reassignment/severance processes, and with the competitive area limited to OEA (even though OEA had already closed). On February 27, 2025, VA rescinded the February 14 separations and placed plaintiffs back on administrative leave retroactive to February 14 but allegedly did not pay a full pay period and continued to block their system access. On March 13, 2025, VA issued new specific RIF notices setting May 10, 2025 separation dates, again defining the competitive area as the “DEIA office where the employee worked.” Plaintiffs contended these actions stigmatized them as “DEIA employees,” damaged their reputations and career prospects, and differed from how other VA components—such as the Office of Health Equity—were treated.

Proceedings and rulings. Plaintiffs moved to proceed under pseudonym; on April 9, 2025, Chief Judge James E. Boasberg granted the motion in part and denied it in part, directing use of the pseudonyms listed in the complaint in public filings and ordering plaintiffs to file their real names and addresses under seal. Plaintiffs filed a Notice of Related Case to Perkins Coie LLP v. U.S. Department of Justice (No. 1:25-cv-00716); on April 18, 2025, Judge Beryl A. Howell concluded the cases were not related under the local rules and directed random reassignment. The case was reassigned to Judge Rudolph Contreras.

On April 18, 2025, plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order seeking to bar VA from designating OEA as a DEIA office and them as DEIA employees, and to restore their access to VA systems and employee benefits (including consideration for the deferred resignation program), citing due-process and First Amendment harms and pointing to recent orders in other courts addressing OPM-related directives. After expedited briefing and a May 2, 2025 hearing, Judge Rudolph Contreras denied the TRO for reasons stated on the record. No written opinion accompanied the TRO denial. The court directed the parties to confer on a preliminary-injunction schedule.

Disposition. On July 17, 2025, plaintiffs filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice; the case was dismissed on July 21, 2025.

Judges. Chief Judge James E. Boasberg (pseudonym order); Judge Beryl A. Howell (related-case reassignment order); Judge Rudolph Contreras (presiding thereafter; TRO denied).

Related matters. Plaintiffs filed a Notice of Related Case to Perkins Coie LLP v. U.S. Department of Justice (No. 1:25-cv-00716), but the court found the cases not related. Plaintiffs’ TRO papers referenced other courts’ orders involving OPM guidance to agencies, but no case was consolidated with this one.

No trial, decrees, settlement, or appeal occurred in this action.

On March 5, 2025, three plaintiffs—a national motorized-access nonprofit, a Utah motorcycle club, and an individual rider—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Utah challenging the Bureau of Land Management’s December 31, 2024 San Rafael Swell Travel Management Plan, its Environmental Assessment, Finding of No Significant Impact, and Decision Record for the San Rafael Swell Travel Management Area in Emery County, Utah. The San Rafael Swell TMA encompasses roughly 1.3 million acres (about 1.15 million acres BLM-managed). The court assigned the case to District Judge David Nuffer. The plaintiffs proceed individually (not as a class) and are represented by private counsel. The federal defendants are BLM and the U.S. Department of the Interior, represented by government counsel. The Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance (a conservation nonprofit represented by its staff attorneys) intervened as a defendant.

The suit is brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706), NEPA (42 U.S.C. § 4332), and the John D. Dingell, Jr. Conservation, Management, and Recreation Act (Pub. L. No. 116-9). Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur and setting aside of the San Rafael Swell TMP, and attorneys’ fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act (28 U.S.C. § 2412). They also sought temporary relief under 5 U.S.C. § 705 or, alternatively, a preliminary injunction.

As factual context, BLM’s 2024 decision closed approximately 665 miles of routes within the San Rafael Swell network, left a large network of routes open to motorized use (over 1,300 miles), and limited certain additional miles. The agency stated it selected a hybrid alternative to balance recreation access and resource protection. The EA also describes route reclamation measures for closed routes, including signage, barriers, and techniques such as “vertical mulching,” ripping and reseeding, and other methods intended to make closed routes undetectable.

Plaintiffs allege three principal violations. First, they contend BLM’s closures unlawfully create de facto wilderness “buffer zones” around the 2019 Dingell Act wilderness areas in the Swell (e.g., near Sid’s Mountain, Mexican Mountain, and Devil’s Canyon), contrary to the Act’s repeated prohibition on protective perimeters and on closing adjacent lands merely because nonwilderness uses may be seen or heard from within wilderness. They similarly argue BLM effectively created a de facto “wild” river corridor along segments of the Price River by closing routes to “encourage only non-motorized access,” despite Congress not designating the Price River under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act; by contrast, Congress designated segments of Utah’s Green River and specified accessibility considerations. Second, under the APA, they allege the decision is arbitrary and capricious: BLM purportedly failed to respond to significant comments (including about Dingell Act compliance), relied on unsubstantiated “user conflict” to close certain single-track routes, adopted closures inconsistent with its own route reports and wildlife analyses, and routed approval through the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary rather than a district manager—thereby eliminating Interior Board of Land Appeals review and making the decision immediately effective without explanation. They also challenge BLM’s reliance on OHV “minimization criteria” (43 C.F.R. § 8342.1) as lacking a clear statutory basis in light of a D.C. Circuit decision (Marin Audubon Society v. FAA) regarding executive orders and regulatory authority, and they question BLM’s reliance on Council on Environmental Quality regulations after those regulations’ removal by CEQ’s interim rule in February 2025. Third, under NEPA, they argue BLM should have prepared an Environmental Impact Statement because closing hundreds of miles of long-used routes significantly affects the human environment and because the plan required substantial planning, time, and resources; they also assert BLM failed to take the requisite “hard look” and that a FONSI was improper.

On March 6, 2025, plaintiffs moved to postpone the plan’s effective date under APA § 705 or for a preliminary injunction, asserting irreparable harm from imminent route obliteration and loss of access to state trust lands and a historic family homestead. The court set a briefing schedule. Federal defendants opposed the motion on April 3, 2025; the intervenor conservation group filed its response on April 10; plaintiffs replied on April 24. No ruling on interim relief appears in the record provided.

On March 10, 2025, the conservation group moved to intervene as of right, citing decades of advocacy, participation throughout travel planning, and interests in minimizing motorized impacts to wildlife, riparian, soil crust, and cultural resources. On April 21, 2025, Judge Nuffer granted intervention, holding the motion timely; that the group has direct, substantial, legally protectable environmental interests that may be impaired by vacatur or remand requiring new decision-making; and that the federal defendants may not adequately represent those interests given their obligation to represent the broader public interest and potential for policy shifts. (No Westlaw citation is provided in the record.)

The docket reflects service on the defendants, completion of preliminary-injunction briefing, and entry of an administrative-appeal scheduling order on June 17, 2025 (later amended August 28, 2025). The court set the administrative record due October 31, 2025; plaintiffs’ opening merits brief due in early 2026; defendants’ and intervenor’s response briefs thereafter; and plaintiffs’ reply due June 5, 2026. There are no consolidated cases, no trials, no reported opinions on the merits, and no appeals or settlements noted in the record provided.

The case arises from longstanding disputes over motorized access in the San Rafael Swell. A 2017 settlement in prior litigation required BLM to redo travel plans in multiple Utah areas, leading to the 2024 decision now at issue. Plaintiffs characterize the new closures as unlawful buffer-zone expansion and improper constraints on river access; the federal agency and the intervenor conservation group characterize the plan as a balanced network that designates a substantial mileage for motorized use while minimizing user and resource conflicts and protecting sensitive resources. The court has not yet adjudicated the merits.
results.46039:
On February 4, 2025, a professional association for FBI agents and seven current FBI employees proceeding under pseudonyms filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice and, in one case, the United States. The individual plaintiffs include special agents and other FBI personnel. This is not a class action. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel and a nonprofit advocacy organization; the government is represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

The cases arise from post–January 20, 2025 actions by DOJ leadership. On January 31, 2025, DOJ directed the FBI to identify all current and former FBI personnel assigned at any time to January 6, 2021–related matters and to United States v. Haniyeh, 24 Mag. 438 (S.D.N.Y.). According to DOJ, the request supports an internal review under Executive Order 14,147 (“Ending the Weaponization of the Federal Government”). The FBI responded by providing lists that used unique employee identifiers (not names) along with each person’s current title, title at the time, current office, role, and last activity date. Internal FBI communications filed by DOJ state the Bureau did not view inclusion on the lists as evidence of misconduct and described an optional questionnaire to help ensure accuracy; managers could complete it for employees. Plaintiffs allege the Department’s actions are part of an effort to identify, punish, and publicly expose personnel who worked on January 6 investigations, placing them and their families at risk amid documented online threats and recent pardons of January 6 offenders.

Plaintiffs assert statutory and constitutional claims and seek injunctive and mandamus relief. The causes of action include: violations of the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a(e)(6) (dissemination without ensuring accuracy) and § 552a(b) (unlawful disclosure from a system of records); arbitrary and capricious agency action under the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2); mandamus under 28 U.S.C. § 1361; First Amendment retaliation based on perceived political affiliation; and Fifth Amendment due process claims for reputational harm (“stigma-plus”) and compelled disclosure of personal information. Plaintiffs invoke federal-question jurisdiction, 28 U.S.C. § 1331, and mandamus jurisdiction, § 1361, and cite the APA’s waiver of sovereign immunity, 5 U.S.C. § 702. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief barring aggregation and dissemination of personally identifying information linking them to January 6 matters, and, if necessary, a writ of mandamus to prevent or rescind any unlawful personnel actions, along with fees and costs.

The government opposed temporary restraining orders, arguing plaintiffs lack standing and irreparable harm because no public disclosure has occurred or been authorized, the Privacy Act permits intra-agency sharing (5 U.S.C. § 552a(b)(1)), the lists do not contain names, and any review is internal and lawful. DOJ also contended the requested injunctions were overbroad and beyond the pleadings.

Judge Jia M. Cobb presides. The court granted leave for the Doe plaintiffs to proceed under pseudonyms and permitted a declaration to be filed under seal and ex parte. On February 6, 2025, the court issued a short administrative stay preserving the status quo (no disclosure outside DOJ) pending further proceedings. On February 7, 2025, with the parties’ consent, the court deferred ruling on the TROs and entered an order that: (1) the government will not disseminate to the public, directly or indirectly, the list at issue (including any subsequent versions or any record pairing unique identifiers to names) before the court rules on anticipated motions for preliminary injunction; and (2) the government may terminate that proscription on two business days’ notice absent further order. The cases—John and Jane Does 1–9 v. DOJ (No. 25‑0325) and FBI Agents Association v. DOJ, et al. (No. 25‑0328)—were consolidated, with No. 25‑0325 designated as the lead case. The court set a preliminary injunction schedule: motions due February 24, 2025; oppositions due March 14, 2025; replies due March 21, 2025; and a hearing set for March 27, 2025. On April 9, 2025, John Doe #4 was dismissed by stipulation. No trials have occurred, no final judgment has been entered, and there are no reported opinions in these consolidated cases to date.

Factual context pleaded by plaintiffs includes the January 6 attack, subsequent DOJ/FBI investigations nationwide, and, after January 20, 2025, presidential pardons/commutations of January 6 defendants and online statements by some recipients perceived as threatening. Plaintiffs allege DOJ is pursuing mass personnel actions based on involvement in January 6 matters and intends to disclose or enable the disclosure of employees’ identities and roles, creating safety and reputational risks. DOJ denies any intent to publicly release identifying information and asserts any review will consider misconduct only, not lawful case work.
results.46681:
Filed February 3, 2025, in the U.S. Court of International Trade, this case is an individual, pro se constitutional challenge by a U.S. citizen consumer to tariffs announced by the President in early 2025. The plaintiff alleged that Congress unconstitutionally delegated its Article I powers to “lay and collect” duties and that the President unconstitutionally imposed tariffs by executive order, violating Article I, Sections 7 and 8; the separation of powers; and the President’s oath in Article II. He invoked the Court’s residual jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i) and also cited 28 U.S.C. § 1361 (mandamus). He sought declaratory relief, preliminary and permanent injunctions halting collection of the tariffs and prohibiting any future presidential imposition of tariffs, and an order compelling the President to perform constitutional duties.

The suit challenged executive actions issued after a January 20, 2025 national emergency proclamation. On February 1, 2025, executive orders announced: 25% tariffs on products from Mexico; 10% on energy from Canada and 25% on other Canadian products; and 10% on products from China, invoking authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), 50 U.S.C. §§ 1701–1702. Implementation included amending the Harmonized Tariff Schedule to add an extra duty line for Chinese goods, with de minimis exceptions under 19 U.S.C. § 1321. Subsequent orders paused or modified the Canada and Mexico measures and altered China rates; in March and April 2025 additional orders increased rates, imposed a general 10% reciprocal tariff, adjusted country-specific China rates, and limited de minimis treatment for certain Chinese goods, followed by a May 12, 2025 order that scaled back some China tariffs. The government did not dispute that the Court possessed § 1581(i) jurisdiction, and the Court later confirmed that jurisdiction because the measures were imposed for reasons other than raising revenue.

The defendant (the United States, represented by the Department of Justice, Civil Division, Commercial Litigation Branch) moved to dismiss under USCIT Rule 12(b)(1) for lack of Article III and prudential standing. It argued the plaintiff alleged only generalized grievances about economic conditions and government adherence to the Constitution; he was not an importer paying the challenged duties; any downstream price effects were speculative and dependent on third-party decisions; and any alleged harms were not fairly traceable to the tariffs or redressable by court order. It also argued prudential standing was lacking because importers—the parties who pay the duties—are better positioned to litigate such claims, citing importer suits recently filed in the Court (e.g., V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump, Ct. No. 25‑00066; Princess Awesome, LLC v. U.S. Customs & Border Prot., Ct. No. 25‑00078).

The plaintiff opposed, maintaining that the Constitution operates as a “contract” the courts must enforce, that Article III should be applied with latitude to permit challenges to unconstitutional acts, and that his injury was the breach of the constitutional “contract” and, by way of example, anticipated consumer price increases. He disclaimed reliance on any injury tied to his personal payment of duties.

Judge Jennifer Choe-Groves granted the motion. In a reported opinion, Slip Op. 25-65 (May 23, 2025), the Court held that while § 1581(i) jurisdiction existed over the subject matter (tariffs imposed for non-revenue purposes), the plaintiff lacked Article III standing. The Court found no injury in fact because the asserted injury—government nonobservance of the Constitution—is an abstract, generalized grievance common to all citizens, and the consumer-price harms were speculative and not particularized to the plaintiff (he did not allege he paid duties or incurred specific increased costs). Because injury in fact was lacking, the Court did not reach causation, redressability, prudential standing, or the merits of the constitutional claims, and it expressed no view on the constitutionality of the IEEPA tariffs. The complaint was dismissed without prejudice, with leave to amend by June 23, 2025.

Procedurally, the Court assigned the case on February 7, 2025, held a status conference on February 28, 2025, and set initial scheduling deadlines. After dismissal without prejudice, the docket reflects that the plaintiff filed an amended complaint; on July 1, 2025, the Court set a briefing schedule. On July 21, 2025, the United States filed a renewed motion to dismiss (or, alternatively, a response to the plaintiff’s reconsideration request). The plaintiff filed his response on August 11, 2025. No further ruling on the amended complaint is reflected in the materials provided.

Key legal foundations and authorities cited include: 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i) (jurisdiction), IEEPA (50 U.S.C. §§ 1701–1702), the National Emergencies Act, the First, Article I, and Article II provisions invoked by the plaintiff, and standing precedents such as Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins, Valley Forge Christian College v. Americans United, DaimlerChrysler Corp. v. Cuno, and Clapper v. Amnesty International. There was no trial or settlement, and no appeal is noted in the record.
results.46758:
On June 20, 2025, three immigration detainees filed a habeas petition under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 in the Central District of California, challenging their arrests during a large federal immigration enforcement effort in Los Angeles and seeking to prevent transfer out of the district. Days later, they and additional individual and organizational plaintiffs filed a First Amended Petition/Complaint alleging a putative class action against senior federal officials responsible for immigration enforcement in the Los Angeles region. The plaintiffs include day laborers and other workers and three membership organizations (including a major farmworker union and a worker center network). They are represented by nonprofit legal organizations and private counsel. The defendants are the Department of Homeland Security Secretary, the Attorney General, ICE and CBP leadership, and the local ICE Field Office Director, represented by the federal government.

The case challenges “Operation At Large,” which began June 6, 2025 and deployed CBP and ICE teams to make contacts in public places across the Central District (Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, Ventura, Santa Barbara, and San Luis Obispo Counties). Plaintiffs allege that agents, often masked and armed, in unmarked vehicles, conducted detentive stops without reasonable suspicion, focusing on locations such as carwashes, day labor pick-up sites, tow yards, bus stops, and Home Depots. The record includes incidents where a U.S. citizen was seized outside a tow yard despite presenting a Real ID, a dual U.S.–Mexico citizen taken to a nearby location for questioning after providing a California driver’s license, and three Pasadena day laborers surrounded by masked men with guns, handcuffed, and taken away without agents identifying themselves or stating the basis for arrest. Organizational declarations describe similar stops of their members and widespread fear and disruption. Plaintiffs also assert separate claims concerning denial of access to counsel and illegal conditions in the downtown Los Angeles federal holding area known as “B-18.”

Proceedings moved quickly. The initial transfer-related TRO application on June 20 was withdrawn based on the government’s agreement to keep the habeas petitioners at Adelanto and not transfer them pending bond hearings. On July 2, 2025, plaintiffs filed their First Amended Petition/Complaint, adding individuals and four organizations and class allegations. On July 3, plaintiffs filed two ex parte TRO applications: (1) to enjoin suspicionless detentive stops district-wide; and (2) to remedy denial of access to counsel and conditions at B-18. After full briefing and a July 10 hearing, on July 11, 2025, Judge Maame Ewusi-Mensah Frimpong granted both TRO applications. As to stops and arrests, the court enjoined federal officials in the Central District “from conducting detentive stops unless the agent or officer has reasonable suspicion that the person to be stopped is within the United States in violation of U.S. immigration law,” and further barred them, “in connection with” that requirement, from relying solely—alone or in combination—on four factors to form reasonable suspicion: (i) apparent race or ethnicity; (ii) speaking Spanish or speaking English with an accent; (iii) presence at a particular location (e.g., bus stop, car wash, tow yard, day-labor site, agricultural site, etc.); or (iv) the type of work one does, with an “except as permitted by law” clause attached to that list. The district court found plaintiffs likely to succeed in showing a pattern of detentive seizures without reasonable suspicion, and addressed the same Fourth Amendment issues only (the statutory and regulatory theories were not the basis of the Stop/Arrest TRO). See 2025 WL 1915964 (C.D. Cal. July 11, 2025).

Defendants noticed an appeal and sought stays in both courts. The district court denied a stay on July 17, 2025. The Ninth Circuit initially denied the government’s first stay motions for failure to comply with Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 8 but set expedited argument. On August 1, 2025, a Ninth Circuit panel (Judges Gould, Berzon, and Sung) denied a stay pending appeal except for staying the single phrase “except as permitted by law” in the TRO’s paragraph limiting the four enumerated factors. The court held the TRO appealable and concluded that plaintiffs—both individuals and associations—have standing to seek prospective equitable relief based on evidence of a pattern of officially sanctioned detentive stops and a realistic threat of recurrence. It further held the TRO is not an impermissibly vague “follow-the-law” order when read together with its specific prohibitions, and that prohibiting sole reliance on the four factors is consistent with the Fourth Amendment’s totality-of-the-circumstances standard because, in the Central District’s context, those factors describe a broad profile that cannot alone yield particularized reasonable suspicion. The panel also upheld the district-wide geographic scope as necessary to give complete relief to the named individual and association plaintiffs. The stay was granted only to the extent of suspending the words “except as permitted by law” in the TRO; otherwise, the TRO remains in effect pending appeal. (Order, No. 25-4312 (9th Cir. Aug. 1, 2025) (published).)

Separately, one of the initial habeas petitioners sought release from detention after the immigration court declared itself without jurisdiction to hold a bond hearing. On July 30, 2025, Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym granted the ex parte application and ordered the petitioner’s immediate release on a $5,000 bond with electronic monitoring, finding the court had inherent authority to grant bail in habeas proceedings and that extraordinary circumstances warranted release, including the government’s inconsistent positions on bond-hearing jurisdiction and the petitioner’s serious uncontrolled hypertension and related symptoms. The court found the petitioner neither a danger nor a flight risk and declined to stay its order.

Key filings and schedules include: the district court’s denial of a stay (July 17, 2025); the Ninth Circuit’s procedural denial of the first stay motions for Rule 8 noncompliance (July 16, 2025); intervention granted to the City and County of Los Angeles and several local municipalities (July 29, 2025); the defendants’ motion for reconsideration of intervention denied (Aug. 13, 2025); plaintiffs’ motions for preliminary injunction (including on the Fifth Amendment right to counsel at B-18) set for hearing September 24, 2025; and plaintiffs’ motion to certify a “Suspicionless Stop” class filed August 7, 2025. A related Central District case, Bautista v. Santacruz, Jr. (No. 5:25-cv-01873-SSS-BFM), involved parallel issues; the government’s jurisdictional arguments from that matter were noted and rejected in the orders here.

Legal basis and remedies: Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief against alleged violations of the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable seizures (stop/arrest practices) and Fifth Amendment due process (denial of access to counsel and conditions at B-18), as well as habeas relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 for individual detainees. The government invoked INA channeling provisions (8 U.S.C. § 1252), but both the district court and the magistrate judge rejected those arguments for these collateral detention challenges. The TRO presently bars federal agents in the Central District from conducting detentive stops without reasonable suspicion and from relying solely on the four enumerated factors to form reasonable suspicion; the clause “except as permitted by law” is stayed by the Ninth Circuit pending appeal. The preliminary injunction hearing is set for September 24, 2025. No trial has occurred, and no settlement or monitoring regime has been ordered. Judge Maame Ewusi-Mensah Frimpong presides at the district court; Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym ruled on the habeas release application. The Ninth Circuit panel comprises Judges Ronald M. Gould, Marsha S. Berzon, and Jennifer Sung.
results.46378:
On April 10, 2025, four noncitizen students enrolled at Michigan public universities filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the federal immigration authorities—the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Acting Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and ICE’s Detroit Field Office Director. The students are individuals (not a class). They are represented by cooperating counsel with the ACLU of Michigan and private counsel.

The case arose after DHS terminated each student’s record in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) between April 4–8, 2025. Each learned of the termination from their school, not from DHS. The termination reason entered in SEVIS was substantially the same across the students, stating that the individual was “identified in criminal records check and/or has had their VISA revoked,” and—at least for some—was prefaced with “OTHERWISE FAILING TO MAINTAIN STATUS.” The students alleged they maintained their F‑1 status requirements, had no criminal convictions (two had brief arrests with no charges; one had only traffic infractions; another had previously withdrawn an application for admission at the border), and had received no State Department notice of visa revocation (one never held an F‑1 visa because he changed status inside the U.S.). They also alleged the SEVIS actions were part of a nationwide pattern of mass terminations affecting hundreds of students within days.

Legal foundation and claims. The students sought emergency and permanent relief under:
- The Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause (procedural due process), alleging DHS terminated their F‑1 student status without notice, reasons, or an opportunity to be heard before an impartial adjudicator.
- The Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), alleging the terminations were arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and contrary to constitutional right, including that DHS lacked regulatory authority to terminate F‑1 status on the stated grounds, citing 8 C.F.R. §§ 214.1(d) and 214.2(f). They also alleged a policy/pattern-and-practice (Accardi doctrine) and a due process claim regarding potential detention.

Relief sought. The students requested: (1) a temporary restraining order and then a preliminary injunction restoring each student’s valid F‑1 status in SEVIS and setting aside the termination decisions; (2) an order prohibiting DHS/ICE from terminating their F‑1 status absent valid grounds and pre-deprivation procedures; (3) prohibitions on arrest, detention, transfer, initiation of removal, or deportation based on the SEVIS terminations without notice to the court and counsel; (4) declaratory relief; and (5) attorneys’ fees. They asked to waive bond.

Defendants’ response. DHS/ICE opposed the TRO, arguing a TRO would alter, not preserve, the status quo. Substantively, the government asserted SEVIS is a DHS recordkeeping system and a SEVIS termination does not control or necessarily reflect lawful nonimmigrant status; accordingly, there was no final, reviewable agency action and no protected property interest in a SEVIS record. ICE submitted a declaration from its National Security Division (Andre Watson) stating:
- SEVP terminated the SEVIS records after criminal-history checks returned matches or after a prior CBP inadmissibility encounter; the State Department had prudentially revoked visas for two students (revocation upon departure).
- SEVIS termination does not terminate nonimmigrant status; prudential visa revocation, by itself, does not render one removable.
- No plaintiff had been detained or placed in removal proceedings.

Proceedings and rulings. Judge Stephen J. Murphy III held a hearing on April 15, 2025. On April 17, 2025, the court denied the requested TRO. The court held the record was insufficient to conclude that terminating a SEVIS record is synonymous with terminating F‑1 status or that a SEVIS termination, standing alone, carries legal consequences—issues central to likelihood of success under the APA and due process claims. The court noted the government’s representation that it did not believe the students had lost status and saw no basis then to initiate removal, undermining irreparable-harm arguments tied to detention or deportation. The court set a briefing schedule and a preliminary injunction hearing (later extended by stipulation). The court did not issue any injunctive decree.

Subsequent filings included plaintiffs’ motion for expedited discovery, which the court granted in part and denied in part on April 30, 2025, and defendants’ preliminary-injunction opposition. Before the scheduled preliminary injunction hearing, the parties filed a stipulated order of dismissal, which the court entered on May 29, 2025. No settlement terms were filed on the docket, and there were no reported opinions, trials, appeals, monitors, or enforcement disputes.

Context and legal basis cited by the parties. The students relied on Fifth Amendment procedural due process and APA § 706(2) (arbitrary/capricious, contrary to law, contrary to constitutional right), arguing DHS lacked authority to terminate status outside the grounds specified in 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d), and that visa revocation cannot by itself warrant SEVIS termination during ongoing study. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting terminations without valid grounds and pre-deprivation procedures and barring arrest/detention/removal based on the SEVIS entries. The government responded that SEVIS is a data system (with schools contributing entries under 8 C.F.R. § 214.3(g)) that does not determine immigration status, that prudential visa revocations had occurred for two students, that no removal proceedings were initiated, and that the APA claim failed for lack of final agency action and because the Privacy Act provides an exclusive scheme for data-record challenges not available to non-U.S. persons.

Judge:
- District Judge Stephen J. Murphy III presided; Magistrate Judge David R. Grand was assigned.

Key dates:
- Complaint and emergency TRO/PI motion filed: April 10, 2025.
- TRO hearing: April 15, 2025.
- Order denying TRO: April 17, 2025 (ECF No. 20).
- Partial grant of expedited discovery: April 30, 2025.
- Stipulated dismissal: May 29, 2025.

Related litigation (not consolidated): Plaintiffs cited contemporaneous cases in other districts where courts issued TROs in similar SEVIS/F‑1 disputes (e.g., D.N.H., E.D.N.Y., D. Mass.), but no formal relation was established in this case.
