On April 9, 2025, two Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law clinical professors—one who directs the Community Justice and Civil Rights Clinic and another who teaches and practices in the Center on Negotiation, Mediation, and Restorative Justice—filed a federal lawsuit in the Northern District of Illinois (Case No. 1:25‑cv‑03837). They sued the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Education and the Workforce, its Chair, and the Chair of its Subcommittee on Higher Education and Workforce Development in their official capacities. Northwestern University and two of its officers (the president and the board chair) were named as nominal defendants to effectuate injunctive relief because they received the Committee’s demand and control the records at issue. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel and the Center for Constitutional Rights.

The suit arises from a March 27, 2025 letter in which the House Committee demanded that Northwestern produce, by April 10, 2025, extensive materials concerning the law school’s Bluhm Legal Clinic and the plaintiffs’ academic and legal work. The demanded categories included: (1) all written policies governing law school clinics and client representations; (2) detailed budgets for the Bluhm Legal Clinic and for each of its clinics and centers; (3) a list of funding sources for the clinic and its programs; (4) a list of all payments by the Community Justice and Civil Rights Clinic to non‑employees since 2020; and (5) all hiring materials and performance reviews for one of the professors. The Committee’s letter stated its concerns about “left‑wing” advocacy and referenced the professor’s pro bono defense of protesters named in civil litigation, while copying the U.S. Attorney General and the U.S. Secretary of Education.

The plaintiffs allege that the Committee’s demands exceed congressional authority and lack a valid legislative purpose, and that enforcing them would violate multiple constitutional protections. They assert First Amendment violations (free speech, freedom of association, right to petition, and academic freedom) based on alleged viewpoint discrimination, compelled disclosure of donors and associations, and retaliation; Fifth Amendment violations (due process and equal protection) based on interference with attorney‑client relationships and allegedly irrational targeting; and Sixth Amendment violations premised on interference with clients’ right to counsel of choice and effective representation. They contend that producing donor identities, budgets, personnel files, and vendor payments would chill speech, deter donors and partners, expose confidential mediation and clinical practice information, and impair ongoing representations (including one client who, they say, already withdrew).

The plaintiffs sought declaratory relief and emergency injunctive relief (temporary, preliminary, and permanent) to stay and prohibit Northwestern’s production of the demanded materials and to bar the Committee from obtaining them.

The case was assigned to Judge Elaine E. Bucklo. Because the Committee’s deadline was imminent, an emergency hearing on the TRO motion was held on April 10, 2025 before Emergency Judge Andrea R. Wood. The court denied the emergency TRO as moot and without prejudice, for reasons stated on the record. No written opinion issued.

Subsequent docket activity included appearances by counsel for the Committee and Northwestern, waivers of service by the nominal defendants, and routine pro hac vice admissions. On June 24, 2025, Judge Bucklo granted the parties’ joint motion to stay the case. The matter is stayed until further order, with a status hearing set for September 22, 2025 and a joint status report due September 15, 2025.

There are no reported opinions, no class allegations, and no related or consolidated cases noted on the docket. No trial has been set. The relief sought remains declaratory and injunctive, with no claim for damages.

On April 7, 2025, a software engineer in lawful F‑1 student status working under a STEM OPT authorization filed suit in the Northern District of California against the President, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Acting Director of ICE, and ICE’s San Francisco Field Office Director. Represented by private counsel (Van Der Hout LLP), the plaintiff brought an individual (non‑class) action under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging that DHS/ICE unlawfully terminated the plaintiff’s SEVIS record on March 28, 2025, by coding the record as “Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status” with a narrative referencing INA § 237(a)(1)(C)(i), and that the termination lacked legal authority and due process. The plaintiff also alleged that DHS adopted an unlawful policy targeting African, Arab, Middle Eastern, Muslim, and Asian students, in violation of the APA and the Accardi doctrine. The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief: vacatur of the SEVIS termination; restoration of the SEVIS record; an order preserving F‑1 status, continued STEM OPT employment, and eligibility to change to H‑1B; and prohibitions on arrest, transfer out of the district, and removal during the litigation.

The factual predicate asserted that since late March 2025 DHS/ICE, through SEVP, terminated hundreds of students’ SEVIS records, often after State Department notifications of visa revocations, and that some affected students were arrested and transferred to detention facilities in Louisiana and Texas. The plaintiff’s school confirmed it did not initiate the termination. The plaintiff acknowledged a single minor misdemeanor that had been disclosed to DHS and did not involve a crime of violence or a potential sentence exceeding one year; DHS had approved immigration benefits after learning of the offense. The plaintiff alleged compliance with F‑1/OPT requirements and argued that neither a visa revocation nor a criminal records “hit” authorizes ICE to terminate status or SEVIS, and that visa issues can be litigated in removal proceedings if charged.

The government opposed emergency relief, arguing that SEVIS is an information‑tracking system created under 8 U.S.C. § 1372; that SEVP’s change of a SEVIS record to “terminated” is a ministerial, record‑keeping action that neither terminates F‑1 status nor has independent legal effect; that DOS (not a defendant) controls visa revocations, which are distinct from status; that ICE had not charged the plaintiff as removable; and that the plaintiff lacked a protected property interest in a SEVIS record and had not shown likely irreparable harm. The opposition included a declaration from an ICE official stating that SEVP changed the plaintiff’s SEVIS designation after receiving DOS communications that the visa was not valid.

Judge Jeffrey S. White granted a temporary restraining order ex parte on April 17, 2025, and set a prompt hearing. At the April 25 hearing, the Court questioned the government’s “flag only” characterization in light of DHS’s own public guidance stating that SEVIS termination eliminates employment authorization and can trigger ICE investigations. The Court extended the TRO for 14 days, enjoining defendants from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring the plaintiff during the proceedings and from imposing any legal effects that might otherwise flow from the SEVIS termination or any potential visa revocation. The Court also ordered supplemental briefing, including on whether nationwide relief might be appropriate.

On April 25, 2025, the government notified the Court that ICE would reactivate or maintain as Active the SEVIS records for the plaintiffs in these related cases (and similarly situated plaintiffs) while ICE developed a new policy framework for SEVIS terminations; at that time, DHS could not represent what notice or opportunity to respond would be provided before future SEVIS terminations. That same day, the plaintiff’s DSO informed the plaintiff that the SEVIS record had been restored to Active and a new Form I‑20 issued.

Several similar cases were related to Judge White for coordinated proceedings, including S.Y. v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03244), Zhuoer Chen v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03292), Emma Bai v. Lyons (No. 25‑cv‑03481), Sky Qui v. Lyons (No. 25‑cv‑03475), Jungwon Kim v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03383), W.B. v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03407), J.C. v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03502), Shangshang Wang v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03323), and Yiwei He v. Noem (No. 25‑cv‑03480). The Court heard these matters together for TROs and later for preliminary injunctions.

After further briefing and a May 14, 2025 hearing, the Court on May 22, 2025 granted motions for preliminary injunctions in this and the related cases. Although the written order is not reproduced in the record provided here, the Court had previously enjoined the government from imposing legal consequences based on the SEVIS terminations or potential visa revocations and from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring plaintiffs during the pendency of the cases; the preliminary injunctions continued to preserve the status quo while the merits are litigated. The Court set case management conferences for August 1, 2025 (later continued to September 26, 2025) and granted extensions for defendants to respond to the complaints.

Defendants filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025 (No. 25‑4514) from the preliminary injunction orders and moved to stay the injunctions pending appeal. On August 22, 2025, Judge White granted the stay motions in part and denied them in part (terms not detailed in the materials provided).

Judge: Jeffrey S. White, United States District Judge.

Legal basis and relief: The plaintiff’s claims arise under the APA (5 U.S.C. § 706) and the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. The plaintiff seeks declaratory relief that ICE lacked authority to terminate the SEVIS record and that the action was arbitrary, capricious, unlawful, and taken without required procedure; injunctive relief restoring the SEVIS record and prohibiting arrest, transfer, removal, or other legal effects based on the termination or any visa revocation; and preservation of work authorization and ability to change status. The Court conditionally granted the plaintiff’s motion to proceed under a pseudonym.

Related proceedings: Numerous similar actions were related to this case and jointly heard for TRO and preliminary injunction purposes. The government stated on April 25, 2025 that ICE would keep or make those plaintiffs’ SEVIS records Active while it developed a new policy on SEVIS terminations. No trial has occurred. Appeals from the preliminary injunctions are pending in the Ninth Circuit.

On April 3, 2025, nineteen states filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts challenging portions of Executive Order No. 14248, “Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of American Elections,” issued by the President on March 25, 2025. The plaintiffs are state governments represented by their state attorneys general. They sued the President (for declaratory relief), the U.S. Attorney General, the U.S. Election Assistance Commission (EAC) and its commissioners, and the Secretary of Defense in their official capacities.

The states seek declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 2201. Their causes of action allege ultra vires and separation-of-powers violations and intrusions on state authority under the Elections Clause and Electors Clause. They also contend that the executive order conflicts with federal election statutes—the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), and the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act (UOCAVA). The complaint challenges executive order provisions that would: (1) require the EAC to add a “documentary proof of citizenship” requirement to the national mail voter registration form and require state/local officials to record specified document details; (2) require “the head of each” voter-registration agency covered by the NVRA to assess citizenship before providing the federal registration form at public assistance programs; (3) require the Secretary of Defense to add documentary proof of citizenship and state-eligibility proof to the UOCAVA Federal Post Card Application; (4) direct the EAC to withhold election funding from states that do not accept and use the federal form as so modified; and (5) direct the Attorney General to enforce a reading of federal “Election Day” statutes that would bar states from counting mail ballots received after Election Day, and direct the EAC to condition funding on adoption of an Election Day ballot-receipt deadline.

The case is before Chief District Judge Denise J. Casper. Early in the case, the court denied the federal defendants’ motion to transfer or stay in favor of consolidated litigation by private plaintiffs in the District of Columbia, noting this state suit involved different parties and also challenged a provision not at issue there (§ 3(d)). The court recognized the related D.D.C. decision preliminarily enjoining §§ 2(a) and 2(d) as to private plaintiffs. See League of United Latin Am. Citizens v. Exec. Off. of the President, 2025 WL 1187730 (D.D.C. Apr. 24, 2025).

On June 13, 2025, after briefing and argument, Judge Casper granted the states’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The court held the claims challenging §§ 2(a), 2(d), 3(d), 7(a) and 7(b) were ripe, the states were likely to succeed on the merits, and they faced irreparable harm. The court concluded the President lacks authority to direct the EAC to mandate documentary proof of citizenship on the NVRA federal form (§ 2(a)) or to direct state-designated voter-registration agencies to assess citizenship before distributing forms (§ 2(d)), and that those commands contravene Congress’s scheme and procedures for the bipartisan, independent EAC under the NVRA and HAVA. The court likewise found the President lacks authority to require the Secretary of Defense to impose documentary proof and proof-of-state-eligibility on the UOCAVA Federal Post Card Application (§ 3(d)), observing that UOCAVA employs a postcard form and attestation. As to § 7(a), the court held the Attorney General could not undertake civil or criminal enforcement actions against thirteen plaintiff “Ballot Receipt States” whose laws count ballots mailed by Election Day but received shortly thereafter, because the cited Election Day statutes do not provide such enforcement mechanisms and do not bar states from counting ballots cast by Election Day. As to § 7(b), the court held HAVA does not authorize conditioning EAC funding on a state’s ballot-receipt deadline and the President cannot direct the EAC to impose such extra-statutory conditions.

The amended preliminary injunction, entered July 18, 2025, enjoins executive-branch officials (but not the President) from: (1) implementing § 2(a) (EAC documentary proof-of-citizenship requirement and recording of document details); (2) implementing § 3(d) (UOCAVA FPCA documentary proof and state-eligibility proof); (3) implementing § 2(d) (pre-distribution citizenship assessments by voter-registration agencies) as to the plaintiff states; (4) taking civil or criminal enforcement actions under § 7(a) against the thirteen plaintiff Ballot Receipt States (California, Nevada, Massachusetts, Arizona, Colorado, Hawaii, Illinois, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, and Rhode Island); and (5) implementing § 7(b) to condition EAC funding on an Election Day receipt deadline against those Ballot Receipt States. The court found imminent irreparable harm from required system overhauls, diversion of resources, threatened loss of HAVA funds, and likely disenfranchisement of eligible voters lacking ready access to citizenship documents. No bond was required. The injunction remains in effect unless modified.

Key procedural steps include: the complaint (April 3, 2025); denial of transfer/stay (May 9, 2025); grant of preliminary injunction (June 13, 2025), with an amended order (July 18, 2025); and the federal defendants’ notice of appeal (First Circuit No. 25-1726) filed July 31, 2025. A motion to dismiss is pending in the district court with a hearing set for September 4, 2025.

The case turns on constitutional separation of powers and the Elections and Electors Clauses, and on Congress’s statutory framework (NVRA, HAVA, UOCAVA) assigning roles to the states and the EAC. The court has not consolidated this matter with the D.D.C. cases, but cited the D.D.C. injunction of §§ 2(a) and 2(d) as related context. No trial has occurred, no settlement has been reached, and there is no court-appointed monitor.

On March 17, 2025, two active‑duty Air Force members—both transgender men—filed a constitutional suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey challenging President Donald J. Trump’s January 27, 2025 Executive Order 14183, Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness, the January 20, 2025 Executive Order 14168 (defining “sex” biologically for executive branch purposes), and Department of Defense (DoD) and Air Force memoranda implementing those orders. The suit was brought by the service members against the Secretary of Defense in his official capacity, the United States, the Acting Secretary of the Air Force, and the Department of the Air Force. Plaintiffs were represented by public‑interest civil rights organizations (GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders and the National Center for Lesbian Rights) and private firms (Stapleton Segal Cochran LLC; Langer Grogan & Diver P.C.).

The complaint alleged that the new policy reversed prior open‑service rules and now bans transgender people from military service and requires any transgender service member to serve only in their birth sex, including with respect to pronouns, facilities, and grooming; pauses accessions for those with a history of gender dysphoria; and directs separation processing of current members meeting those criteria. Plaintiffs—an E‑7 Master Sergeant with over 14 years of decorated service and an E‑5 Staff Sergeant with six years of service—alleged they were pulled from assignments in early March 2025 (one from training at Joint Base McGuire‑Dix‑Lakehurst, the other from deployment in Kuwait), placed on administrative absence because they are transgender, told they must comply with female standards, and warned they could face involuntary administrative separation as early as March 26, 2025. They asserted violations of the Fifth Amendment’s equal protection component (for exclusion from service, the requirement to serve in birth sex, and the discriminatory executive‑branch definition of sex), procedural due process, and estoppel, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting enforcement of the challenged directives, as well as preliminary relief.

Judge Christine P. O’Hearn presided. On March 18, 2025, the court issued an Order to Show Cause setting a TRO hearing for March 24. Defendants opposed, arguing military deference, that the policy regulates a medical condition (gender dysphoria) rather than sex or transgender status, applies at most rational‑basis review, that plaintiffs had not shown irreparable harm, and that they had failed to exhaust administrative remedies. Defendants also cited prior litigation over a 2018 DoD policy and a then‑recent nationwide preliminary injunction entered in Talbott v. United States (D.D.C.) enjoining implementation of EO 14183 and related DoD policies.

After briefing and argument, on March 24, 2025 the court granted a 14‑day TRO. The order enjoined defendants from initiating administrative separation proceedings against the two plaintiffs based on their transgender status and from enforcing the challenged executive orders and implementing guidance as to them. The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on their Fifth Amendment equal protection claims because the orders classify based on sex and transgender status and failed to show an “exceedingly persuasive” justification under intermediate scrutiny; that plaintiffs were already suffering and faced imminent irreparable harm, including removal from duty, administrative absence, reputational stigma associated with separation processing, and disclosure of personal information; that no bond was required; and that exhaustion was not required because the policies presented a clear constitutional violation, administrative procedures would be inadequate to prevent irreparable injury, and exhaustion would be futile given the directives to separate. On March 25, 2025 defendants asked to stay implementation of the TRO to align with parallel litigation and asserted no separations would begin before March 28; on March 26 the court denied the stay request, noting defendants had not shown a basis for a stay and that staying the TRO would return plaintiffs to the status that prompted emergency relief.

Throughout, the parties and the court referenced related cases, including Talbott v. United States (D.D.C.), which had entered a nationwide preliminary injunction against EO 14183 and implementing DoD policies, and Shilling v. United States (W.D. Wash.). No appeal was noticed in this case. On May 15, 2025, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the action without prejudice.

Legal foundation and relief sought: Plaintiffs proceeded under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 1343, asserting Fifth Amendment equal protection (challenging exclusion, the requirement to serve in birth sex, and the executive‑branch definition of sex), procedural due process, and estoppel. They sought declaratory and permanent injunctive relief, preliminary injunctive relief, and fees and costs.

Factual context: The complaint traced prior DoD policy development: a 2016 policy allowing open service; a 2018 policy restricting service by those with gender dysphoria; a 2021 reversal allowing transgender service under President Biden; and the 2025 executive orders and DoD/Air Force memoranda that, among other things, defined sex biologically, barred accessions by those with gender dysphoria, required service in birth sex, ended use of gender‑identity pronouns, and directed identification and separation of affected service members on an expedited timeline.
results.46234:
Filed March 15, 2025 in the Northern District of New York, this case was brought by three individuals connected to Cornell University: a non‑citizen Ph.D. student studying on an F‑1 visa, a U.S.‑citizen Cornell professor, and a U.S.‑citizen Cornell Ph.D. student. They sued the federal government—initially the President, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and the DHS Secretary—challenging portions of two executive orders issued in early 2025: Executive Order 14161 (Protecting the United States From Foreign Terrorists and Other National Security and Public Safety Threats) and Executive Order 14188 (Additional Measures to Combat Anti‑Semitism). After a hearing on their first TRO motion, the plaintiffs amended their pleading on March 27, 2025 to add the Department of State, the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)’s Acting Director, and ICE’s Buffalo Field Office Director.

The suit is an individual, not class, action. Plaintiffs are represented by a combination of private counsel and a civil rights advocacy organization.

Legal foundation and claims. Plaintiffs asserted constitutional claims under the First Amendment (free speech, right to receive information, and freedom of association) and the Fifth Amendment (due process—vagueness/overbreadth), along with claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706), the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the Accardi doctrine. In the amended filing, the non‑citizen plaintiff also sought habeas relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and invoked the Suspension Clause. Statutory provisions central to the dispute included 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) (consular visa revocation), § 1227(a)(1)(B) (removability upon loss of status), and the jurisdiction‑channeling provisions of 8 U.S.C. § 1252. Constitutionally, plaintiffs alleged viewpoint discrimination and unconstitutional vagueness/overbreadth in the Orders’ references to “hostile attitudes” toward U.S. “citizens, culture, government, institutions, or founding principles” (EO 14161) and the directive to use all available tools to “prosecute [and] remove” people for “unlawful anti‑Semitic harassment and violence,” including having universities “monitor and report” non‑citizen students and staff (EO 14188).

Factual basis. The non‑citizen plaintiff has publicly criticized U.S. policy toward Israel and supported Palestinian rights in campus and public forums. Plaintiffs alleged that high‑level public statements by federal officials conflated pro‑Palestinian advocacy with antisemitism and warned of deportations or criminal prosecution. In March 2025, DHS arrested a former Columbia student activist, which the President publicly characterized as the first of many enforcement actions under the Orders. The State Department revoked the Cornell student’s F‑1 visa under 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i), and ICE stated it attempted to locate him for a civil arrest to initiate removal under 8 U.S.C. § 1227(a)(1)(B) because his authorization had been revoked. Government declarations asserted that the revocation relied on DHS information that the student engaged in “disruptive protests … creating a hostile environment for Jewish students,” and not on foreign policy grounds. Plaintiffs alleged that these actions—and the Orders themselves—chilled their speech and association; the citizens also claimed a First Amendment right to hear the non‑citizen student.

Remedies sought. Plaintiffs requested declaratory and injunctive relief to bar enforcement of challenged provisions of the Orders (including EO 14161 § 1(b) and EO 14188 § 2 and monitoring/reporting directives), to enjoin detention and removal of the non‑citizen plaintiff, to vacate the visa revocation under § 1201(i), and to obtain habeas relief preventing custody and transfer, along with fees.

Proceedings and rulings. Judge Elizabeth C. Coombe presided; Magistrate Judge Miroslav Lovric handled case‑management issues. Plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO) with their initial filing; an ex parte TRO request was denied on March 20, 2025 and unsealed the next day. After expedited briefing, the court held a hearing on March 25, 2025 and, on March 27, 2025, denied TRO relief. The court concluded: (1) it lacked subject‑matter jurisdiction to enjoin the initiation of removal proceedings against the non‑citizen plaintiff because 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(5) and § 1252(b)(9) channel such challenges to a petition for review after a final order; (2) plaintiffs’ challenge to EO 14161 appeared constitutionally unripe because that Order expressed policy and preparatory steps but did not itself proscribe conduct or threaten imminent enforcement against plaintiffs; (3) the citizen plaintiffs failed to show redressable injury for their “right‑to‑listen” claim, because any remedy would require enjoining removal proceedings the court could not reach; and (4) plaintiffs had not established irreparable harm warranting a TRO, including any imminent enforcement of EO 14188 against U.S. citizens. The court noted that the State Department had already revoked the non‑citizen plaintiff’s visa before suit was filed.

Amended filings and disposition. On March 27, 2025, plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint and Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus that added the State Department, the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and ICE officials, challenged the visa revocation under 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i), and renewed requests to enjoin detention, transfer, and removal, as well as enforcement of the Orders. The court set expedited briefing on a second TRO motion. Before the court ruled, plaintiffs filed a notice of voluntary dismissal without prejudice on March 31, 2025. The case was closed on April 2, 2025.

Judge: U.S. District Judge Elizabeth C. Coombe (N.D.N.Y.). No reported opinions were issued; the TRO denial is reflected at Dkt. 40 (Mar. 27, 2025).

Related matters. Plaintiffs cited a contemporaneous Southern District of New York case involving a lawful permanent resident student who obtained a TRO against detention and transfer while challenging enforcement actions (Chung v. Trump, No. 1:25‑cv‑02412 (S.D.N.Y. Mar. 25, 2025)), but this case was not consolidated with any other. No trial occurred, and no appeal was taken. No decrees, settlements, or monitors were appointed.
results.46216:
Basic Case Information
- Filing date: March 12, 2025.
- Parties: Two physicians who are Harvard Medical School faculty sued the federal personnel agency, the federal health department, and the federal patient‑safety research agency, along with their acting leaders in their official capacities. The suit concerns those agencies’ actions affecting a federal patient‑safety website.
- Plaintiffs: Individual physicians and medical school faculty (not a class action).
- Counsel: Plaintiffs are represented by the ACLU of Massachusetts, the national ACLU, and Yale Law School’s Media Freedom & Information Access Clinic. Defendants are represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.
- Judge: District Judge Leo T. Sorokin (D. Mass.).

Legal Foundation
- Causes of action: (1) First Amendment (viewpoint discrimination and unreasonable restriction in a government‑run forum), and (2) Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claims alleging agency action that is arbitrary and capricious, contrary to constitutional right, and exceeding statutory authority (5 U.S.C. § 706).
- Statutory/constitutional bases: First Amendment; APA, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551–706. Plaintiffs also challenge OPM’s reliance on 5 U.S.C. § 1103(a)(1), (5).
- Remedy sought: Declaratory and injunctive relief, vacatur of the OPM guidance to the extent it mandates takedowns, restoration of removed materials, and fees.

Context and Factual Basis
- AHRQ’s Patient Safety Network (PSNet), launched in 2005 and merged with “WebM&M” in 2015, publishes case studies and expert commentaries on patient safety. Content is authored by private experts, curated by contractor‑editors, and displays a disclaimer that it is not the official position of AHRQ or HHS.
- Plaintiffs authored two PSNet commentaries: (1) an endometriosis diagnostic commentary (published June 24, 2020) noting that endometriosis can occur in trans and non‑gender‑conforming people, and (2) a suicide‑risk commentary (published January 7, 2022) listing LGBTQ and transgender individuals among higher‑risk groups with a JAMA citation.
- On January 20, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14168 (“Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government”), directing agencies to remove statements that “promote or otherwise inculcate gender ideology.”
- On January 29, 2025, OPM issued a memorandum to all agencies instructing—by January 31, 2025—removal of “all outward facing media (websites, social media accounts, etc.) that inculcate or promote gender ideology,” and to report actions by February 7, 2025.
- On January 31, 2025, HHS relayed the directive internally. AHRQ identified PSNet materials via word searches for terms including “transgender,” “nonbinary,” “gender identity,” and “LGBTQ,” and removed the two plaintiffs’ commentaries (and about 20 items total).
- AHRQ offered to repost plaintiffs’ content only if the “problematic words” were deleted; the suicide‑risk piece required removing “transgender” and “LGBTQ,” and the endometriosis piece required deleting its final sentence. Plaintiffs declined. AHRQ later rejected plaintiffs’ proposed alternative wording for the endometriosis piece and reiterated that “no reference to transgender” would be permitted.

Filings and Proceedings
- March 12, 2025: Complaint filed alleging First Amendment violations (viewpoint‑based censorship in a limited public forum and unreasonableness) and APA violations (arbitrary and capricious, ultra vires, and contrary to constitutional right); seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and restoration of removed content.
- April 1, 2025: Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. Defendants opposed, arguing lack of standing/redressability (PSNet contract had expired on March 24, 2025 and the site was static), reasonableness of actions in a limited public forum, no final agency action, and that OPM did not exceed statutory authority.
- May 21, 2025: Hearing held.
- May 23, 2025: Preliminary injunction granted in part.

Court Rulings on Important Filings
- Preliminary Injunction (May 23, 2025):
  - The court held plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits of their First Amendment claim because PSNet is a limited public forum and the removals amounted to “textbook” viewpoint discrimination; restrictions also appeared unreasonable in light of PSNet’s patient‑safety purpose.
  - The court found plaintiffs also likely to succeed on APA claims: the removals were final agency action and likely arbitrary and capricious, and OPM likely exceeded statutory authority by directing agencies to take down outward‑facing media under 5 U.S.C. § 1103, which concerns OPM’s own functions and civil‑service management, not other agencies’ website content.
  - The court rejected defendants’ standing/redressability arguments, finding restoration feasible despite the PSNet contract lapse.
  - Irreparable harm was presumed from the First Amendment violation. Balance of equities and public interest favored plaintiffs.
  - Relief ordered: within seven days, defendants must restore to PSNet complete, unaltered versions of (a) the two plaintiffs’ commentaries and (b) all other content authored by private parties that was removed from PSNet pursuant to implementation of EO 14168. The injunction remains in effect until judgment unless modified. The court declined broader, forward‑looking relief enjoining all future implementation of the OPM memorandum because the record did not show ongoing harm beyond PSNet.

Decrees
- Date and terms: Preliminary injunction entered May 23, 2025; restoration of specified content within seven days; no bond required; remains in effect until entry of judgment unless altered by a higher court or the district court.

Related Cases
- The court noted, but did not defer to, a separate suit in the District of Columbia (Doctors for America v. OPM) addressing similar issues. No consolidation.

Subsequent Proceedings
- June 16, 2025: Defendants moved to dismiss for lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction (mootness, standing, ripeness). That motion was fully briefed and remains pending on the docket as of the latest filings.

Monitoring/Settlement
- No court‑appointed monitor. No settlement reported.

Summary of the Dispute
- The case challenges the removal and conditional reposting of privately authored, peer‑reviewed patient‑safety commentaries from a government‑run medical‑safety website based on references to LGBTQ and transgender people, undertaken to comply with an Executive Order and an OPM directive. The court found a strong likelihood that the actions were unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination in a limited public forum and likely unlawful under the APA, and ordered restoration of the removed private‑party materials to PSNet while the case proceeds.
results.46207:
Filed March 7, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this class action is brought by three transgender federal prisoners on behalf of similarly situated people in Bureau of Prisons (BOP) custody against the President (official capacity), the Attorney General, the Acting BOP Director, and senior BOP officials. The plaintiffs are represented by public‑interest counsel (ACLU Foundation, ACLU of the District of Columbia, and Transgender Law Center). They challenge Executive Order 14168 (issued Jan. 20, 2025) and BOP implementing memoranda that, as applied in federal prisons, prohibit spending for medical procedures, treatments, or drugs “for the purpose of conforming an inmate’s appearance to that of the opposite sex,” and bar gender‑affirming accommodations (e.g., binders, opposite‑sex undergarments, hair‑removal devices, and pronoun use). Before the EO, BOP provided gender‑affirming care under its 2016 and 2023 clinical guidance and a 2022 Transgender Offender Manual, including hormone therapy, surgery referrals, and clothing/commissary accommodations.

Legal foundation and relief sought: Plaintiffs allege (1) Eighth Amendment violations (deliberate indifference to serious medical needs), (2) Fifth Amendment equal‑protection violations, (3) disability discrimination under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and (4) Administrative Procedure Act (APA) violations (final agency action that is unconstitutional and arbitrary and capricious). They seek declaratory and injunctive relief setting aside BOP’s memoranda, enjoining EO 14168 as applied to BOP medical care and accommodations, a stay of agency action under 5 U.S.C. § 705, restoration/continuation of gender‑affirming hormone therapy and accommodations, class certification, and fees.

Proceedings and rulings: On March 17, 2025, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction (and § 705 stay) and for provisional class certification. Amici States (Indiana, Idaho, and 22 others) supported defendants, arguing policymakers may categorically regulate contested medical interventions and that the Eighth Amendment does not compel prisons to provide them. After briefing and a May 22 hearing, Judge Royce C. Lamberth granted the preliminary injunction and certified a class on June 3, 2025.

- Jurisdiction and exhaustion: The court found the case not moot despite partial restoration of some hormones (voluntary cessation), and held PLRA exhaustion was excused because, as of filing, the grievance process operated as a “dead end” given BOP’s then-uniform implementation of the EO and memoranda.

- APA merits: The court found the challenged BOP memoranda were reviewable final agency action and that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA claims. The memoranda provided no reasoned explanation, treated gender dysphoria differently from comparable medical needs without justification, and failed to account for reliance interests or the abrupt reversal of longstanding BOP policy. The court declined, at this stage, to reach the constitutional claims.

- Irreparable harm and equities: The court credited evidence that stopping hormone therapy and revoking accommodations caused or risked serious psychological harm (including suicidality) and found the equities and public interest favored an injunction.

- Preliminary injunction (significant terms): The court ordered BOP to make social accommodations available to all class members to the same extent as before the EO and to provide hormone therapy to class members prescribed such medications by BOP or other medical personnel to the same extent as before the EO (pending litigation). On August 20, 2025, the court granted a renewed preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of EO 14168 § 4(c) against any class member from September 1 to November 30, 2025.

Class certification: The court certified a Rule 23(b)(2) class (after modifying the proposed definition) consisting of “all persons who are currently or will be incarcerated in BOP facilities with a current diagnosis of gender dysphoria or who receive such a diagnosis in the future.” The court found numerosity (over 1,000 BOP inmates with gender dysphoria), commonality/typicality (a uniform policy restricting care), adequacy (no conflicts; experienced public‑interest counsel), and that a single injunction would provide indivisible relief. The court appointed plaintiffs’ counsel as class counsel.

Context and factual basis: The EO directed BOP to revise policies to end “gender ideology” spending; BOP then (1) disbanded the Transgender Executive Council, (2) removed the Transgender Offender Manual from its website, and (3) issued two memoranda (Feb. 21 and Feb. 28, 2025) halting gender‑affirming accommodations and prohibiting funds for treatments or drugs to conform appearance. Plaintiffs had previously received hormone therapy and accommodations that alleviated gender dysphoria; after the EO/memoranda, hormones were reduced, halted, or threatened with discontinuation, and accommodations were revoked, causing anxiety, insomnia, mood swings, and suicidality. The court noted BOP later restored some hormone therapy to hundreds of inmates but found, as of filing, implementation was categorical.

Judge: Judge Royce C. Lamberth.

Important filings and opinions:
- Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction and for Provisional Class Certification (Mar. 17, 2025).
- Amicus Brief of 24 States in support of defendants (Apr. 1, 2025).
- Hearing (May 22, 2025).
- Memorandum Opinion granting preliminary injunction and class certification (ECF 67, June 3, 2025); Order (ECF 68).
- Renewed Preliminary Injunction Order enjoining EO § 4(c) for the class from Sept. 1–Nov. 30, 2025 (ECF 79, Aug. 20, 2025).

Related case: Doe v. McHenry, No. 1:25‑cv‑00286‑RCL (D.D.C.) (earlier TRO/PI involving BOP treatment of transgender inmates referenced by the court).

Status/appeals: Defendants answered on June 24, 2025. No appeals are reflected in the record provided. No settlement or monitor has been appointed. The President remains a defendant; the court noted potential availability of declaratory relief against the President and declined to dismiss him at this stage.

Filed February 11, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this Freedom of Information Act case is brought by a nonprofit public‑interest watchdog organization against several executive‑branch entities and one White House component: the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), the U.S. DOGE Service (USDS), the U.S. DOGE Service Temporary Organization, the former U.S. Digital Service, and the Office of Management and Budget. The plaintiff seeks to compel responses to eight FOIA requests, two of which it asked to be processed on an expedited basis, for records of communications involving Elon Musk and key staff and for records related to the January 2025 removals of inspectors general. The nonprofit is represented by its own in‑house counsel. The case is before Judge Beryl A. Howell.

The suit alleges jurisdiction under FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B), and the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202. The plaintiff contends the DOGE entities are “agencies” subject to FOIA because, as created and implemented by executive orders in January and February 2025, they perform functions beyond advising and assisting the President, including directing embedded “DOGE teams” within federal agencies and accessing or influencing agency systems and operations. The plaintiff further alleges that, despite proper FOIA requests submitted between January 30 and February 3, 2025—including requests to OMB and USDS for (1) communications using specified key terms tied to the inspectors general removals, (2) communications with congressional offices, (3) pre‑inauguration exchanges between the then‑U.S. Digital Service and a nongovernmental “DOGE” group, and (4) post‑inauguration records such as Musk’s calendars, staffing records, Musk’s employment records, and his external communications—defendants did not make timely determinations, did not grant expedited processing, and did not produce records. OMB acknowledged several requests and assigned tracking numbers (including OMB 2025‑613, ‑614, ‑641 to ‑646) but, as pled, provided no determinations. In March 2025, USDS informed the plaintiff that USDS sits within the Executive Office of the President, is subject to the Presidential Records Act, and is not subject to FOIA, which the plaintiff disputes.

The First Amended Complaint (filed March 5, 2025) asserts three FOIA claims: failure to grant expedited processing for the two January 30 requests concerning the inspectors general removals; failure to conduct adequate searches; and wrongful withholding of non‑exempt records. The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief ordering expedited processing of the two urgent requests, FOIA‑compliant searches for all eight requests, prompt production of non‑exempt records and Vaughn indices for any withholdings, as well as costs and attorneys’ fees.

Key procedural steps include: service completed March 6, 2025; an extension granted for defendants to answer; and defendants’ answer filed April 21, 2025 (amended April 24, 2025). On April 2, 2025, Judge Howell granted the plaintiff’s motion for a preservation order, directing DOGE to preserve all records responsive to the eight FOIA requests and to disclose whether all such records had been preserved to date. In granting preservation, the Court noted the use of ephemeral messaging and the need to guard against spoliation during litigation, and observed that FOIA and Presidential Records Act obligations differ.

On May 23, 2025, the Court issued a scheduling order for briefing on whether the plaintiff should be permitted limited discovery to determine whether DOGE wields independent authority sufficient to be subject to FOIA. The plaintiff’s motion for limited discovery was filed June 2, 2025, attaching proposed, narrowly tailored interrogatories, requests for production, and requests for admission focused on DOGE’s authority, structure, leadership, and the role of “DOGE teams.” Defendants opposed on June 16, 2025, and the plaintiff replied on June 23, 2025. As of the latest docketed entries, that discovery motion remained under submission, and no dispositive motion schedule had been set.

Judge: Beryl A. Howell.

Cause of action and legal basis: FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552 (including expedited processing provisions) and Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202. The case turns in part on whether DOGE/USDS/USDS Temporary Organization qualify as “agencies” under FOIA. The plaintiff cites related D.D.C. decisions discussing DOGE’s status, including AFL‑CIO v. Department of Labor, 2025 WL 542825 (D.D.C. Feb. 14, 2025) (discussing agency status issues) and CREW v. U.S. DOGE Service, 2025 WL 752367 (D.D.C. Mar. 10, 2025) and 2025 WL 1392836 (D.D.C. Apr. 15, 2025), which addressed preservation and FOIA applicability in other litigation.

Relief sought: declaratory and injunctive orders requiring expedited processing of two requests, FOIA‑compliant searches and productions on all eight requests, Vaughn indices for withholdings, and attorneys’ fees and costs. The preservation order was granted on April 2, 2025 and remains in effect during the litigation. No settlement, trial, or appeal has occurred. The case remains in pre‑dispositive motion practice focused on preservation and limited discovery regarding DOGE’s agency status.

Factual context: The requests concern communications involving Elon Musk and his staff; the establishment and operations of DOGE as implemented by executive orders; access to and direction of agency systems and functions by DOGE personnel; and the mass removal of inspectors general. The plaintiff alleges urgency due to widespread public interest and potential risks of record loss through ephemeral or non‑governmental messaging platforms.
results.46602:
Filed May 15, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon, this case challenges the April–June 2025 actions that disrupted the federal-state humanities funding partnership. The plaintiffs are a state humanities council and the national federation of state and territorial humanities councils. The defendants are the White House’s DOGE component and its acting administrator; the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) and its advisory National Council on the Humanities; and the Acting Chair of NEH. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel; defendants by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Congress created NEH to fund humanities activities nationwide and, since 1976, to provide grants-in-aid to each state and U.S. jurisdiction through the Federal/State Partnership. In FY 2024 Congress appropriated $207 million to NEH, with $192 million for humanities activities and administration and, by joint explanatory statement and table, $65 million identified for the Federal/State Partnership. A full-year continuing resolution in March 2025 extended those amounts through September 30, 2025. The authorizing statutes direct how Federal/State funds must be allotted to councils with approved plans, including a mandatory formula: 44% in equal shares, 22% by population, and 34% available for discretionary state or regional grants, with funds “available” to states with approved plans at the start of the fiscal year. 20 U.S.C. § 956(f)(4)-(5).

In early April 2025, after DOGE operatives arrived at NEH, NEH sent near-identical emails to roughly 1,500 grantees terminating awards, including operating, special initiative, and other grants to the state councils. The termination letters, sent from a non-NEH email account and not through NEH’s grants system, cited a Presidential Executive Order and 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4), asserted the grants no longer effectuated agency priorities, and offered no appeal. NEH also placed most staff on leave and then executed a large reduction in force, including in the Office of Federal/State Partnership. On June 2, 2025, NEH partially rescinded some FY 2025 council operating grant terminations but restored only “up to 20%” of program funds, leaving many grants terminated and stating there would be no appeal. Plaintiffs alleged widespread harm including layoffs, cancelled programming, and loss of community partnerships.

The amended complaint (June 11, 2025) asserts: (1) APA § 706(1) unlawful withholding/unreasonable delay (failure to process and allocate funds as required); (2) APA § 706(2) agency action contrary to law (terminations and partial rescissions in violation of 20 U.S.C. § 956(f) and procedural requirements, and contrary to the Impoundment Control Act); (3) APA § 706(2) arbitrary and capricious action (lack of reasoned explanation and mass terminations); (4) Separation of Powers (Appropriations Clause, Spending Clause, Take Care Clause); (5) nonstatutory ultra vires action by DOGE; and (6) Impoundment Control Act/appropriations violations via nonstatutory review. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including to vacate the terminations and partial rescissions; to compel NEH to apply the statutory allocation formula and process grants and reimbursements; to prohibit reallocation of committed funds; and attorneys’ fees.

Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction and an APA § 705 stay on June 25, 2025. Sixteen states and the District of Columbia filed an amicus brief supporting the motion. On August 6, 2025, Judge Michael H. Simon granted in part the requested preliminary injunction and § 705 stay. The court held plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits of several claims. It found a strong likelihood of success on the Separation of Powers claim because NEH may not refuse to spend appropriated funds or ignore the mandatory allocation regime in 20 U.S.C. § 956(f); the general “carryover” clause, § 956(f)(6), does not authorize bypassing the statutory formula or withholding funds “available” to states with approved plans. The court also found a likelihood of success on APA “contrary to law” claims: NEH did not comply with the statutory process for suspending or terminating grants to councils, which requires the Chair to make specified findings after notice and opportunity for a hearing before halting further funding, § 956(f)(7); NEH failed to follow the formula in § 956(f)(4); and NEH’s actions likely violated the Impoundment Control Act, which does not permit withholding budget authority without the statute’s required procedures. The court further concluded the mass terminations and “partial rescission” were arbitrary and capricious because NEH provided only boilerplate assertions tied to presidential policy, offered no reasoned explanation or individualized analysis, and did not account for reliance interests.

Addressing jurisdictional defenses, the court rejected the government’s Tucker Act argument, holding the case arises under statutes and the Constitution, seeks equitable relief, and challenges agency action—not contract claims. It found final agency action, that the decisions were not committed to unreviewable discretion, venue proper in Oregon, and associational standing for the federation. The court held there is no private right of action under the Impoundment Control Act, but ICA violations can render agency actions “contrary to law” under the APA. The court found irreparable harm from halted programs, layoffs, and reputational injury; the equities and public interest favored maintaining the statutory status quo.

Relief ordered (Preliminary Injunction and § 705 Stay, Aug. 6, 2025): (1) NEH is enjoined from implementing the April 2, 2025 terminations of grants awarded to the two plaintiffs and to all member councils of the federation; (2) defendants are prohibited from further terminating, suspending, or canceling plaintiffs’ grants approved as of April 2, 2025, absent cause specified in § 956(f)(7) or further court order; and (3) defendants are barred from obligating, encumbering, disbursing, or otherwise disposing of funds committed to plaintiffs and federation members through grants approved as of April 2, 2025, except to plaintiffs. The court stayed, under APA § 705, implementation of the April 2 terminations and any disbursement of the committed funds to others. The court denied the government’s request for an administrative stay and did not require a bond. The injunction remains in effect pending further order. No appeals are noted. There are no consolidated or related cases on this docket, no trial, and no settlement.
results.46478:
On April 22, 2025, two Illinois‑based, family‑owned companies that design and sell educational toys—Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc.—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the President, cabinet officials, and federal agencies, including Homeland Security, Treasury, Commerce, U.S. Customs and Border Protection, and the U.S. Trade Representative. Represented by private counsel (Akin Gump), the companies challenge a series of 2025 executive orders issued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), 50 U.S.C. § 1701 et seq., that imposed sweeping tariffs.

The challenged orders are: (1) Executive Order 14195 (Feb. 1, 2025), imposing a 10% tariff on all Chinese goods (later increased to 20% by Executive Order 14228 on Mar. 3, 2025), predicated on fentanyl trafficking; (2) a further order eliminating de minimis duty‑free treatment for covered Chinese goods; and (3) Executive Order 14257 (Apr. 2, 2025), which declared a national emergency based on persistent U.S. goods trade deficits and imposed a universal 10% tariff on nearly all imports plus country‑specific “reciprocal” tariffs. Executive Orders 14259 (Apr. 8, 2025) and 14266 (Apr. 9, 2025) adjusted the “reciprocal” rate on China to 84% and then 125% and paused those reciprocal tariffs for most other countries for 90 days. With the separate 20% China tariff, most Chinese imports faced a combined minimum ad valorem IEEPA tariff of about 145% before later adjustments. DHS/CBP implemented these orders by modifying the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States.

The plaintiffs allege that: (1) the tariffs are ultra vires because IEEPA does not authorize tariff‑levying (they argue “regulate” importation under § 1702(a)(1)(B) does not mean “tax” and is limited to property in which a foreign country or national has an interest); (2) even if IEEPA could authorize tariffs, these particular measures violate § 1701(b) because they are not limited to “unusual and extraordinary” threats and are not reasonably related to the emergencies declared (trade deficits for the universal order; fentanyl for the China orders), and because the orders also eliminated statutory de minimis and drawback protections; (3) the agency actions implementing the orders violate the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706; and (4) to the extent IEEPA is construed to authorize such broad tariff power, it violates Article I and the separation of powers (nondelegation). They seek declaratory and injunctive relief, vacatur of HTSUS modifications, and fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act.

The government moved to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT) under 28 U.S.C. § 1631 and § 1581(i), arguing the CIT has exclusive jurisdiction over tariff cases. On May 29, 2025, Judge Rudolph Contreras denied transfer and granted a preliminary injunction. The Court held it had jurisdiction because IEEPA is not a “law … providing for … tariffs” within 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i)(1)(B), and concluded the plaintiffs are likely to succeed on their ultra vires claim. The Court reasoned that IEEPA’s text does not mention tariffs or duties, that “regulate” importation is distinct from raising revenue, that the statute’s other listed verbs confirm a non‑revenue regulatory focus, that Title 19 contains specific, limited tariff delegations that would be undermined by a broad IEEPA reading, that historical practice shows no President has used IEEPA to levy tariffs, and that § 1702(a)(1)(B) is limited to property in which a foreign country/national has an interest. The Court distinguished the 1975 Yoshida decision interpreting TWEA, found irreparable harm based on detailed evidence of immediate cancellations, lost sales, and existential business risk (Woldenberg Declaration), and determined that a plaintiff‑only injunction would minimally burden the government given broader, contemporaneous litigation. The injunction enjoined the agency defendants (not the President) from collecting tariffs from these plaintiffs under Executive Orders 14195, 14228, 14257, 14259, and 14266; the Court set a Rule 65(c) bond and initially delayed the injunction’s effectiveness 14 days.

The United States noticed an appeal to the D.C. Circuit (No. 25‑5202) and moved to stay the injunction pending appeal, submitting declarations from the Secretaries of State, Treasury, and Commerce, and the USTR attesting to ongoing, sensitive negotiations and national security concerns. On June 3, 2025, Judge Contreras granted a stay pending appeal, noting the Federal Circuit had stayed a separate, broader CIT injunction and that a stay here would protect the President’s ability to respond to perceived threats while appellate review proceeds. On July 18, 2025, the district court stayed further proceedings pending the D.C. Circuit’s decision.

Amicus briefs were filed: America First Legal supported transfer; a bipartisan group of former officials and scholars supported the preliminary injunction; and several small businesses opposed transfer. Related litigation includes V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. United States, 2025 WL 1514124 (Ct. Int’l Trade May 28, 2025) (permanent injunction later stayed by the Federal Circuit), Barnes v. United States, 2025 WL 1483384 (Ct. Int’l Trade May 23, 2025) (standing dismissal after finding § 1581(i) jurisdiction), Webber v. DHS, 2025 WL 1207587 (D. Mont. Apr. 25, 2025) (transfer to CIT), and Emily Ley Paper, Inc. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1482771 (N.D. Fla. May 20, 2025) (transfer to CIT).

Factual context: The President invoked IEEPA to address fentanyl supply chains (China order) and “large and persistent” trade deficits (universal/reciprocal order), estimating substantial revenue and asserting national security and economic rationales. Plaintiffs import directly from China and other affected countries and attested that the tariffs render many imports uneconomical, causing immediate order cancellations, projected steep sales declines, and potential layoffs and closures. The preliminary injunction currently is stayed, and the case is paused pending the D.C. Circuit appeal.
results.46390:
Filed April 12, 2025, this class habeas action in the District of Colorado challenges the President’s March 2025 invocation of the Alien Enemies Act (AEA), 50 U.S.C. §§ 21–24, to summarily remove Venezuelan nationals alleged to be members of Tren de Aragua (TdA). The petitioners are Venezuelan civil immigration detainees held at ICE’s Denver Contract Detention Facility in Aurora who seek to represent a class of similarly situated detainees in Colorado. They are represented by the ACLU (national and Colorado affiliates) and the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network. The respondents are federal officials and agencies, including the President, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, DHS/ICE leadership, the Secretary of State, and local ICE and facility officials, all sued in their official capacities.

Proceeding under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 (habeas), the All Writs Act (28 U.S.C. § 1651), and the Declaratory Judgment Act, the petition asserts that the Proclamation exceeds the AEA (ultra vires) because TdA is not a “foreign nation or government” and there is no qualifying “invasion” or “predatory incursion” within the AEA’s meaning; violates the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause (for lack of meaningful notice and opportunity to contest “alien enemy” designations); and conflicts with the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), including asylum (8 U.S.C. § 1158), withholding (8 U.S.C. § 1231(b)(3)), and the Convention Against Torture (FARRA, 8 U.S.C. § 1231 note). Petitioners sought class certification under Rule 23(b)(2), a TRO and preliminary injunction (PI), an order barring transfers out of the district, adequate advance notice of any AEA removal, and declaratory relief.

The case arose after the March 14–15, 2025 Proclamation invoked the AEA to authorize immediate apprehension and removal of Venezuelan TdA “members,” bypassing INA processes. According to the filings, more than 100 individuals were removed to El Salvador shortly thereafter and incarcerated at the CECOT “mega-prison,” with reports of harsh conditions and lack of contact; petitioners challenged the government’s designation methods (e.g., reliance on tattoos) and asserted no process was afforded to contest TdA membership. The Supreme Court subsequently held in related litigation that challenges to AEA removals must proceed via habeas and that detainees are entitled to due process and “notice within a reasonable time and in such a manner as will allow them to actually seek habeas relief” before removal. Trump v. J.G.G., 2025 WL 1024097 (U.S. Apr. 7, 2025). The government later described a notice protocol as short as 12 hours to indicate intent to file habeas and 24 hours to file.

On April 14, 2025, the district court (Judge Charlotte N. Sweeney) issued an All Writs Act order preserving jurisdiction by prohibiting removal of the named petitioners (and, as clarified, the putative class) from the District of Colorado or the United States for up to 14 days. On April 22, 2025, the court granted a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), provisionally certified the proposed class, barred transfers of class members outside the district, and required 21 days’ advance written notice (in a language the person understands) of any intended AEA removal, including notice of the right to seek judicial review and to consult an attorney. See D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1163530 (D. Colo. Apr. 22, 2025). The court found habeas jurisdiction, standing (based on the substantial risk of imminent designation/removal), and justiciability (rejecting “political question” arguments). On the merits, the court concluded petitioners were likely to succeed because the Proclamation failed AEA preconditions: Founding-era and constitutional usage show “invasion” and “predatory incursion” are military concepts, and the Proclamation did not establish that TdA is a “foreign nation or government.” The court also found the government’s notice practices inadequate under due process and the Supreme Court’s J.G.G. guidance. The court denied the government’s request to stay the TRO; the Tenth Circuit also denied a stay, finding no irreparable harm given existing Supreme Court constraints on AEA removals and the TRO’s brief duration. See D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1233583 (10th Cir. Apr. 29, 2025). The government later voluntarily dismissed its appeal of the TRO.

On May 6, 2025, the district court certified the class under Rule 23(b)(2): “All noncitizens in custody in the District of Colorado who were, are, or will be subject to the March 2025 Presidential Proclamation entitled ‘Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren de Aragua’ and/or its implementation.” The court found numerosity, commonality, typicality, adequacy, and that respondents had acted on grounds generally applicable to the class such that uniform injunctive relief was appropriate.

That same day, the court granted a preliminary injunction. Adopting its prior statutory analysis, the court again held petitioners were likely to succeed because the Proclamation exceeded the AEA’s scope; it found irreparable harm based on the risk of wrongful AEA removal and the harms alleged in detention abroad, and it held the equities and public interest favored relief. The PI enjoins respondents from detaining, transferring, or removing petitioners and class members under the AEA based on the Proclamation from the District of Colorado. In light of this broader relief, the court lifted the TRO’s 21‑day notice requirement for AEA removals (because AEA removals are now barred in the district while the case proceeds). The government filed a notice of appeal on July 7, 2025 from the class certification and PI (10th Cir. No. 25‑1265); an earlier TRO appeal had been dismissed after the stay was denied.

Reported opinions: D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1163530 (D. Colo. Apr. 22, 2025) (TRO); D.B.U. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1233583 (10th Cir. Apr. 29, 2025) (stay denied). The orders certifying the class and granting the PI issued May 6, 2025 (ECF Nos. 51, 52).

Related national litigation includes J.G.G. v. Trump (D.D.C./D.C. Cir.) culminating in Trump v. J.G.G., 2025 WL 1024097 (U.S. Apr. 7, 2025) (requiring habeas route and adequate pre‑removal notice) and A.A.R.P. v. Trump, 2025 WL 1147581 (U.S. Apr. 19, 2025) (directing the government not to remove members of a putative AEA class pending further order); district courts in other jurisdictions have also issued class TROs or preliminary relief in analogous habeas class cases (e.g., J.A.V. v. Trump, S.D. Tex.).

In sum, the case is a certified Rule 23(b)(2) habeas class action brought by detained Venezuelan noncitizens challenging the President’s use of the AEA against alleged TdA members. The district court has enjoined any AEA‑based detention, transfer, or removal of the class in the District of Colorado while the case proceeds, and the government has appealed the class certification and preliminary injunction.
results.46499:
Filed April 11, 2025 in the Northern District of California, this case challenges an early-April 2025 nationwide operation in which the Department of Homeland Security, through ICE’s Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), terminated hundreds or thousands of active SEVIS records for F‑1 international students. The plaintiffs—individual students pursuing degrees or OPT—allege they were in good academic standing and compliant with F‑1 rules, yet their records were terminated without notice or individualized process based on entries such as “otherwise failing to maintain status—identified in criminal records check and/or had visa revoked.” The terminations immediately jeopardized lawful presence, studies, and work authorization.

Parties and counsel. The plaintiffs are individual students (not a class) from several universities and programs. They are represented by private counsel at DeHeng Law Offices PC, joined later by the Chinese American Legal Defense Alliance. The defendants are the Secretary of Homeland Security and ICE’s Acting Director; in July 2025 the Secretary of State was added in connection with visa revocations. The government is represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Legal foundation and claims. The students sue under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging the SEVIS terminations were arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law, and that the lack of notice and opportunity to be heard violated the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause; they also assert equal protection claims under the Fifth Amendment. They rely on 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(f) (F‑1 rules) and § 214.1(d), which tightly limits DHS’s authority to terminate nonimmigrant status (revoked waivers, private bills, or a Federal Register notice on specified grounds), and on ICE Policy Guidance 1004‑04 stating visa revocation alone is not a basis to terminate a SEVIS record after admission. The amended complaint adds an APA claim against the State Department targeting mass F‑1 visa revocations or “prudential” revocations (often stated to become effective upon departure) purportedly under 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i), alleging those actions exceed statutory authority and were arbitrary when pegged to the unlawful SEVIS terminations.

Relief sought. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief: restoration of their SEVIS records and F‑1 status, an order barring further unlawful SEVIS terminations without lawful process, and later, restoration or withdrawal of visa revocations linked to the same operation.

Proceedings and rulings. On April 15, 2025 the students moved for a TRO. On April 18, Judge Susan Illston issued a 14‑day ex parte TRO limited to the named plaintiffs, enjoining arrests, transfers, and adverse legal effects tied to the terminations, and set a later hearing. The case was related with other F‑1 student cases and reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White, who coordinated proceedings with several related actions (including John Doe v. Trump, S.Y. v. Noem, W.B. v. Noem, and J.C. v. Noem). After litigation began, ICE reactivated affected students’ SEVIS records retroactively and issued a new policy on SEVIS terminations; DHS stated the retroactive activation meant “as though the termination did not happen,” and sent letters to impacted students. On May 22, 2025, Judge White granted preliminary injunctions (covering this and related cases). He found plaintiffs likely to succeed on their APA claim because SEVIS termination functions as a termination of status and DHS did not adhere to § 214.1(d) or its own guidance; he also found irreparable harm (education and work disruption, risk of detention/removal), and that the equities and public interest favored relief.

Preliminary injunction (terms and duration). The Court enjoined DHS and ICE from: (1) arresting or incarcerating the named plaintiffs and similarly situated F‑1 students nationwide; (2) transferring them outside their jurisdictions; (3) imposing any adverse legal effect caused by the SEVIS terminations; and (4) reversing the reinstatement of SEVIS records of students maintaining status under 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(f)(5)(i) for reasons not set forth in 8 C.F.R. § 214.1 without further showing and court approval. The injunction is preliminary and remains in effect pending further proceedings; initial case management conferences were set for August 1, 2025.

Amended pleading and further motion practice. On July 29, 2025, plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint adding the Secretary of State and three additional student plaintiffs, alleging visa revocations tied to the same April 2025 sweep were unlawful under 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) and the APA. On July 30, they moved to amend the preliminary injunction to address the visa revocations; that motion remained pending on the record provided.

Appeal and stay request. On July 21, 2025, DHS and ICE appealed the preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit and moved in the district court for a stay pending appeal on August 8, 2025. They argued (among other points) that the nationwide scope violates the Supreme Court’s decision in Trump v. CASA, that plaintiffs lacked irreparable harm after SEVIS reactivation, that the order is overbroad as to arrests and transfers, and that § 214.1(d) was misapplied to SEVIS records. Subsequent orders on the stay are reflected on the docket but not provided in the record excerpts.

Related cases and context. The Court handled this case together with several related F‑1 student cases in the same district for argument and coordinated relief (John Doe, S.Y., W.B., J.C.). The filings also referenced a TRO issued in a similar case in the District of New Hampshire (Liu v. DHS, No. 1:25‑cv‑00133‑LM, Apr. 7, 2025) and other contemporaneous cases around the country. No class has been certified in this action.

Factual basis. Plaintiffs contend the April 2025 operation combined an NCIC data sweep with SEVIS terminations and visa revocations, without individualized assessments, notice, or lawful basis. Many affected students had no convictions; some had minor or dismissed matters (e.g., expunged arrests or traffic citations). Universities reported receiving no advance notice and advised students that terminations ended their F‑1 status and work authorization. DHS later reactivated SEVIS records retroactively, but plaintiffs allege harms persisted and, for some, visa revocations remained in place.
results.46319:
On March 31, 2025, the National Treasury Employees Union (a labor union representing about 160,000 federal employees across 37 agencies) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the President and the heads of multiple federal departments and agencies, including the Office of Personnel Management, the Departments of Justice, Health and Human Services, Energy, Treasury, and the Interior (Bureau of Land Management), the Environmental Protection Agency, the Federal Communications Commission, and Treasury component heads (IRS, IRS Chief Counsel, Bureau of the Fiscal Service, Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency). The union is represented by its in‑house counsel; the defendants are represented by the U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Division.

The suit challenges Executive Order 14,251, issued March 27, 2025, which invokes 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1) to exclude from the Federal Service Labor‑Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS) a long list of agencies and subdivisions—among them, all of the NTEU‑represented bargaining units at: the IRS; IRS Office of Chief Counsel; Bureau of the Fiscal Service; Treasury Departmental Offices; TTB; OCC; DOE; EPA; FCC; BLM; and HHS components (Office of the Secretary, FDA, ASPR, CDC, and ORR in ACF); and DOJ’s Civil Rights Division and Environment and Natural Resources Division. According to the union, these exclusions immediately terminate recognition and collective‑bargaining obligations, and, under same‑day OPM guidance, end agency participation in grievance procedures, permit disregard of CBA provisions (including reduction‑in‑force articles), and cease payroll dues withholdings. NTEU alleges about two‑thirds of its represented employees (roughly 104,000) are removed from statutory coverage, that dues (94% paid via payroll deduction) will be cut off at the affected agencies, and that it will lose about half of its revenue (about $25 million annually), jeopardizing its operations.

NTEU asserts three claims: (1) the Order is ultra vires because it exceeds § 7103(b)(1)’s narrow authority to exclude only agencies or subdivisions whose primary function is “intelligence, counterintelligence, investigative, or national security work” and only where the statute cannot be applied “consistent with national security requirements and considerations”; (2) the Order conflicts with Chapter 71 generally by effectively nullifying Congress’s statutory collective‑bargaining program; and (3) the Order is First Amendment retaliation, citing a contemporaneous White House Fact Sheet stating “[c]ertain Federal unions have declared war on President Trump’s agenda,” contrasting “hostile” unions with those that “work with him,” and linking the Order to large‑scale reductions‑in‑force and removal of “procedural impediments” to firing. NTEU seeks declaratory relief and to enjoin non‑Presidential defendants from implementing Section 2 of the Order and OPM’s guidance.

Judge Paul L. Friedman granted a preliminary injunction on April 25, 2025 (opinion issued April 28, 2025, 2025 WL 1218044). The court held district court jurisdiction was not precluded by the FSLMRS administrative scheme because the Executive Order itself removed the affected agencies and subdivisions from the statute, leaving no FLRA forum; it noted the FLRA has dismissed similar cases for lack of jurisdiction when an agency is excluded by executive order. On the merits, the court determined the usual presumption of regularity was rebutted by clear evidence in the Administration’s own materials: the Fact Sheet’s focus on “hostile” unions and “mass obstruction,” and OPM’s guidance tying the Order to facilitating RIFs and employee removals rather than to national security criteria. The court concluded NTEU was likely to succeed on its ultra vires claims because the President applied an overly broad interpretation of “primary function” and “national security work,” risking “allowing the exception to swallow the rule” and conflicting with Congress’s stated findings that collective bargaining is in the public interest (5 U.S.C. § 7101(a)). The court found irreparable harm based on ongoing loss of bargaining recognition and dues (already in the millions), threats to the union’s viability, and diminished ability to represent employees. Balancing the equities and public interest, the court emphasized preserving the statutory status quo Congress enacted. It enjoined non‑Presidential defendants from implementing Section 2 of the Order and OPM’s guidance as to the NTEU‑represented agencies and subdivisions, declined to require a bond, and rejected a carve‑out for any single agency on the preliminary record.

Defendants appealed and sought a stay. The district court denied a stay on May 1, 2025, but on May 16, 2025, a D.C. Circuit panel (per curiam; Judge Childs dissented) granted a stay pending appeal. The panel held NTEU had not shown irreparable harm given government directions to agencies (in post‑Order FAQs) not to terminate CBAs or decertify units while litigation proceeds and that revenue loss could be redressed in FLRA proceedings if NTEU ultimately prevailed; it found the injunction impaired the President’s national‑security prerogatives and that the public interest favored preserving presidential autonomy under § 7103(b). The court also observed bonds are generally required for injunctions.

While the appeal proceeds, the district court set summary‑judgment briefing. NTEU moved for summary judgment on June 9, 2025, pressing its ultra vires and First Amendment claims and detailing agency noncompliance (refusal to bargain or process grievances, eviction from union offices, and cessation of dues withholding).
