Defendants cross‑moved on June 23, 2025, arguing: (i) the FSLMRS review scheme precludes district court jurisdiction; (ii) sovereign immunity bars the suit; (iii) ultra vires review is unavailable or, if available, the Order is a lawful exercise of the President’s discretion under § 7103(b)(1) because the identified agencies’ primary functions include investigative or national‑security work and Chapter 71 cannot be applied consistently with national security; and (iv) retaliation fails because the Order would have issued regardless. NTEU opposed, reiterating that the Executive Order itself forecloses FLRA jurisdiction; that ultra vires review is proper to enforce Congress’s limits; that the Order’s stated rationale is unrelated to § 7103(b)(1); and that the record (including the Fact Sheet and Treasury’s immediate suit against an NTEU chapter) shows retaliatory motive and effect. Final decision on the cross‑motions is pending.

Judge: Paul L. Friedman (D.D.C.). On appeal, a D.C. Circuit motions panel (Judges Henderson and Walker; Judge Childs dissenting) granted a stay pending appeal on May 16, 2025.

Legal basis and remedies: The claims rest on the FSLMRS (Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 7101–7135) and the First Amendment. NTEU seeks declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining implementation of Section 2 of Executive Order 14,251 and OPM’s March 27, 2025 guidance and an award of fees and costs.

Key factual context: The Executive Order excludes roughly two‑thirds of the federal workforce (including about two‑thirds of NTEU’s represented employees) from Chapter 71. OPM’s guidance states excluded agencies are no longer subject to Chapter 71, lose obligations to bargain, and should end payroll dues allotments, and it links the Order to large‑scale RIFs and easing removals. The White House Fact Sheet characterizes certain federal unions as having “declared war” on the President’s agenda and frames the Order as preventing “union obstruction” in agencies with “national security missions.” NTEU alleges immediate loss of recognition and dues (94% of its dues revenue is from payroll deductions), diminished bargaining power, and substantial financial harm. The government asserts the affected entities have primary investigative or national‑security functions and that Chapter 71 cannot be applied to them consistently with national‑security requirements. The case remains pending on appeal and on cross‑motions for summary judgment.
results.46285:
Filed March 24, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this case is brought by three nonprofit, membership-based immigrant-rights organizations—the organizations’ members include noncitizens paroled into the United States—against federal officials: the Secretary of Homeland Security, the acting heads of ICE, CBP, and USCIS, and the President, all sued in their official capacities. The plaintiffs are represented by nonprofit public-interest counsel (Justice Action Center), in coordination with counsel for the organizations. This is not a class action; the groups sue on behalf of their members.

The case challenges DHS’s use of expedited removal against noncitizens who were inspected at a port of entry and granted humanitarian parole. Plaintiffs target three written DHS actions issued in early 2025: (1) a January 23, 2025 memorandum instructing DHS components to consider applying expedited removal to any noncitizen amenable to it, including terminating active removal proceedings and parole; (2) a February 18, 2025 ICE directive instructing officers to consider for expedited removal “paroled arriving aliens” (stating there is “no time limit” to process such aliens for expedited removal); and (3) a March 25, 2025 Federal Register notice terminating the Cuban, Haitian, Nicaraguan, and Venezuelan (CHNV) parole processes and ending existing CHNV parole, expressly to maximize use of expedited removal before many parolees reached two years’ presence. Plaintiffs allege that after these directives, ICE began dismissing immigrants’ pending § 1229a (section 240) removal cases in court and arresting them outside courtrooms to process them for expedited removal, with attendant detention and limited access to counsel.

Legal basis and claims: Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief and vacatur under the APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), and 8 U.S.C. § 1252(e)(3), contending that applying expedited removal under 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1) to individuals previously paroled at a port of entry is unlawful. They also assert that the agency actions are arbitrary and capricious and violate due process. The amended complaint (June 11, 2025) adds an Accardi claim and a direct APA challenge to the regulatory definition of “arriving alien” at 8 C.F.R. § 1.2. Plaintiffs also sought a temporary stay under 5 U.S.C. § 705.

Proceedings and rulings: The government moved to dismiss (May 30, 2025) arguing lack of standing, § 1252 jurisdictional bars, timeliness, zone-of-interests, and failure on the merits. Plaintiffs amended as of right (June 11), mooting the motion to dismiss, and moved the same day for a § 705 stay. After a July 9 hearing, Judge Jia M. Cobb granted the § 705 stay on August 1, 2025, staying the January 23 memorandum, the February 18 ICE directive, and the March 25 CHNV termination notice insofar as they subject to expedited removal any noncitizen who has been, at any time, paroled into the United States at a port of entry. The Court found a substantial likelihood of success that the actions exceed statutory authority and are arbitrary and capricious, that plaintiffs’ members face irreparable harm (including curtailed process, detention, family separation, and risk of wrongful removal), and that the balance of equities and public interest favor relief. The Court held that the Designation Provision, 8 U.S.C. § 1225(b)(1)(A)(iii)(II), by its terms excludes individuals who have been “admitted or paroled,” and that the Arriving Aliens Provision, § 1225(b)(1)(A)(i), does not authorize treating previously paroled individuals as perpetually “arriving.” The Court also found the DHS documents internally inconsistent about the legal bases and time limits for using expedited removal and lacking a reasoned explanation. On jurisdiction, the Court concluded that § 1252(e)(3) authorizes the challenge, § 1252(f)(1) does not bar a § 705 stay, § 1252(g) does not foreclose review of systemwide policies, the claims were timely as challenges to written policy directives first implemented in 2025, and plaintiffs met associational standing and redressability. The Court issued the stay nationwide as to all such parolees and required no bond.

Post-ruling activity: The government filed a notice of appeal to the D.C. Circuit on August 5, 2025 (No. 25-5289) and moved in the district court to stay the August 1 order pending appeal; Judge Cobb denied that stay on August 13, 2025. The Court vacated the deadline to answer the amended complaint and directed the government to serve the administrative record within 60 days while the stay remains in place, with a joint status report due after the D.C. Circuit’s decision.

Relief sought and granted to date: Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, vacatur of the challenged DHS actions, an order barring application of expedited removal to individuals previously paroled at a port of entry, potential vacatur of any such expedited removal orders issued to members, facilitation of returns if needed, and attorneys’ fees. To date, the Court has granted interim § 705 relief staying the three DHS actions to the extent they subject previously paroled individuals to expedited removal, pending final resolution. No bond was required.

Judge: Hon. Jia M. Cobb, U.S. District Judge, District of Columbia.

Related litigation: The filings reference other challenges to (i) the nationwide expansion of expedited removal (Make the Road New York v. Huffman, No. 25-cv-00190 (D.D.C.)) and (ii) the termination of parole programs (Doe v. Noem, 2025 WL 1099602 (D. Mass. Apr. 14, 2025), stay granted pending appeal, Noem v. Doe, 2025 WL 1534782 (U.S. May 30, 2025)).

Context and factual basis: The case arises from January–March 2025 DHS actions following an executive order directing termination of categorical parole programs, a January 21, 2025 DHS designation expanding expedited removal to the statutory maximum nationwide for certain noncitizens with less than two years’ presence, and the shutdown of CBP One scheduling. Plaintiffs allege the combined effect exposes hundreds of thousands of parole beneficiaries, including those who built lives and pursued relief while on parole, to arrest, detention, and rapid removal without the procedural protections of section 240 proceedings. The Court’s stay preserves the pre-policy status quo as to expedited removal applicability to such parolees while the case proceeds.
results.46179:
On February 24, 2025, two Senate‑confirmed members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Board, a sitting Board member, the Board’s Executive Director, a White House personnel official, and the President, all in their official capacities. The individual plaintiffs (not a class) are represented by private counsel (Arnold & Porter). The government is represented by the Department of Justice, Civil Division, and the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

The dispute arises from events between January 21 and January 27, 2025. The White House Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel emailed each plaintiff requesting resignation by January 23 and stating they would otherwise be terminated. The plaintiffs did not resign. On January 27, they received one‑line emails stating their positions “were terminated on Thursday, January 23, 2025 at 17:01.” No cause was given. The third Democratic member (then‑Chair) was also terminated. A remaining Board member directed staff to cut off the plaintiffs’ Board access, and the Board publicly announced the terminations. Those actions left the five‑member Board without a quorum, limiting its ability to perform statutory functions, including issuing Board reports and its semiannual reports to Congress.

The suit asserted: (1) Administrative Procedure Act claims (agency action contrary to law, in excess of authority, and without required procedure) premised on 42 U.S.C. § 2000ee and the 2007 amendments that made PCLOB an “independent agency”; (2) a Fifth Amendment due‑process claim; (3) non‑statutory ultra vires claims; (4) mandamus; and (5) equitable relief to enforce statutory and constitutional limits. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief (including reinstatement). The initial complaint sought backpay not exceeding $10,000, but the amended complaint dropped all monetary relief.

On March 12, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for summary judgment; the government filed a cross‑motion on April 3. After a hearing on April 30, Judge Reggie B. Walton granted summary judgment to the plaintiffs in a memorandum opinion issued May 21, 2025. See 2025 WL 1454010. The court held that, although PCLOB’s organic statute contains no express for‑cause removal clause, the statute’s structure and function clearly indicate Congress intended to restrict at‑will presidential removal of Board members: in 2007 Congress removed the Board from the Executive Office of the President, designated it an “independent agency,” deleted “serve at the pleasure of the President” and “under the general supervision of the President” language, required Senate confirmation, partisan balance, expert qualifications, and staggered six‑year terms, and assigned oversight and reporting functions to Congress and the public. The court further held those implied removal protections are constitutional under Humphrey’s Executor because PCLOB is a multimember expert body that does not wield substantial executive power (it cannot regulate, adjudicate, punish, or issue subpoenas on its own). Concluding the removals were unlawful, the court: (1) declared the terminations null and void; (2) ordered de facto reinstatement by enjoining the Board, the Board member, the Executive Director, and the White House personnel official—not the President—from treating the plaintiffs as removed or interfering with their duties; and (3) clarified that each plaintiff may be removed before his term ends only for cause (and, for the holdover member, upon confirmation of a successor). No damages were awarded.

The government noticed an appeal on May 27, 2025 (D.C. Cir. No. 25‑5197) and moved to stay the injunction; the district court denied a stay on May 29, 2025. On July 1, 2025, a D.C. Circuit panel (Judges Katsas, Rao, and Walker) granted a stay pending appeal, concluding the government satisfied the Nken factors. The panel stated PCLOB’s statute lacks clear removal restrictions; PCLOB is not an adjudicatory tribunal and therefore does not warrant implied removal protection; and enjoining the Executive Branch to work with removed principal officers risks irreparable injury to presidential supervision. The district court’s injunction is stayed pending further order of the court.

Key statutory and constitutional bases include 42 U.S.C. § 2000ee (PCLOB’s organic statute); the APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706; and the Fifth Amendment. Remedies sought were declaratory and injunctive relief (including reinstatement), mandamus, and—initially but later withdrawn—limited backpay. There was no trial. The case resulted in a reported district court opinion (2025 WL 1454010) and a subsequent D.C. Circuit stay order; the appeal remains pending.

Judge: Reggie B. Walton.

Decree (district court, May 21, 2025):
- Declared the terminations unlawful and void.
- Held each plaintiff remains a Board member (one through January 29, 2028; the other in holdover through January 29, 2026, unless a successor is confirmed), removable early only for cause (or upon successor confirmation for the holdover member).
- Enjoined the Board and specified officials from treating the plaintiffs as removed or interfering with their duties or benefits of office.

Appeal/Stay:
- Notice of appeal filed May 27, 2025.
- District court denied a stay May 29, 2025.
- D.C. Circuit granted a stay pending appeal July 1, 2025.

Context:
Congress created PCLOB to balance counterterrorism activities with privacy and civil liberties, expanded its independence in 2007, and assigned it significant oversight and reporting roles to Congress and the public. The January 2025 removals of all three members affiliated with one political party left the Board without a quorum, prompting this suit and the district court’s de facto reinstatement order, now stayed on appeal.
results.46106:
Filed on February 11, 2025, this action challenges the U.S. Office of Personnel Management’s disclosure of federal personnel records to individuals associated with a new White House initiative. The plaintiffs are two unions representing federal employees and three current/former federal employees. They sued OPM and its Acting Director, as well as entities created or renamed by a January 20, 2025 executive order—the U.S. DOGE Service (formerly U.S. Digital Service), the U.S. DOGE Service Temporary Organization—and its director. Plaintiffs are represented by private and public‑interest counsel (Lex Lumina LLP; Electronic Frontier Foundation; State Democracy Defenders Fund; The Chandra Law Firm). The United States Attorney’s Office represents the government.

The suit alleges that, immediately after inauguration day, OPM granted DOGE‑affiliated individuals sweeping, “administrative” access to numerous OPM systems that contain highly sensitive personnel information, including the Electronic Official Personnel Folder, the Enterprise Human Resources Integration data warehouse, USAJOBS, USA Staffing, USA Performance, and health‑benefits systems (FEHB/PSHB). Plaintiffs contend the access was given without required vetting, security training, or a demonstrated “need to know,” and that it facilitated creation of a Government‑Wide Email System that used names/emails extracted from OPM databases. The complaint pleads: (1) Privacy Act claims under 5 U.S.C. § 552a(b) (unlawful disclosure) and § 552a(e)(10) (failure to safeguard records); (2) APA claims (5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706) alleging agency action “not in accordance with law” and arbitrary/capricious action; and (3) an ultra vires claim against the DOGE defendants. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief halting disclosures, impoundment/destruction of any records obtained, and compliance measures; they also pleaded Privacy Act damages, though the case has proceeded focused on injunctive relief.

After plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order on February 14, the Court directed briefing and converted the request to preliminary‑injunction proceedings. Defendants moved to dismiss on March 14. On April 3, Judge Denise L. Cote denied the government’s jurisdictional challenge, holding the plaintiffs had Article III standing based on an injury resembling the common‑law tort of intrusion upon seclusion and risk of future harm, and found the complaint plausibly alleged Privacy Act violations. The Court dismissed the direct Privacy Act claims (to the extent they sought injunctive relief) but allowed them to serve as the predicate for APA review, and it sustained the APA claims and the ultra vires claim at the pleading stage. Reported opinion: 2025 WL 996542.

Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on April 25. Following a May 29 evidentiary hearing (including cross‑examination of OPM’s Chief Information Officer), the Court issued a detailed June 9 opinion granting a preliminary injunction. The Court found: (1) OPM “disclosed” records under the Privacy Act by granting access to systems containing personally identifiable information, even if some users did not personally log in, (2) the § 552a(b)(1) “need to know” exception was not satisfied because broad administrative access was extended absent a demonstrated need tied to OPM duties, and (3) OPM failed to establish appropriate safeguards under § 552a(e)(10) by bypassing basic vetting, training, and least‑privilege/separation‑of‑duties principles. The Court further held the challenged actions were reviewable final agency action under the APA and that the Privacy Act did not provide an adequate alternative remedy for the forward‑looking relief sought. It declined to grant relief on the ultra vires claim at this stage because the APA injunction provided meaningful relief. On June 20, the Court entered the preliminary‑injunction order, administratively stayed for 14 days under Rule 62(c) and conditioned on a $1,000 bond. The order requires, among other things, that OPM file within two weeks of the order’s effective date a report describing the processes and procedures put in place since March 6, 2025 to ensure adherence to the Privacy Act before any new grants of access to PII in OPM systems of records. Status conferences and additional administrative‑record supplementation followed.

Legal foundation and remedies: The case is brought under the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (particularly §§ 552a(b) and 552a(e)(10)), and the APA, 5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706(2)(A); plaintiffs also invoked FISMA (44 U.S.C. § 3554) as context for required safeguards. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief and, in the pleadings, damages under § 552a(g), though the Court held injunctive relief lies under the APA rather than directly under the Privacy Act. The preliminary injunction was granted on June 9 and entered June 20 with a 14‑day administrative stay and ongoing reporting; it remains in effect pending further order.

Judge: Hon. Denise L. Cote, U.S. District Judge, Southern District of New York.

Important filings and rulings:  
- TRO motion filed Feb. 14, 2025; opposed by the government; converted to PI proceedings.  
- Motion to dismiss filed Mar. 14, 2025; granted in part/denied in part Apr. 3, 2025 (standing found; Privacy Act claims dismissed only insofar as independent injunctive claims; APA and ultra vires claims proceed). Reported at 2025 WL 996542.  
- Preliminary injunction motion filed Apr. 25, 2025; hearing May 29, 2025; PI granted in a June 9, 2025 opinion; PI order entered June 20, 2025 (administrative stay of 14 days; $1,000 bond; OPM reporting obligations to ensure Privacy Act compliance before any new access to PII).  

Decrees (significant terms and duration): The June 20 preliminary‑injunction order (effective upon posting of a $1,000 bond and after a 14‑day administrative stay) requires OPM to file a report within two weeks of the effective date describing processes and procedures implemented since March 6, 2025 to ensure adherence to the Privacy Act before any new grant of access to PII in OPM systems of records. The preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further order of the Court.

Monitoring: The Court directed OPM to file the compliance report and has held follow‑up status conferences; additional administrative‑record supplementation was ordered, including for DOGE‑affiliated individuals.

Related cases: Courts in other districts addressed similar DOGE‑related access issues. The District of Maryland issued and later converted a TRO to a preliminary injunction against OPM (Am. Fed’n of Teachers v. Bessent), which was stayed on appeal; a separate preliminary injunction issued against SSA (later stayed by the Supreme Court). Other courts addressed related challenges involving Treasury, DOL, HHS, DOE, and CFPB.

Context and facts: The case arises from Executive Order 14,158 (Jan. 20, 2025) establishing the Department of Government Efficiency agenda and redesignating the U.S. Digital Service as the U.S. DOGE Service within the Executive Office of the President. Plaintiffs allege—and the Court preliminarily found—that, beginning January 20, 2025, OPM granted DOGE‑affiliated personnel broad, administrative‑level access to numerous OPM systems containing the PII of tens of millions of federal employees, applicants, annuitants, and family members without required vetting or training and without demonstrating a need to know tied to OPM duties. The Court found these actions violated the Privacy Act’s disclosure and safeguarding provisions and were arbitrary and capricious under the APA. The Court emphasized that while IT modernization is legitimate, it must comply with applicable law and cybersecurity standards.
results.46095:
On February 10, 2025, three higher‑education associations and sixteen universities filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts challenging the National Institutes of Health’s February 7, 2025 “Supplemental Guidance to the 2024 NIH Grants Policy Statement: Indirect Cost Rates” (Notice NOT‑OD‑25‑068). The plaintiffs—two national university associations and a land‑grant association, joined by private and public research universities—alleged that NIH and the Department of Health and Human Services unlawfully capped indirect (facilities and administrative) cost reimbursement at 15% for all new NIH grants and, for institutions of higher education, for existing grants on a go‑forward basis, effective February 10, 2025. Defendants were HHS, NIH, the Acting HHS Secretary, and the Acting NIH Director (later automatically substituted by the current Secretary and NIH Director). Plaintiffs were represented by private counsel (including Jenner & Block LLP and Clement & Murphy, PLLC).

The complaint arose under the Administrative Procedure Act and related statutes and regulations. Plaintiffs claimed the Guidance violated: (1) Section 224 of the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2024 (a recurring rider preserving the 2017 regulatory treatment of indirect costs and forbidding HHS/NIH from developing or implementing a modified approach), (2) HHS’s own grant regulations, particularly 45 C.F.R. § 75.414 and the NIH Grants Policy Statement (governing negotiated indirect cost rates and limited, procedurally‑defined deviations), (3) APA requirements of reasoned decisionmaking (arbitrary and capricious action) and notice‑and‑comment rulemaking, and (4) the APA’s bar on retroactive rules. They sought declaratory relief, vacatur, and injunctive relief (TRO, preliminary, and permanent injunction). Plaintiffs described immediate and irreparable disruption to ongoing clinical trials, research operations, staffing, and compliance activities if the 15% cap took effect.

This case proceeded in tandem with two related cases before the same judge: an action by 22 states (Commonwealth of Massachusetts v. NIH, 1:25‑cv‑10338) and an action by medical and public‑health education associations and hospital groups (Association of American Medical Colleges v. NIH, 1:25‑cv‑10340). The court coordinated briefing and held a joint hearing on February 21, 2025.

Defendants opposed, arguing among other things that the district court lacked jurisdiction because the claims sounded in contract under the Tucker Act; that 45 C.F.R. § 75.414(c)(1)–(3) authorized NIH to deviate from negotiated indirect cost rates for a “class of Federal awards” and the Guidance did so, with reasons including reorienting funds toward direct research, oversight concerns, and alignment with private grant‑maker rates; that the appropriations rider did not prohibit NIH’s action; that no notice‑and‑comment was required; and that the Guidance was not retroactive because it applied only to “go‑forward” expenses.

On March 5, 2025, Judge Angel Kelley granted a nationwide preliminary injunction. The court rejected the jurisdictional (Tucker Act) argument, holding the case stated APA claims based on statutes and regulations rather than contract terms. On the merits, the court found plaintiffs likely to succeed because: (1) the Guidance conflicted with 45 C.F.R. § 75.414—NIH did not provide the required documented justification or pre‑established, publicly available policies, procedures, and decisionmaking criteria, and a uniform, across‑the‑board cap for all awards exceeded the regulation’s allowance for deviations for a “class” or “single” award; (2) the Guidance violated Section 224 of the 2024 appropriations act by modifying the approach to indirect cost provisions and expanding the fiscal effect of deviations beyond the proportional effect in 2017; (3) the Guidance was arbitrary and capricious because NIH offered conclusory rationales, failed to consider critical factors (including reliance interests and differences from private funders), and disregarded the existing audit regime; (4) the Guidance was a legislative rule adopted without required notice‑and‑comment, and HHS had bound itself to use APA procedures for grants‑related rules; and (5) as applied to existing grants, the Guidance was impermissibly retroactive because it impaired rights under already‑issued awards and imposed new obligations on past transactions. The court found irreparable harm (including impacts on clinical trials, research continuity, animals and facilities, staffing, and institutional operations) and held the public interest and equities favored relief.

On April 4, 2025, on defendants’ assented motion, the court converted the preliminary injunction into a permanent injunction, entered final judgment, and vacated the Guidance. In the states’ case (1:25‑cv‑10338), judgment entered for plaintiffs on their APA claims. In the AAMC case (1:25‑cv‑10340), judgment entered for plaintiffs on their APA claims (with a constitutional retroactivity claim dismissed without prejudice). In this AAU/universities case (1:25‑cv‑10346), judgment entered for plaintiffs on Counts I (appropriations rider), III (45 C.F.R. § 75.414/NIH policy), IV (arbitrary and capricious), V (cost‑recovery regulations), VI (notice‑and‑comment), and VIII (retroactivity). Two counts (Appropriations Clause and Public Health Service Act theories) were dismissed without prejudice. The permanent injunction prohibits NIH, HHS, and their officers and agents from implementing, applying, or enforcing NOT‑OD‑25‑068 nationwide, and the Guidance was vacated under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2).

Defendants filed a notice of appeal on April 8, 2025, to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit (No. 25‑1345), appealing the final judgment and permanent injunction and the interlocutory orders merged into it. No trial occurred, and no monitor was appointed. The court’s orders remain in effect pending appeal.
results.46023:
Filed February 3, 2025, this APA case in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia challenges the Treasury Department’s grant of access to its payment systems and records to personnel associated with the United States “DOGE” Service (a rebranded United States Digital Service created by Executive Order 14158). The plaintiffs are three membership organizations—the Alliance for Retired Americans, the American Federation of Government Employees (AFL‑CIO), and the Service Employees International Union (AFL‑CIO)—suing on behalf of their members who receive or make federal payments (e.g., Social Security benefits, wages, refunds). The defendants are the Secretary of the Treasury in his official capacity (Scott Bessent), the Department of the Treasury, and the Bureau of the Fiscal Service (BFS). Plaintiffs are represented by Public Citizen Litigation Group and the State Democracy Defenders Fund; the government is represented by the Department of Justice, Civil Division, Federal Programs Branch.

Legal foundation. Plaintiffs bring claims under the Administrative Procedure Act, alleging that Treasury’s decision to allow DOGE-affiliated individuals to access BFS systems and the personal/financial information therein is (1) “contrary to law” because it violates the Privacy Act of 1974 and, for taxpayer data, Internal Revenue Code § 6103; (2) arbitrary and capricious for failure to engage in reasoned decision-making; and (3) in excess of statutory authority. The requested remedy is declaratory and injunctive relief halting access and requiring future compliance with the Privacy Act, § 6103, and BFS Systems of Records Notices (SORNs), plus fees and costs.

Context and facts. BFS is Treasury’s component that handles most federal disbursements and collections through systems such as Payment Automation Manager (PAM), the Secure Payment System (SPS), and the Payment Information Repository System (PIRS). These systems contain sensitive personally identifiable and financial information (e.g., names, SSNs, dates of birth, addresses, bank account/routing numbers) covered by BFS SORNs published at 85 Fed. Reg. 11776 (Feb. 27, 2020). Executive Order 14158 (Jan. 20, 2025) renamed USDS as the U.S. DOGE Service and directed agency heads, “to the maximum extent consistent with law,” to ensure DOGE has full and prompt access to unclassified agency records and IT systems; agencies were to establish internal DOGE Teams.

At Treasury, Thomas H. Krause (a Special Government Employee) began duties connected with the DOGE initiative in late January 2025; Marko Elez (a temporary transitional Schedule C employee) also worked briefly before resigning on February 6, 2025. Treasury initiated a “payment process engagement plan” in late January to give the Treasury DOGE Team insight into BFS’s end‑to‑end payment process. BFS recognized the scope of access was broader than usual for one individual and adopted mitigations (e.g., “read‑only” configuration, a secure code “sandbox,” laptop logging). On February 3–5, 2025, Elez received access to PAM and SPS; SPS was mistakenly configured with read/write privileges briefly on February 5 before correction to read‑only. Treasury reports an initial forensic review showed no unauthorized actions in the systems; a later filing disclosed that (on January 30) Elez emailed to two GSA officials a spreadsheet with USAID payment information that included personally identifying details; the agency subsequently recovered his credentials and equipment after his resignation. Separately, Treasury and State coordinated to identify and flag certain foreign‑assistance-related payment files for State Department review under a separate Executive Order; one payment was held and four proceeded.

Proceedings and rulings. Plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) on February 5, 2025. After a same-day hearing, the parties negotiated a consent order (entered February 6) deferring ruling on the TRO and preserving the status quo by prohibiting access to any BFS payment records/systems except for: (i) Krause and Elez with “read‑only” access as needed for Treasury duties; (ii) other Treasury employees with a need for the record in performance of duty; (iii) persons otherwise entitled under 5 U.S.C. § 552a(b)(2)–(13) or the Internal Revenue Code. The Court converted the TRO motion to a preliminary‑injunction motion and set briefing. On February 20, the Court modified the consent order (unopposed) to substitute Ryan Wunderly (a Treasury employee) for Elez and to specify that “Special Government Employees or Treasury DOGE Team members” other than those identified could not be granted access; the consent order remained in place pending resolution of the preliminary‑injunction motion.

On February 24, 2025, the Court held an evidentiary hearing and ordered production of the administrative record. On March 7, 2025, Judge Colleen Kollar‑Kotelly denied preliminary injunctive relief and dissolved the interim access limits. In the detailed opinion (All. for Retired Americans v. Bessent, 2025 WL 740401 (D.D.C. Mar. 7, 2025)), the Court (1) concluded it had subject‑matter jurisdiction; (2) held plaintiffs had associational standing (the alleged privacy harm was sufficiently concrete by analogy to intrusion upon seclusion, causally connected, and redressable; sovereign immunity did not bar suit under APA § 702 and the Privacy Act did not impliedly foreclose APA relief); but (3) denied a preliminary injunction for failure to show irreparable harm: plaintiffs did not demonstrate a “likelihood” (as opposed to a possibility) of imminent public dissemination or disclosure outside the federal government, Treasury had imposed monitoring/mitigations, and the claimed injuries were capable of later remediation (e.g., retrieval/destruction) if necessary. The Court emphasized it did not prejudge the merits.

Administrative record and limited discovery. Treasury filed the administrative record on March 10, 2025. On March 13, the Court partially granted plaintiffs’ record objections and directed supplemental information. On March 20, the Court granted in part expedited discovery (narrow written discovery) because the record was insufficient to “ascertain the contours of the precise policy at issue” (what actions Treasury took to implement EO 14158 within BFS), while declining broader discovery. A stipulated protective order governing confidential discovery materials entered on April 1.

Dispositive motions. Defendants moved to dismiss or, alternatively, for summary judgment on April 11, 2025, arguing lack of standing, no final agency action, adequate alternative remedies (Privacy Act and § 6103), and compliance with law (including that DOGE team members were Treasury “employees” with a “need to know” under § 552a(b)(1) and that § 6103(h) permitted access for tax‑administration purposes). Plaintiffs cross‑moved for summary judgment on April 25, 2025, contending Treasury instituted an unlawful system of disclosure without required SORN changes or congressional/OMB notice (5 U.S.C. § 552a(e), (r)); that the “need‑to‑know” exception does not support unfettered access untethered to specific duties; that the policy is arbitrary and capricious for failure to consider privacy risks; and that § 6103 prohibits disclosure of return information absent strict statutory authorization. Briefing concluded May 23, 2025; a joint appendix was filed June 2, 2025. No final decision on the merits has issued.

Related matters. The Court noted other federal cases addressing DOGE‑related access. In New York v. Trump, 2025 WL 573771 (S.D.N.Y. Feb. 21, 2025), the court preliminarily enjoined Treasury from granting DOGE access to payment systems containing PII/confidential financial information. Other courts denied TROs or preliminary relief in different contexts (e.g., EPIC v. OPM (E.D. Va.), UCSA v. Carter (D.D.C.), and State of New Mexico v. Musk (D.D.C.)).

Judge. The case is before U.S. District Judge Colleen Kollar‑Kotelly.

Current status. Interim access limits were dissolved on March 7, 2025. The administrative record is on file, limited discovery has been completed under a protective order, and cross‑motions for summary judgment are fully briefed and pending decision.
results.46563:
Filed May 2, 2025 in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, this case is brought by a growing coalition of local governments and public authorities (counties, cities, housing and transportation agencies) challenging new federal grant conditions the Trump Administration directed agencies to impose after January–April 2025 executive orders. The plaintiffs initially included King County (WA), Pierce County (WA), Snohomish County (WA), San Francisco (CA), Santa Clara County (CA), Boston (MA), Columbus (OH), and New York City (NYC); subsequent amendments added many more local governments and agencies, including transit and airport authorities. They are represented by local government counsel, the Public Rights Project, and private counsel (Pacifica Law Group LLP). The defendants are HUD; DOT and, as the case expanded, its operating administrations FTA, FHWA, FAA, and FRA; and the agencies’ leaders (including HUD Secretary Scott Turner and DOT Secretary Sean Duffy). Later amendments also added HHS and its Secretary.

Plaintiffs challenge conditions newly attached to congressionally funded grants—including HUD’s Continuum of Care (CoC) grants under the McKinney‑Vento Homeless Assistance Act and DOT grants under multiple statutes (e.g., 49 U.S.C. §§ 5307, 5309, 5337, 5339; airport grants under 49 U.S.C. ch. 471; and programs funded by the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act). The contested conditions flow from executive orders on “Ending Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit‑Based Opportunity” (anti‑DEI), immigration enforcement, “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism,” and “Enforcing the Hyde Amendment.” As implemented in HUD and DOT agreements, the conditions include: (1) a DEI certification paired with an admission that compliance with federal nondiscrimination laws is “material” under the False Claims Act; (2) a requirement to “comply with all executive orders”; (3) immigration cooperation mandates (e.g., cooperating with ICE) and, for HUD CoC grants, immigration eligibility verification using DHS’s SAVE system; (4) a prohibition on using funds to “promote gender ideology,” as defined in an executive order; and (5) a prohibition on using funds to “promote elective abortion.” Plaintiffs allege these conditions are unauthorized by statute, unrelated to the grants’ purposes, vague, and coercive.

Plaintiffs bring claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. § 706) and the Constitution, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and fees. They allege violations of separation of powers (Executive usurping Congress’s spending power), the Spending Clause (lack of clear notice and germaneness; coercion), the Tenth Amendment (commandeering state/local officials for federal immigration enforcement), Fifth Amendment due process (vagueness), and APA defects (arbitrary and capricious; contrary to law and constitution; in excess of statutory authority; failure to follow required procedures including HUD’s and DOT’s own rulemaking requirements).

Judge Barbara J. Rothstein granted emergency relief twice. On May 7, 2025, the Court issued a TRO enjoining HUD, DOT, and FTA from imposing or enforcing the challenged CoC and FTA conditions, from withholding or delaying funds based on those conditions, and from requiring certifications tied to them. On May 23, 2025, the Court entered a second TRO extending materially identical relief to additional plaintiffs and to DOT’s other operating administrations (FHWA, FAA, FRA). After briefing and hearings, the Court granted preliminary injunctions on June 3, 2025, and again on August 12, 2025 (the latter addressing additional parties and agencies added by amendment). The June 3 order held the APA’s sovereign-immunity waiver applied; rejected defendants’ Tucker Act argument; found the challenged agency actions reviewable (not “committed to agency discretion”); and concluded plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their APA claims. Specifically, the Court found the new conditions are likely contrary to constitutional separation-of-powers limits and in excess of statutory authority (because Congress did not authorize these conditions in the CoC or transportation statutes) and arbitrary and capricious (no reasoned explanation, reliance on executive orders untethered to statutory mandates). The Court did not need to resolve all constitutional claims to issue the injunction. It also found irreparable harm (including budgetary disruption and loss of critical homelessness, transit, and safety projects) and that the equities and public interest favored maintaining the status quo. The injunctions bar agencies from imposing or enforcing the conditions (or materially similar ones) against plaintiffs and their subrecipients, from withholding or delaying funds based on those conditions, and from requiring related certifications; agencies must treat any actions taken to implement the conditions as null and void and not retroactively apply them. The Court later required agency notice and status reports on compliance. Defendants noticed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit on June 9, 2025.

Procedurally, the case has expanded through amended complaints adding more plaintiffs and defendants (including FHWA, FAA, FRA, and later HHS), and a third preliminary injunction was granted on August 12, 2025. The matter remains pending in the district court with the preliminary injunction in effect “pending further orders,” while the June injunction is on appeal.

Factual context: Plaintiffs allege Congress appropriated funds for homelessness and transportation under detailed program statutes and NOFOs that did not include the new policy conditions; after executive orders issued in early 2025, HUD and DOT inserted the conditions into grant agreements and program templates (including FTA’s Master Agreement and FAA grant assurances), threatening loss of crucial funding unless grantees agreed. Plaintiffs contend the conditions bear little or no relation to the grants’ purposes, force local governments into controversial federal policy positions (including anti‑DEI and immigration enforcement roles), and expose them to heightened False Claims Act risk, all without statutory authorization or required rulemaking. Judge Rothstein’s injunctions preserve existing funding flows while the legality of those conditions is adjudicated.
results.46484:
On April 23, 2025, a national bar association filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the U.S. Department of Justice and two senior Department officials in their official capacities. The suit challenges the Department’s abrupt termination of multiple Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) grants that supported the association’s Commission on Domestic & Sexual Violence. The association is represented by a public‑interest nonprofit litigation organization; the government is represented by Department of Justice counsel. This is not a class action.

The case arises from events in early April 2025. On April 9, the Deputy Attorney General circulated a memorandum barring Department lawyers from participating in association‑sponsored events on official time, expressly citing the association’s recent participation in litigation against the federal government and its advocacy positions. The next day, the Department terminated all of the association’s OVW cooperative agreements “effective immediately,” invoking 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a) and asserting only that the awards no longer effectuated agency priorities. According to the record, there were five active OVW awards totaling approximately $3.2 million; the Department identified an unobligated balance of about $2.05 million. The association alleges it had no performance deficiencies, that comparable OVW awards to other organizations remained in place, and that two already‑ended awards were purportedly “terminated” as well.

The association’s complaint pleads multiple constitutional and statutory claims and seeks declaratory and injunctive relief: (1) First Amendment retaliation; (2) First Amendment viewpoint discrimination; (3) unconstitutional conditions (First Amendment/Spending Clause); (4) Fifth Amendment equal protection; (5) Fifth Amendment procedural due process; and (6) Administrative Procedure Act violations. The association promptly moved for a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction to: (a) bar enforcement of the terminations (including closeout steps); (b) prevent re‑obligation of the affected funds; and (c) require continued, customary disbursement of funds on the awards.

The motion was set on an expedited schedule. The government represented it would not re‑obligate the funds before June 2, 2025, and then moved to dismiss, arguing principally that the dispute belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act because it concerns federal cooperative agreements. After a May 12, 2025 hearing, Judge Christopher R. Cooper issued a memorandum opinion and order on May 14, 2025 granting a preliminary injunction on the First Amendment retaliation claim and denying the government’s jurisdictional objection as to that claim.

In his opinion, Judge Cooper held that the court had jurisdiction because the retaliation claim arises from the First Amendment, not from the grant contracts, and seeks specific equitable relief rather than money damages; sovereign immunity is not a bar to constitutional claims for injunctive relief under the Larson‑Dugan line of cases. On the merits, the court found the association likely to succeed on its retaliation claim: filing suit and engaging in advocacy are protected activities; grant termination is an adverse action; the temporal proximity to the Deputy Attorney General’s memo and the absence of performance failings, combined with the continued funding of similar OVW activities through other grantees, supported an inference of retaliatory motive. The court also found irreparable harm, both because loss of First Amendment freedoms constitutes irreparable injury and because the termination threatened the viability of the association’s domestic‑violence grant operations. The balance of equities and public interest favored relief because preventing likely constitutional violations serves the public interest.

As a remedy, the court enjoined the Department from enforcing the terminations and from taking steps that would give them effect, and required the Department to continue administering and disbursing funds on the association’s active OVW awards in the ordinary course. The court did not require reinstatement of two awards that had already expired by their terms and made clear the Department remains free to terminate or modify awards for permissible, non‑retaliatory reasons.

Key filings and proceedings include: the complaint (April 23, 2025); the TRO/PI motion (April 24, 2025); a status conference and briefing schedule; the government’s motion to dismiss (May 2, 2025); the motion hearing (May 12, 2025); and the preliminary injunction order and memorandum opinion (May 14, 2025). The court’s memorandum opinion is at ECF No. 28. No trial has occurred, and no appeal is noted in the record. On July 17, 2025, after a joint status report, the court administratively closed the case and struck the pending motion to dismiss, directing the parties to file a further status report by October 1, 2027, or earlier if developments warrant. The preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further order.
results.46279:
Filed March 23, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, this certified class action challenges the Department of Homeland Security’s policy and practice of removing noncitizens with final removal orders to “third countries” (countries not designated on the removal order) without prior meaningful notice and an opportunity to seek protection from persecution or torture. The plaintiffs—noncitizens with final orders (including individuals granted withholding of removal or CAT protection against removal to the country designated in their orders)—sue the Department of Homeland Security, its Secretary, the U.S. Attorney General, and the superintendent of a Massachusetts immigration detention facility. Plaintiffs are represented by nonprofit public‑interest counsel (National Immigration Litigation Alliance, Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, and Human Rights First).

The complaint pleads the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. § 706(1), (2)(A), (C), (D)), the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 implementing the Convention Against Torture (FARRA), the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, and a FOIA proactive‑disclosure claim (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(2)). Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief requiring DHS to provide written notice and a meaningful opportunity to present withholding/CAT claims to an immigration judge before third‑country removals, to set aside DHS’s challenged policies (including a February 18, 2025 redetention directive), to return class members who were removed without these protections, and to award fees.

The factual core alleges DHS has no operative process to ensure notice and a pre‑removal hearing when it seeks to remove an individual to a third country. On February 18, 2025, DHS directed officers to re‑detain previously released individuals for potential third‑country removals. On March 30, 2025, DHS issued “Guidance Regarding Third Country Removals” allowing removal without any process where the United States has blanket diplomatic assurances from the receiving country, and otherwise providing only notice and rapid (often 24‑hour) screening if, without prompting, an individual affirmatively voices fear. Plaintiffs assert this violates statutory, regulatory, treaty, and due‑process requirements for individualized adjudication and meaningful notice/opportunity to be heard.

The named plaintiffs exemplify the allegations. A Cuban man (final order to Cuba) faced imminent re‑detention and third‑country removal; a Honduran woman with 2021 withholding to Honduras was told she was on a deportation list; an Ecuadorean man granted CAT protection in 2018 was re‑detained; and a Guatemalan man granted withholding to Guatemala in February 2025 was quickly deported by DHS to Mexico without notice or a chance to raise fear; Mexico then removed him to Guatemala, where he remains in hiding.

Judge Brian E. Murphy granted a TRO on March 28, 2025, enjoining third‑country removals without written notice and a meaningful opportunity to seek CAT protection. On April 18, 2025, the court certified a class of individuals with final orders who DHS has removed or will remove on or after February 18, 2025, to a country not designated or identified in writing in their prior proceedings. The court also issued a preliminary injunction requiring, before any third‑country removal: (1) written notice to the individual (and counsel, if any) in a language the person understands; (2) a meaningful opportunity to present a CAT claim; (3) if “reasonable fear” is shown, DHS must move to reopen immigration proceedings so an immigration judge can adjudicate the claim; and (4) if no reasonable fear is found, a minimum of 15 days to seek reopening. On April 30, 2025, the court amended the injunction to prevent DHS from ceding custody or control to avoid compliance (e.g., via Department of Defense removal from Guantánamo).

On May 20, 2025, DHS began removing eight class members to South Sudan with fewer than 24 hours’ notice. Following emergency hearings, on May 21 the court found DHS violated the injunction, clarified that “meaningful opportunity” requires a minimum of 10 days after notice, and ordered remedial relief: DHS must provide private reasonable‑fear interviews, with 72 hours’ notice, counsel access (in‑person or remote) and interpreters, and post‑interview procedures (including a 15‑day period to seek reopening after a negative screening), either in the United States or abroad so long as DHS retains custody/control and ensures access equivalent to that provided in the U.S. The court denied DHS’s motions for reconsideration and stay on May 26, 2025.

Separately, on May 23, 2025, the court ordered DHS to facilitate the immediate return to the United States of the named plaintiff who was removed to Mexico without notice after winning withholding to Guatemala, following DHS’s later admission that it could not identify any officer who had asked him about fear of Mexico as previously represented.

Appellate proceedings followed. The First Circuit denied DHS’s request for a stay of the preliminary injunction (Order of Court, May 16, 2025). On June 23, 2025, the Supreme Court stayed the district court’s preliminary injunction pending appeal and any petition for certiorari (DHS v. D.V.D., 145 S. Ct. 2153), while the district court noted its May 21 remedial order for the eight individuals remained in effect. Additional appeals remain pending in the First Circuit. DHS has moved in the district court to stay proceedings pending appeal; plaintiffs have moved for an indicative ruling to dissolve the stayed preliminary injunction and for partial summary judgment on their APA, due‑process, and declaratory claims.

In sum, the district court (Judge Murphy) certified the class, granted preliminary relief requiring written notice and a meaningful pre‑removal opportunity to present fear‑based protection claims before third‑country removals, clarified and enforced that relief after attempted removals with less than a day’s notice, and ordered the return of one named plaintiff wrongfully removed without those protections. The preliminary injunction is currently stayed by the Supreme Court pending further appellate proceedings; the district court’s remedial order for the eight individuals removed toward South Sudan remains operative.
results.46186:
Filed on February 28, 2025, this class action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts challenges a series of federal executive actions that (1) terminated humanitarian parole programs and (2) halted adjudication of immigration benefits for parolees. The plaintiffs are individual parole beneficiaries (or would-be beneficiaries), U.S.-based sponsors (including military families), and Haitian Bridge Alliance. They sue the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Acting Directors of ICE and USCIS, the Acting Commissioner of CBP, and the President, alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer LLP) and nonprofit legal organizations (Justice Action Center, Human Rights First).

The case centers on immigration parole authority under 8 U.S.C. § 1182(d)(5). Plaintiffs contend that, on Inauguration Day (January 20, 2025), the President issued Executive Orders directing DHS to terminate “categorical parole programs” (including the parole processes for nationals of Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela (collectively CHNV)), limit parole to case-by-case decisions, and re-establish rigorous vetting. Acting DHS Secretary Huffman then issued a memorandum authorizing pausing/terminating categorical parole programs; Acting CBP Commissioner Flores limited CBP parole authority; and Acting USCIS Director Higgins directed staff to cease decisions on parole, re‑parole, and other benefit applications for beneficiaries of programs such as Uniting for Ukraine (U4U), CHNV, Operation Allies Welcome (OAW), Family Reunification Parole (FRP), and Central American Minors (CAM). On February 14, 2025, Acting USCIS Deputy Director Davidson ordered an “administrative hold” on adjudicating immigration benefits (e.g., asylum, TPS, adjustment) for U4U, CHNV, and FRP parolees based on potential vetting deficiencies. On March 25, 2025, DHS published a Federal Register Notice terminating the CHNV parole processes and providing that all unexpired CHNV paroles and associated employment authorization would end April 24, 2025, absent individualized contrary determinations.

Plaintiffs assert that these actions are contrary to the INA and the APA (5 U.S.C. §§ 701‑706) because they misinterpret the parole statute, impose categorical decisions where case‑by‑case determinations are required, and arbitrarily suspend adjudications. They also invoke the Accardi doctrine and allege Fifth Amendment Due Process violations. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur of the Huffman, Higgins, and Davidson directives and the March 25, 2025 CHNV termination notice, restoration of adjudications, and attorneys’ fees.

Judge Indira Talwani presides. On April 14, 2025, the court preliminarily stayed the March 25 CHNV notice insofar as it revoked existing CHNV grants of parole and work authorization without case‑by‑case review, and certified a class of individuals whose CHNV parole grants were being truncated. The government appealed. The First Circuit denied a stay pending appeal on May 5, 2025, but on May 30, 2025, the Supreme Court stayed the district court’s April 14 order pending appeal and any petition for certiorari, allowing DHS’s mass truncation of CHNV parole to go forward (over a dissent).

In parallel, on May 28, 2025, the district court granted partial preliminary relief on plaintiffs’ broader motion, staying: (1) the January 23 Higgins directive to the extent it suspended adjudications of re‑parole and other non‑parole benefits for parolees under the identified programs; (2) any DHS actions suspending initial parole/re‑parole and related benefits under Military Parole in Place (MPIP); and (3) the February 14 Davidson memorandum to the extent it suspended adjudications of immigration benefit applications for U4U, FRP, and CHNV parolees and required case‑by‑case lifting of the hold even in the face of classwide court orders. The court simultaneously expanded class certification to cover (a) parolees with pending re‑parole applications under programs providing re‑parole, (b) parolees with pending applications for other immigration benefits, and (c) MPIP supporters with pending applications. The court then issued compliance orders requiring DHS/USCIS to resume adjudications, update system “holds,” contact‑center scripts, and public messaging, and to report on implementation. USCIS issued the June 9 “Alfonso‑Royals” memo authorizing resumption of adjudications, and reported lifting system holds by June 19, 2025, with adjudicator guidance to follow; the court continues to monitor compliance, including issues raised by plaintiffs about lingering “administrative hold” messaging and diversity‑visa processing for class members.

Defendants moved to dismiss on May 30, 2025, arguing lack of standing, jurisdictional bars under 8 U.S.C. § 1252(a)(2)(B), nonfinal/nonreviewable agency action under the APA, and failure to state an APA or due process claim. Plaintiffs opposed on June 13, 2025. Plaintiffs also moved for partial summary judgment on June 16, 2025, seeking to vacate DHS’s mass truncation of CHNV parole; defendants opposed on July 7, 2025, and an amicus (Immigration Reform Law Institute) filed in opposition. Defendants have appealed the May 28, 2025 preliminary injunction and amended class certification orders (First Circuit No. 25‑1715). On August 1, 2025, the district court denied the remaining portion of plaintiffs’ earlier PI motion addressing suspensions of initial parole adjudications for persons outside the U.S.

Throughout the case, plaintiffs have proceeded under pseudonyms by court order, and several state and organizational amici have participated. No settlement has been reached. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce its preliminary orders and to adjudicate defendants’ motion to dismiss and plaintiffs’ partial summary judgment motion.
results.46180:
On February 25, 2025, three national and state membership organizations of educators and scholars—the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), the American Sociological Association (ASA), and AFT‑Maryland—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the U.S. Department of Education, the Secretary of Education (initially Acting Secretary Denise L. Carter; later Linda McMahon), and the Acting Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, Craig Trainor. On March 5, 2025, they amended the complaint to add Oregon’s Eugene School District 4J. Plaintiffs are represented by the Democracy Forward Foundation (a private public‑interest nonprofit); Defendants by the U.S. Attorney’s Office. The suit challenges DOE’s February 14, 2025 Dear Colleague Letter, associated FAQs, and the Department’s April 3, 2025 demand that state and local education agencies certify compliance with DOE’s interpretation of Title VI and Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard (SFFA). Plaintiffs assert Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claims (5 U.S.C. § 706), and constitutional claims under the First Amendment (free speech and association) and the Fifth Amendment (void‑for‑vagueness), seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and a stay under APA § 705.

Plaintiffs allege that DOE’s Letter misstates and greatly expands Title VI and SFFA by, among other things, characterizing as unlawful “DEI” programs; discouraging or proscribing classroom speech about “systemic and structural racism” or teaching that some racial groups bear “unique moral burdens”; warning against “relying on proxies for race” (e.g., dropping standardized tests to increase diversity); and threatening loss of federal funds. DOE simultaneously opened an “End DEI” reporting portal (Feb. 27) and issued FAQs (Feb. 28), and on April 3 directed state education chiefs to obtain and submit certifications—by April 24—acknowledging that compliance with DOE’s understanding (including that “certain DEI practices” and “illegal DEI” can violate federal law) is a material condition of federal funding, warning of funding termination, claw‑back, and possible False Claims Act liability. Plaintiffs alleged these actions were legislative rules issued without notice and comment, arbitrary and capricious, exceeded DOE’s statutory authority (including 20 U.S.C. § 3403’s prohibition on federal control of curriculum), and were unconstitutionally vague and viewpoint/content‑based.

After a venue show‑cause (venue was held proper in Maryland), Plaintiffs moved for preliminary injunctions against the Letter and the Certification. Following an April 18, 2025 hearing, the Court (Judge Stephanie A. Gallagher) granted the Letter motion in part, staying the Letter under 5 U.S.C. § 705, and denied the Certification motion because certification‑related facts and claims had not yet been pled. Mem. Op., ECF 60 (Apr. 24, 2025). The Court found the Letter likely a final, legislative rule issued without notice and comment; likely arbitrary and capricious; likely beyond DOE’s statutory authority (because it effectively regulated curriculum and classroom speech); and likely contrary to the First Amendment where it targeted content and viewpoint (e.g., teaching on “structural racism”). The Court did not enjoin the FAQs or remove the portal but noted DOE could continue enforcing Title VI consistent with law.

Plaintiffs then filed a Second Amended Complaint adding Certification‑specific claims. On cross‑motions for summary judgment, the Court again found standing (for District 4J directly and for the associations via their members) and concluded both the Letter and the Certification were reviewable final agency actions and legislative rules. The Court held that neither action complied with the APA’s procedural requirements; the Certification also violated the Paperwork Reduction Act. Substantively, both were arbitrary and capricious (for failing to acknowledge or explain major departures from prior policy, to rely on evidence, to account for existing federal and state standards and baseline conditions, and to consider reliance interests). The Court further held the Letter contrary to law (DOE may not control curriculum under 20 U.S.C. § 3403 and related statutes) and contrary to constitutional rights (First Amendment: content‑ and viewpoint‑based proscriptions of certain classroom speech; Fifth Amendment: vagueness). As to the Certification, the Court held it unconstitutionally vague (undefined “illegal DEI,” “certain DEI practices,” and “advantaging” one race), but granted judgment for the government on Plaintiffs’ separate First Amendment claim against the Certification. Mem. Op., ECF 83 (Aug. 14, 2025).

Remedies: On April 24, 2025, the Letter was stayed under APA § 705 pending final resolution. On August 14, 2025, the Court granted summary judgment for Plaintiffs on Counts One (First Amendment as to the Letter), Two (Fifth Amendment vagueness as to the Letter), Three (APA as to the Letter), Five (Fifth Amendment vagueness as to the Certification), and Six (APA as to the Certification), granted summary judgment for the government on Count Four (First Amendment as to the Certification), and vacated both the February 14, 2025 Letter and the April 3, 2025 “Reminder of Legal Obligations… and Request for Certification” under 5 U.S.C. § 706. Order of Judgment, ECF 84 (Aug. 14, 2025). No trial occurred, and no appeal is noted on the docket.

Judge: U.S. District Judge Stephanie A. Gallagher (D. Md.). Reported decisions: Mem. Op., ECF 60 (Apr. 24, 2025); Mem. Op., ECF 83 (Aug. 14, 2025). Related litigation (not consolidated): Nat’l Educ. Ass’n v. Dep’t of Educ., No. 25‑91 (D.N.H.) (preliminary injunction against the Letter, FAQs, portal, and certification), and NAACP v. Dep’t of Educ., No. 25‑1120 (D.D.C.) (preliminary injunction against the certification).
results.46119:
Filed on February 13, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, this case challenges the creation and actions of the “Department of Government Efficiency” (DOGE) established by executive order on January 20, 2025, and the role of Elon Musk as an unpaid special government employee. The plaintiffs—originally 26 current and former personnel of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), later narrowed and re‑pleaded as six pseudonymous representatives—allege that, beginning in late January 2025, DOGE personnel directed by Musk rapidly assumed control over USAID’s systems and operations, closed USAID’s headquarters and disabled its website, placed large numbers of USAID employees on administrative leave, terminated or attempted to terminate thousands of grants and contracts, and initiated a reduction-in-force to wind down the agency. The plaintiffs claim DOGE members without proper clearances accessed sensitive systems and data, and that these actions disrupted legally mandated programs and jeopardized safety and security of USAID personnel and beneficiaries. They seek only declaratory and injunctive relief.

The suit began against Elon Musk in his official capacity, the U.S. DOGE Service, and the Department of Government Efficiency. On April 17, 2025, plaintiffs amended to add USAID, the Department of State, the President, the Secretary of State (acting as USAID Administrator), and senior USAID officials linked to the alleged actions (Peter Marocco, Jeremy Lewin, Kenneth Jackson) and Amy Gleason (Acting USDS Administrator). Plaintiffs’ counsel includes the State Democracy Defenders Fund (public‑interest) and private firms Marziani, Stevens & Gonzalez PLLC and Lieff Cabraser Heimann & Bernstein LLP. The case is before Judge Theodore D. Chuang.

Plaintiffs bring two constitutional claims: (1) violation of the Appointments Clause, alleging Musk exercised “significant authority” as the de facto DOGE leader without Senate confirmation or lawful statutory vesting; and (2) violation of the separation of powers, alleging that defendants’ actions to dismantle or abolish USAID—an agency established by law and funded by Congress—contravene Congress’s exclusive authority to create, fund, and abolish agencies. They seek declaratory judgments and injunctions to set aside actions taken at USAID by Musk and DOGE, to bar further dismantling of USAID absent congressional authorization, and to prohibit Musk and DOGE from further actions at USAID.

On March 18, 2025, after expedited briefing and a hearing, Judge Chuang granted a preliminary injunction in part. The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on both claims as to key actions: the court concluded Musk appeared to have made the decisions to permanently close USAID headquarters and take down USAID’s website without approval by a duly appointed USAID officer, and that the broader effort to “effectively eliminate” USAID was incompatible with Congress’s establishment and ongoing appropriations for the agency. The injunction (1) barred defendants from disclosing plaintiffs’ sensitive information; (2) required restoration of USAID employees’ and PSCs’ access to email, payment, and security systems; (3) enjoined defendants from implementing terminations, stop‑work orders, or other shutdown measures at USAID; and (4) prohibited further actions relating to USAID absent authorization by a USAID official with legal authority. The court later denied defendants’ request to carve out Jeremy Lewin (then delegated duties as USAID’s Deputy Administrator/COO), holding the order applied to DOGE‑affiliated personnel to prevent circumvention.

Defendants noticed an interlocutory appeal. On March 28, 2025, a Fourth Circuit panel (Judges Quattlebaum, Niemeyer, and Gregory) stayed the preliminary injunction pending appeal, concluding defendants made a strong showing of likely success and emphasizing, among other things, that many actions were taken or ratified by USAID officials and that plaintiffs had not sued the proper agency defendants at the time of the injunction. On June 9, 2025, the Fourth Circuit held the appeal in abeyance to allow the district court to resolve a pending motion to dismiss or enter any subsequent appealable order.

Meanwhile, on May 1, 2025, defendants moved to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and failure to state a claim, arguing, among other things, that current and former USAID employees and personal services contractors must pursue personnel and contract disputes through the Civil Service Reform Act or Contract Disputes Act, and that plaintiffs lacked standing. Plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Class Action Complaint on May 30, 2025, clarifying which named plaintiffs were USAID employees and which were PSCs and maintaining the two constitutional claims with USAID, State, the President, Secretary Rubio, Marocco, Lewin, Jackson, and Gleason added as defendants. On August 13, 2025, Judge Chuang granted the motion to dismiss in part and denied it in part (details not provided in the docket beyond the mixed disposition) and ordered the remaining defendants to answer, which they did on August 27, 2025.

Plaintiffs moved for class certification under Rule 23(b)(2) on May 1, 2025, proposing a class of all USAID employees and personal services contractors during the class period. On August 18, 2025, the court granted the motion in part and denied it in part (again, details are not in the provided record). The case remains in the district court on the constitutional claims, with a partial injunctive relief framework initially issued by the district court but stayed by the Fourth Circuit; no trial has occurred, and there is no settlement.

The factual allegations underlying the claims include that DOGE teams—often including personnel with prior ties to Musk—were embedded across agencies; that on January 27, 2025 they began demanding and receiving administrator‑level access to USAID systems; that Musk and DOGE orchestrated the closure of USAID headquarters, took down the agency website, blocked staff access to systems, and removed signage; that large numbers of employees and contractors were placed on administrative leave or issued RIF or termination notices; and that mass terminations of grants and contracts were directed. Plaintiffs assert that DOGE members without appropriate clearances accessed restricted areas and systems and that these actions impeded statutory reporting and operations and risked safety and program continuity worldwide. Plaintiffs allege injuries in the form of unauthorized access or disclosure of personal data, interruptions to employment (including loss of system access and communications), reputational harm from public statements by Musk and the President labeling USAID corrupt or criminal, and dignitary harms. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief restoring lawful governance over USAID consistent with constitutional constraints.

Judge: The Honorable Theodore D. Chuang, U.S. District Judge, District of Maryland.  
Appellate proceedings: Fourth Circuit No. 25‑1273; preliminary injunction stayed on March 28, 2025; appeal held in abeyance on June 9, 2025 pending district court rulings.  
Related matters noted by the parties and the court include American Foreign Service Association v. Trump (D.D.C.) and AIDS Vaccine Advoc. Coalition v. U.S. Department of State (D.D.C.), which addressed overlapping issues concerning USAID staffing and foreign assistance pauses. No settlement has been reported in this case.
results.46099:
On February 10, 2025, two U.S. non‑profits—the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition (AVAC) and Journalism Development Network (JDN)—sued the U.S. Department of State, USAID, OMB, the Secretary of State (also acting as USAID Administrator), the OMB Director, and the President in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. (First Amended Complaint filed May 2, 2025, added the Center for Victims of Torture.) The case challenges a January 20, 2025 Executive Order (No. 14169) directing an immediate “pause” in foreign development assistance and a January 24, 2025 State Department memorandum instructing an immediate suspension and issuance of stop‑work orders for existing foreign‑assistance awards. Plaintiffs, represented by Public Citizen Litigation Group (and, in the related Global Health Council case, by private counsel), alleged violations of the APA (5 U.S.C. § 706), the Impoundment Control Act (ICA), the Anti‑Deficiency Act, the Constitution’s separation of powers and Take Care Clause, and non‑statutory ultra vires principles. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the government to stop enforcing the across‑the‑board funding “pause,” to pay amounts due, to make appropriated funds available, and (as later amended) to set aside mass terminations of awards.

Judge Amir H. Ali presides. On February 13, 2025, after a joint hearing with a related case (Global Health Council v. Trump, No. 25‑cv‑402), the court granted in part a temporary restraining order, finding plaintiffs likely to succeed on their APA claim that the blanket suspension pending “review” lacked a reasoned explanation and failed to consider massive reliance interests, and that plaintiffs faced irreparable harm (layoffs, shuttered programs, and threats to humanitarian services). The TRO enjoined enforcement of the State memorandum and other directives implementing EO 14169 “including by” suspending or preventing disbursements, or issuing/maintaining stop‑work orders and terminations, for awards in existence as of January 19, 2025. At the same time, to tailor relief, the court allowed the agencies to enforce individual award terms (including expirations, modifications, or terminations) and declined to enjoin the President or the Executive Order itself. See Aids Vaccine Advoc. Coal. v. U.S. Dep’t of State, 2025 WL 485324 (D.D.C. Feb. 13, 2025).

When plaintiffs reported non‑compliance, the court issued enforcement orders on February 20 and 22, reiterating that defendants must cease any blanket suspension and “take all necessary steps” to honor existing awards, including disbursing funds due. See 2025 WL 569381 (D.D.C. Feb. 20, 2025); 2025 WL 577516 (D.D.C. Feb. 22, 2025). On February 25, after another hearing, the court ordered immediate payment by February 26, 11:59 p.m., of invoices and drawdowns for work completed before the TRO date. The government’s interlocutory appeal was dismissed the next day because the order enforced a non‑appealable TRO; mandamus was denied. See AIDS Vaccine Advoc. Coal. v. U.S. Dep’t of State, 2025 WL 621396 (D.C. Cir. Feb. 26, 2025). The Supreme Court briefly entered an administrative stay but then denied the application to vacate the enforcement order—vacating the administrative stay and instructing the district court to clarify obligations with due regard to feasibility. See Dep’t of State v. AIDS Vaccine Advoc. Coal., 604 U.S. __, 2025 WL 698083 (U.S. Mar. 5, 2025); see also 145 S. Ct. 753 (2025) (mem.).

On March 10, 2025, the court granted in part a preliminary injunction. It held plaintiffs likely to succeed on their APA claim that the initial directives implementing the blanket “pause” were arbitrary and capricious, and it enjoined the government from giving effect to suspensions/terminations or withholding payments for work completed before February 13 on awards in existence as of January 19. It declined, however, to enjoin the government’s subsequent, post‑TRO “individualized” termination decisions based on award terms (finding that later termination decisions constituted distinct agency action and, on the record, plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on those APA challenges at that time). Separately, the court held plaintiffs likely to succeed on their constitutional separation‑of‑powers claim that defendants had engaged in a unilateral rescission/deferral of appropriated foreign‑assistance funds in violation of Congress’s Article I spending authority and the ICA, and it ordered defendants to “make available for obligation the full amount of funds that Congress appropriated for foreign assistance programs” in the FY2024 appropriations. The court set a feasibility benchmark of approximately 300 payments per day, required weekly compliance reports, and emphasized that agencies remained free to conduct program reviews consistent with governing law. See AIDS Vaccine Advoc. Coal. v. U.S. Dep’t of State, 2025 WL 752378 (D.D.C. Mar. 10, 2025).

Defendants appealed the preliminary injunction. While the appeal was pending, they sought an indicative ruling on the injunction’s “impoundment” component based on the Supreme Court’s stay in Dep’t of Educ. v. California; the district court denied the motion on May 13, 2025, and vacated a limited administrative stay it had granted while considering that motion. The court continued to require weekly status updates and later granted, in part, plaintiffs’ motion to enforce the preliminary injunction on July 21, 2025.

On August 13, 2025, a D.C.
