Circuit panel vacated the portion of the preliminary injunction requiring the government to make appropriated funds available for obligation, holding that the grantees lacked a cause of action to enforce the alleged impoundment (relying on Dalton v. Specter and finding the ICA’s scheme precluded APA review), but it did not disturb the district court’s APA ruling on the initial funding freeze (which was not on appeal). Judge Pan dissented. A few days later, on August 20, 2025, the court of appeals entered an en banc order stating that “the preliminary injunction that requires the government to obligate the appropriated funds remains in effect” pending further en banc proceedings, and the district court reminded defendants they remained obligated to comply absent further appellate or district court order. Appeals thus remain pending.

Meanwhile, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on May 2, 2025 (adding the Center for Victims of Torture), alleging that after the TRO the government mass‑terminated most awards (roughly 9,900 of about 13,100 in both agencies) based on cursory review and form letters, and asserting these later terminations are arbitrary and contrary to law (APA), in addition to renewing constitutional and ultra vires challenges. Defendants moved to dismiss under Rules 12(b)(1) and 12(b)(6) in June 2025 (arguing, among other things, lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction, Tucker Act/CDA channeling of contract‑based disputes, and preclusion of APA review by the ICA); briefing on dismissal has been held in abeyance pending resolution of the preliminary‑injunction appeal. The district court continues to require periodic compliance reports and, as of late August 2025, set a status conference to monitor compliance with the injunction’s obligation requirement.

Key reported rulings include: TRO, 2025 WL 485324; TRO enforcement orders, 2025 WL 569381 and 2025 WL 577516; preliminary injunction, 2025 WL 752378; D.C. Circuit dismissal of appeal from TRO enforcement, 2025 WL 621396; Supreme Court order denying application to vacate TRO enforcement, 2025 WL 698083; and the D.C. Circuit panel opinion vacating the impoundment portion of the preliminary injunction (Aug. 13, 2025), followed by an en banc order (Aug. 20, 2025) leaving that obligation requirement in place pending en banc review.

Factual context: Plaintiffs averred—and the district court credited at the TRO/PI stages—that EO 14169 and the January 24 State memorandum caused an immediate, across‑the‑board suspension of foreign‑assistance disbursements and stop‑work orders, disrupting global health, humanitarian, and democracy‑assistance programs, prompting widespread layoffs and shutdowns, and jeopardizing vulnerable populations. The court concluded the initial blanket “pause” lacked a reasoned basis and disregarded reliance interests (APA), and that the later “impoundment” conduct likely infringed Congress’s power of the purse (separation of powers/ICA). The court tailored relief to prohibit the blanket freeze while permitting individualized, lawful award actions; it required payments for pre‑TRO work and continued monitoring to ensure compliance. Appeals are active; the panel’s vacatur of the impoundment portion is currently subject to en banc proceedings, and the district court’s injunction continues to govern pending further appellate action.

Filed on February 10, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington (Seattle), this case challenges actions taken by the federal government on and after January 20, 2025, related to the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program (USRAP). The plaintiffs are eight individual refugees or U.S.‑based family/sponsors, and three nonprofit organizations central to refugee resettlement—HIAS, Inc., Church World Service, Inc. (CWS), and Lutheran Community Services Northwest. They sue the President, the Secretary of State (Marco Rubio), the Secretary of Homeland Security (Kristi Noem), and the Secretary of Health and Human Services (Dorothy A. Fink, later Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.) in their official capacities. Plaintiffs are represented by the International Refugee Assistance Project (legal services nonprofit) and Perkins Coie LLP (private counsel).

The suit challenges Executive Order 14163, “Realigning the United States Refugee Admissions Program,” issued January 20, 2025, which indefinitely suspended refugee entries under USRAP and suspended decisions on refugee applications pending future presidential determinations. Plaintiffs also challenge how agencies implemented the order: the State Department canceled refugee travel before the order’s effective date, suspended all case processing, and on January 24, 2025, issued stop‑work notices and halted USRAP funding to resettlement partners under a separate foreign aid review order (EO 14169). On February 26, 2025, the State Department terminated resettlement partners’ cooperative agreements for domestic reception and placement services and, for most, overseas processing support through Resettlement Support Centers. Plaintiffs allege these steps dismantled USRAP infrastructure, stranded refugees who had been approved and booked to travel, and cut off statutory post‑arrival services to new arrivals.

The complaint pleads violations of the Immigration and Nationality Act/Refugee Act (8 U.S.C. §§ 1157, 1522), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (arbitrary/capricious, contrary to law, failure to follow required procedures), the Accardi doctrine, separation‑of‑powers principles, and the Fifth Amendment due process rights of “follow‑to‑join” petitioners. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief and class certification.

On February 25, 2025, Judge Jamal N. Whitehead granted a preliminary injunction (written order issued February 28) enjoining enforcement of EO 14163’s suspension provisions and enjoining the suspension of refugee processing, decisions, admissions, and USRAP funding (including withholding of pre‑January 20 reimbursements). The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits: the President’s order likely exceeded 8 U.S.C. § 1182(f) because it effectively nullified Congress’s refugee scheme and lacked the required findings, and the agencies’ implementation and funding suspensions were likely arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law. The court also found due process concerns for follow‑to‑join petitioners and issued a nationwide injunction. The government appealed (No. 25‑1313) and sought a stay. On March 25, 2025, the Ninth Circuit stayed the injunction in large part, but denied a stay as to individuals conditionally approved for refugee status before January 20, 2025. On April 21, 2025, the Ninth Circuit clarified that the carve‑out applied to those who, by January 20, had: (1) an approved refugee application authorizing conditional admission per 8 C.F.R. § 207.4; (2) USCIS travel clearance; and (3) arranged and confirmable travel plans. On May 9, 2025, the court further clarified the carve‑out should be applied narrowly, case‑by‑case, to individuals with strong reliance interests comparable to the lead plaintiff.

Meanwhile, the district court allowed a supplemental complaint addressing the February 26 terminations and, on March 24, 2025, issued a second preliminary injunction enjoining the State Department’s termination of USRAP cooperative agreements and ordering reinstatement. The court held APA jurisdiction, found the terminations likely contrary to the Refugee Act’s resettlement scheme (8 U.S.C. § 1522) and arbitrary and capricious, and denied the government’s request for a bond. The government appealed (No. 25‑1939). The district court denied motions to stay either injunction.

As implementation issues arose, the district court issued compliance orders. Initially (May 5), the court set detailed steps to resume processing for injunction‑protected refugees, but rescinded that framework (May 15) after the Ninth Circuit’s May 9 clarification requiring individualized reliance assessments. On July 14, 2025, the court entered an “Injunction Implementation Framework” appointing Magistrate Judge Michelle L. Peterson to manage case‑by‑case reliance determinations. The court defined “Review‑Eligible Cases” (those meeting the Ninth Circuit’s three criteria, including certain pre‑January 20 travel cancellations after December 1, 2024) and “Injunction‑Protected Refugees” (those with Pacito‑comparable reliance interests). The framework created a rebuttable presumption of sufficient reliance for: (1) approximately 160 refugees with travel within two weeks of January 20, 2025; (2) unaccompanied minor children; and (3) certain Afghan refugees processed via Camp As Sayliyah. It directed the government to identify Review‑Eligible Cases, notify applicants, facilitate standardized reliance surveys via RSCs, conduct initial decisions, and litigate disputed cases before Judge Peterson, whose reports and recommendations would be subject to objection and final ruling by Judge Whitehead. Addressing a June 4, 2025 presidential proclamation restricting certain nationals’ entry, the court held it did not apply to refugees due to an explicit carve‑out and directed processing for affected injunction‑protected refugees.

Class certification was granted on July 30, 2025, under Rule 23(b)(2) for three subclasses: (1) Refugee and Family Member Subclass (represented by Pacito, Sara, Alyas, Marcos, Josephine, and Ahmed); (2) Reception & Placement Subclass (represented by Ali); and (3) Follow‑to‑Join Petitioner Subclass (represented by Esther). IRAP and Perkins Coie were appointed class counsel. On the same date, the court denied the government’s motion to dismiss, rejecting jurisdictional and merits challenges.

Throughout, the Ninth Circuit issued stay and clarification orders narrowing the district court’s injunction to a case‑by‑case carve‑out, later issuing an administrative stay on July 19, 2025, pending resolution of an emergency motion concerning the implementation framework. The litigation remains ongoing on appeal (Nos. 25‑1313 and 25‑1939) and in the district court under the implementation framework, with the preliminary injunctions in force as narrowed by the Ninth Circuit. Judge Jamal N. Whitehead presides in the district court; Magistrate Judge Michelle L. Peterson oversees reliance determinations under the framework; and Judges Silverman, Bade, and De Alba comprise the Ninth Circuit panel.
results.46065:
On February 7, 2025, the States of Washington, Minnesota, and Oregon, together with three University of Washington pediatric physicians, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington (Seattle) to challenge President Trump’s January 28, 2025 Executive Order 14,187, “Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation,” and, later by amendment, the January 20, 2025 Executive Order 14,168, “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.” Colorado joined as a plaintiff on February 19, 2025. Plaintiffs are represented by their respective state Attorneys General; the physicians are represented by the Washington Attorney General. Defendants are the President (official capacity), the United States, and multiple federal departments and agency heads, including HHS, DOJ, and others.

Plaintiffs bring constitutional claims under the Fifth Amendment’s equal protection component, the separation of powers, the Tenth Amendment, and (as to EO 14,168’s definitions of “sex,” “male,” and “female”) the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause (vagueness), invoking the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief. The challenged provisions are: (1) Section 4 of EO 14,187, which directs agency heads to “immediately” take steps to ensure institutions receiving federal research or education grants end gender‑affirming care for “children” (defined in that order as individuals under 19); (2) Section 8(a) of EO 14,187, which instructs the Attorney General to prioritize enforcement of 18 U.S.C. § 116 (female genital mutilation); and (3) Sections 3(e) and 3(g) of EO 14,168, which require agencies to end federal funding of “gender ideology” and ensure grant funds do not promote “gender ideology.”

Judge Lauren King granted a temporary restraining order on February 14, 2025, enjoining enforcement or implementation of Section 4 of EO 14,187 within the plaintiff states and enjoining Section 8(a) to the extent it purported to redefine “female genital mutilation” under 18 U.S.C. § 116 as the order’s “chemical and surgical mutilation.” In a February 16 memorandum, the Court found Plaintiffs likely to succeed on separation‑of‑powers grounds (improperly conditioning congressionally appropriated grants), equal protection (sex and transgender‑status discrimination), and the Tenth Amendment (intruding on state regulation of medicine by attempting to expand § 116), and found standing based on threatened loss of funds, forced policy choices, and credible enforcement risks.

After Plaintiffs amended the complaint to add Colorado, claims against EO 14,168’s funding instructions, and a vagueness claim, the Court held a preliminary‑injunction hearing on February 28, 2025. That day, the Court granted in part and denied in part Plaintiffs’ motion. The preliminary injunction (1) enjoined all Defendants (other than the President) from enforcing or implementing Section 4 of EO 14,187 within Washington, Oregon, Minnesota, and Colorado; and (2) enjoined enforcement of Sections 3(e) and 3(g) of EO 14,168 to condition or withhold federal funding based on the fact that a health‑care entity or professional provides gender‑affirming care within those four states. The Court denied preliminary relief as to Section 8(a) of EO 14,187 for lack of standing, finding no credible threat of prosecution under 18 U.S.C. § 116 on the record presented.

Following the injunction, Plaintiffs moved for contempt, citing NIH’s February 28 termination of a Seattle Children’s Hospital research grant related to transgender youth and HHS/CDC notices referencing the executive orders. On March 17, 2025, the Court denied contempt but granted expedited discovery limited to whether the NIH termination contravened the preliminary injunction, and ordered Defendants to correct an “unreasonable” interpretation of the injunction—clarifying that “gender‑affirming care” is not confined to the four treatments listed in EO 14,187 and that research may involve patient care. Defendants provided notice of compliance on March 20. On March 27, 2025, NIH reinstated the Seattle Children’s grant in full, and the Court later denied as moot Plaintiffs’ motion to compel further discovery.

Defendants filed an interlocutory appeal to the Ninth Circuit (No. 25‑1922) from the preliminary‑injunction order (and the expedited‑discovery order) on March 21, 2025. On April 23, 2025, the District Court stayed further district‑court proceedings pending appeal, with important exceptions: the stay does not bar proceedings to enforce or clarify the preliminary injunction, motions to amend or seek additional preliminary relief (including on any new claims), or motions for relief from the stay. The Court noted similar limited‑stay terms entered in related litigation (PFLAG, Inc. v. Trump, D. Md.) and observed that the issues on appeal are largely legal (ripeness, Article II authority, level of scrutiny), and that Supreme Court review in Skrmetti is expected to provide guidance.

Throughout, the Court documented a concrete factual basis: the Executive Orders sought to cut off federal research and education grants to medical institutions providing gender‑affirming care; agencies issued rapid notices referencing the orders; a White House press release stated the orders were “already having [their] intended effect”; and some hospitals curtailed care pending legal developments. Plaintiffs presented evidence of immediate harms to research funding and patient care at institutions such as the University of Washington School of Medicine, Oregon Health & Science University, Oregon State University, and Children’s Hospital Colorado, and described the medical‑community consensus that gender‑affirming care, when indicated, is the standard of care for adolescents with gender dysphoria.

There is no trial or settlement. The preliminary‑injunction order remains in place pending further order, and the case is on appeal to the Ninth Circuit.
results.46028:
On February 4, 2025, two national membership organizations (PFLAG and GLMA) and several families and young adults under 19 filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland challenging two January 2025 Executive Orders: (1) Executive Order 14,168 (“Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government”), which directs agencies to ensure federal funds are not used to “promote gender ideology,” and (2) Executive Order 14,187 (“Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation”), which directs agencies to “immediately” ensure institutions receiving federal research or education grants end gender‑affirming medical care for individuals under 19. Plaintiffs—transgender adolescents and 18‑year‑olds, their parents, and the two membership organizations—alleged that, after the Orders issued, federal health agencies sent notices and hospitals across the country abruptly halted gender‑affirming care for patients under 19, cancelling existing treatments and planned procedures. They sued the President (official capacity), the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its leaders and sub‑agencies (including HRSA and NIH), and later, by amended complaint on February 11, 2025, added the National Science Foundation (NSF) and its Director.

Plaintiffs are represented by civil-rights organizations and private counsel (ACLU; Lambda Legal; Jenner & Block; Hogan Lovells). The complaint (and amended complaint) assert: ultra vires separation‑of‑powers claims (usurpation of Congress’s spending power; violation of bicameralism and presentment); statutory conflicts (prohibiting sex‑based discrimination in federally funded health programs under ACA § 1557, 42 U.S.C. § 18116, and PHSA § 300w‑7; and, in the amended pleading, disability discrimination under § 504 of the Rehabilitation Act as incorporated by § 1557); Fifth Amendment Equal Protection; substantive due process (parental decision‑making); and First Amendment viewpoint discrimination. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

Judge Brendan A. Hurson granted a temporary restraining order on February 13, 2025 (memorandum opinion issued February 14), enjoining HHS (and subagencies, including HRSA and NIH) and NSF from conditioning or withholding federal funding under EO 14,168 § 3(g) or EO 14,187 § 4 based on a grantee’s provision of gender‑affirming care to patients under 19. The Court found the case ripe and justiciable and held Plaintiffs were likely to succeed because the Orders imposed new funding conditions not authorized by Congress (violating separation of powers), conflicted with nondiscrimination statutes, and—under Fourth Circuit precedent—likely violated the Equal Protection Clause by discriminating based on sex/transgender status. The Court also found irreparable harm due to the shutdown of medically necessary care and issued a nationwide injunction to provide complete relief. The TRO was extended to March 5.

On March 4, 2025, after full briefing (including amicus participation), the Court entered a nationwide preliminary injunction on the same terms and ordered Defendants to notify covered components and release any disbursements paused due to the Executive Orders, without requiring a bond. The Court again concluded Plaintiffs showed a strong likelihood of success on separation of powers, statutory conflicts, and Equal Protection, as well as irreparable harm; and found the balance of equities and public interest favored relief.

On March 7, Plaintiffs moved to enforce the preliminary injunction after CMS, HRSA, and SAMHSA issued notices echoing the Executive Orders’ themes and stating they “may” review or adjust policies or grants; on March 28, the Court denied the enforcement motion without prejudice, holding those notices, as then framed, did not clearly violate the injunction’s specific commands (no actual conditioning, withholding, or termination) and did not yet amount to reinstating the enjoined directives “under a different name.” In April, Defendants notified the Court that CDC had, on January 31, 2025, briefly terminated 17 grants “in accordance with” EO 14,168 but reinstated them on February 11 with no de‑obligation of funds.

Defendants noticed an interlocutory appeal of the preliminary injunction on March 21, 2025 (Fourth Circuit No. 25‑1279). On May 12, 2025, the Fourth Circuit placed the appeal in abeyance pending the Supreme Court’s decision in United States v. Skrmetti (No. 23‑477). In the district court, the parties jointly obtained a limited partial stay of responsive pleading and Rule 16 deadlines (April 9, 2025) pending the appeal, but the preliminary injunction remains in effect, and Plaintiffs retain the ability to seek further preliminary relief or enforcement if necessary.

Factual background: Plaintiffs allege the two Executive Orders triggered immediate agency communications and led multiple federally funded institutions—including Children’s National (DC), VCU Health/Children’s Hospital of Richmond and UVA Health (VA), NYU Langone (NY), Boston Children’s (MA), Denver Health (CO), Children’s Hospital Colorado, Children’s Hospital Los Angeles, and others—to halt gender‑affirming care for patients under 19, cancelling appointments, prescriptions, and surgeries for the adolescent and 18‑year‑old plaintiffs and PFLAG members. The Court credited these showings of harm and found a nationwide injunction necessary to prevent further coercive effects tied to federal funding.

Key counsel: Plaintiffs are represented by the ACLU Foundation, Lambda Legal, and private firms Jenner & Block and Hogan Lovells. Defendants are represented by the U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Division, Federal Programs Branch.

Current status: A nationwide preliminary injunction enjoins HHS (including HRSA and NIH) and NSF from conditioning, withholding, or terminating federal funding under EO 14,168 § 3(g) and EO 14,187 § 4 based on a grantee’s provision of gender‑affirming care to patients under 19; the injunction remains in force while the interlocutory appeal is held in abeyance pending the Supreme Court’s resolution of U.S. v. Skrmetti. No settlement has been reached. The district court has partially stayed case‑management deadlines, but preserved Plaintiffs’ ability to seek additional preliminary relief or enforcement during the appeal.

On March 26, 2025, eleven nonprofit legal service organizations that represent unaccompanied immigrant children filed this APA action in the Northern District of California against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), its Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR), and the Department of the Interior (DOI). The organizations—based in California and across the country—alleged that the Government’s abrupt March 21, 2025 termination of contract line items for direct immigration representation of unaccompanied children violated the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), 8 U.S.C. § 1232(c)(5), and ORR’s 2024 Unaccompanied Children Program Foundational Rule, 45 C.F.R. § 410.1309, and was arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to preserve funding and services.

The suit arises from a long-running federal program under which ORR funds legal services for unaccompanied children—children under 18 without lawful status and without a parent or legal guardian available in the United States—to ensure, “to the greatest extent practicable,” they have counsel in legal proceedings. For more than a decade, ORR funded such services through a prime contract with Acacia Center for Justice and subcontracts to providers like Plaintiffs. On March 21, 2025, DOI issued a “Notice of Partial Termination for the Government’s Convenience” of Contract No. 140D0422C0009, canceling the line items for direct representation, attorney recruitment/IJC fellows, and language tutoring (CLINs 2–4), while leaving only know-your-rights presentations and consultations (CLIN 1). Plaintiffs alleged that Congress has appropriated funds for TVPRA services—including direct representation—through September 2027 and that ORR’s Foundational Rule obligates ORR, subject to appropriations, to fund providers to deliver direct representation when pro bono counsel is not practicable.

Judge Araceli Martínez-Olguín granted a temporary restraining order on April 1, 2025, enjoining Defendants from withdrawing ORR-provided services or funds as of March 20, 2025, particularly the provision of funds for direct legal representation, and precluding cutting off access to congressionally appropriated funding during the TRO. The court later extended the TRO to April 30, 2025. The Government moved to dissolve the TRO (arguing, inter alia, that the Tucker Act channeled the dispute to the Court of Federal Claims and that the Supreme Court’s April 4, 2025 decision in Department of Education v. California barred APA orders compelling payments), and also sought the judge’s recusal based on past employment at a plaintiff organization. The court denied recusal on April 17, 2025 and denied dissolution of the TRO on April 21, 2025.

Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. After hearing on April 23, 2025, the court granted a preliminary injunction on April 29, 2025, preserving the status quo and prohibiting the Government from withdrawing the ORR funding and services for direct representation provided as of March 20, 2025. The court found Plaintiffs likely to succeed on their APA claims that the termination contravened the TVPRA’s mandate to “ensure, to the greatest extent practicable” that unaccompanied children have counsel, and the Foundational Rule’s requirement that ORR fund direct representation (subject to available appropriations) where pro bono representation is not practicable. The court also credited evidence of available appropriations for legal services through September 2027, and Plaintiffs’ declarations describing imminent layoffs, service cuts, and the risk that children would appear in immigration court without counsel.

On appeal, the Government’s challenge to the TRO was dismissed by the Ninth Circuit on April 18, 2025 for lack of jurisdiction; rehearing en banc was denied April 25, 2025, and the mandate issued May 5, 2025. The Government noticed an appeal of the preliminary injunction on April 30, 2025 and moved for a stay pending appeal. On May 14, 2025, the Ninth Circuit (Judge Koh, with Judge Callahan dissenting) denied the stay, holding the Government had not shown a likelihood of success on its arguments that the Tucker Act impliedly barred APA review or that the termination decision was committed to agency discretion by law, and had not demonstrated irreparable injury absent a stay.

Throughout the case, amici curiae—including Former Immigration Judges and Former HHS Officials—supported Plaintiffs, addressing the importance of counsel for unaccompanied children and ORR’s historic provision of funded representation. The district court’s preliminary injunction remains in effect, enjoining Defendants from cutting off ORR funding and services for direct legal representation of unaccompanied children during the pendency of the litigation.
results.46201:
On March 6, 2025, eight states (California, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Colorado, Illinois, Maryland, New York, and Wisconsin), represented by their Attorneys General, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the U.S. Department of Education, the Secretary of Education, and the former Acting Secretary (in their official capacities). The states challenge the Department’s abrupt mid‑February 2025 termination of virtually all previously awarded grants under two federal teacher pipeline programs—the Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) Program (authorized by the Higher Education Act, 20 U.S.C. § 1022 et seq.) and the Supporting Effective Educator Development (SEED) Program (authorized by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, 20 U.S.C. § 6672). The states allege the Department sent standardized termination letters to grantees, asserting the awards no longer effectuated Department “priorities,” including concerns about alleged DEI‑related discrimination, but without program‑specific reasons or individualized analysis. The terminations followed a February 5, 2025 internal Department directive, issued amid new Executive Orders addressing “DEI,” directing staff to review grants for discriminatory practices and for consistency with Department policy objectives.

The complaint, brought under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706, seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to vacate and set aside the terminations, alleging they are arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, ultra vires, and inconsistent with notice‑and‑comment priority‑setting requirements in GEPA (20 U.S.C. § 1232(d)) and the Department’s regulations (34 C.F.R. § 75.105). The states also invoke the OMB Uniform Guidance—particularly 2 C.F.R. § 200.340—which permits termination for failure to effectuate program goals or agency priorities only if such conditions are “clearly and unambiguously” specified in the award terms and “to the extent authorized by law.” The states contend the TQP/SEED Grant Award Notifications did not authorize termination on new Department “priorities,” and that Congress itself embedded service to diverse and traditionally underserved students (and recruitment into hard‑to‑staff subjects) in the programs’ purposes. The amended complaint (filed June 2, 2025) adds Spending Clause and separation‑of‑powers claims and challenges the Department’s February 2025 “Eliminating Discrimination and Fraud in Department Grant Awards” directive, linking it to Executive Orders 14151, 14173, and 14190.

Judge Myong J. Joun granted a temporary restraining order on March 10, 2025, requiring the Department to immediately restore the pre‑termination status quo for TQP/SEED awards within the plaintiff states, enjoining implementation or reinstatement of the terminations, and directing notice to grantees and staff. The order permitted individualized terminations consistent with Congress’s authorizations, the APA, applicable regulations, and grant terms. The TRO issued for 14 days and was later extended to April 7, 2025. The Department filed an emergency appeal.

On March 21, 2025, a First Circuit panel (Judges Gelpí, Kayatta, and Montecalvo) denied the government’s motion for a stay pending appeal. The panel—without deciding the merits—concluded the Department had not shown a likelihood of success on threshold arguments that the states’ claims belonged exclusively in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act or were committed to agency discretion, noting that federal regulations (including 2 C.F.R. § 200.340, adopted by 2 C.F.R. § 3474.1) cabin termination discretion and that plaintiffs sought equitable relief set by federal law rather than contract damages. The court also found the record at that stage did not show irreparable harm justifying a stay.

On April 4, 2025, the Supreme Court, in a per curiam opinion, stayed the district court’s order pending appeal, construing the TRO—extended and heavily contested—as an appealable preliminary injunction. The Court stated the government was likely to succeed in showing the district court lacked APA jurisdiction where the relief effectively compelled payment under federal grant contracts and the Tucker Act implies the APA’s sovereign‑immunity waiver does not extend to such claims. It also credited the government’s showing of potential irreparable harm if tens of millions could be drawn down and not readily recovered, and noted respondents could maintain programs or pursue appropriate monetary relief later. (The Chief Justice would have denied the application; separate dissents by Justices Kagan and Jackson (joined by Justice Sotomayor) disagreed.)

Following the Supreme Court’s stay, the plaintiff states withdrew their pending preliminary injunction motion on April 8, 2025. The government then voluntarily dismissed its First Circuit appeal. The states filed a First Amended Complaint on June 2, 2025, expanding their APA and constitutional claims and describing the February actions as implementing the Department’s new directive and Executive Orders. As of June 30, 2025, the Department has moved to dismiss for lack of subject‑matter jurisdiction or, alternatively, to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of Federal Claims (28 U.S.C. § 1631). That motion remains pending, and the case has been reassigned on the district court docket to Judge Angel Kelley (No. 1:25‑cv‑10548‑AK).

Throughout, the states have emphasized the factual context of a nationwide teacher shortage and the role of multi‑year TQP/SEED awards in recruiting, training, and retaining teachers for hard‑to‑staff subjects and underserved districts. They cite reliance by programs in their jurisdictions—for example, UMass initiatives to license early childhood and bilingual special‑education teachers, CSU/UC programs addressing rural and special‑education needs, SUNY/CUNY residencies, Montclair State and The College of New Jersey residencies, Milwaukee Public Schools special‑education residencies through UW–Madison, and CU Denver’s rural teacher pipeline—many mid‑grant when the terminations issued.

Key filings and rulings: Complaint (Mar. 6, 2025); TRO granted (Mar. 10, 2025); Department’s notice of appeal (Mar. 11, 2025); First Circuit order denying stay pending appeal (Mar. 21, 2025); Supreme Court stay of district court’s order (Apr. 4, 2025); plaintiffs’ withdrawal of preliminary‑injunction motion (Apr. 8, 2025); government’s voluntary dismissal of appeal; First Amended Complaint (June 2, 2025); motions to dismiss or transfer (May 12 and June 30, 2025). The district court’s TRO referenced Massachusetts v. National Institutes of Health, 2025 WL 702163 (D. Mass. Mar. 5, 2025), as persuasive on APA jurisdiction.

Remedies sought are declaratory and injunctive relief vacating the Department’s February grant terminations and directive as applied, reinstating awards consistent with statutory authorizations, and barring re‑termination on unlawful grounds. No trial or settlement has occurred, and no monitor has been appointed. The litigation remains pending on threshold jurisdiction and venue/transfer questions following the Supreme Court’s stay.

On February 6, 2025, several active-duty servicemembers who are transgender, a transgender man seeking to enlist, and a Washington‑based membership organization filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington challenging a new federal policy that excludes transgender people from military service. The suit names the United States, the Department of Defense and the military departments, and the Secretary of Defense and service secretaries in their official capacities. The individual plaintiffs include senior officers and senior enlisted personnel with lengthy, decorated careers in the Navy, Army, and Air Force; the organizational plaintiff, Gender Justice League, sues on behalf of its members. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Perkins Coie LLP) together with civil‑rights organizations (Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc., and the Human Rights Campaign Foundation).

The action challenges Executive Order 14183, “Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness,” issued January 27, 2025, and the Department of Defense’s February 26, 2025 implementing memorandum and guidance (and subsequent March 21, 2025 guidance). The new policy declares that “expressing a false ‘gender identity’ divergent from an individual’s sex” is incompatible with military service, recognizes only “male” and “female” as immutable, and directs the Department to exclude from accessions and to separate servicemembers who have a current diagnosis or history of, or “exhibit symptoms consistent with,” gender dysphoria. The guidance also: (a) pauses and cancels transition‑related surgeries and prohibits funding for sex‑reassignment surgeries and newly initiated cross‑sex hormone therapy; (b) mandates pronoun and salutation use to reflect a servicemember’s birth sex; (c) limits access to berthing, bathroom, and shower facilities by sex; (d) provides only narrow, case‑by‑case waivers; and (e) directs identification of affected members and initiation of separation processes (beginning March 26, 2025), with members deemed non‑deployable, subject to “administrative absence,” and offered limited financial inducements for voluntary separation. Plaintiffs allege that, since 2016 and under the 2021 “Austin Policy,” transgender people have been permitted to serve openly, including through gender‑transition care, without adverse effects on readiness, cohesion, or costs.

Plaintiffs assert constitutional claims under the Fifth Amendment’s equal protection and due process components and the First Amendment. They contend the policy facially classifies based on transgender status and sex and targets speech by forbidding expression of gender identity (including pronoun use), and that it arbitrarily breaks promises on which servicemembers relied to serve openly, causing reputational harm (“stigma‑plus”). They seek declaratory relief and preliminary and permanent injunctions barring enforcement of the Executive Order and implementing guidance. The case is before Judge Benjamin H. Settle.

On February 19, 2025, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. After ordering the government to file the Department’s “Action Memo,” the 2018 Mattis report, a 2021 AMSARA study, and a 2025 literature review on gender‑affirming care, and receiving supplemental briefing addressing additional February 26 and March 21 guidance, the court granted the motion on March 27, 2025. The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits of their equal protection claim because the policy facially discriminates based on transgender status and sex and fails intermediate scrutiny; the court also concluded it would fail even rational‑basis review given the absence of evidence of harm from open service during the prior four years and the Department’s reliance on outdated or inapposite materials. The court additionally found likely success on plaintiffs’ First Amendment claim (viewpoint- and content‑based restrictions on expression, including compelled pronoun usage inconsistent with identity), and on procedural due process and equitable estoppel theories (a “bait and switch” that punished servicemembers for relying on prior policy and imposed a stigmatizing bar). The court determined plaintiffs faced irreparable harm (loss of careers and constitutional injuries), that the balance of equities favored maintaining the status quo, and that the public interest was served by allowing qualified servicemembers to continue serving. The resulting nationwide preliminary injunction enjoined implementation of Executive Order 14183, the February 26, 2025 “Additional Guidance on Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness,” and related memoranda, restoring the pre‑existing “Austin Policy” permitting open transgender service pending trial.

The government sought stays in the Ninth Circuit; the court of appeals denied an administrative stay on March 31, 2025 and denied a stay pending appeal on April 18, 2025. On May 6, 2025, the Supreme Court (on an application referred by Justice Kagan) stayed the district court’s March 27 injunction pending disposition of the appeal in the Ninth Circuit and of any petition for certiorari, thereby allowing the Department’s 2025 policy to take effect during the appeal. The government subsequently filed its answer on May 19, 2025. The district court referenced related litigation, including Talbott v. United States (D.D.C.), where a preliminary injunction issued and later was administratively stayed by the D.C. Circuit, and Ireland v. Hegseth (D.N.J.), where a temporary restraining order issued as to the named plaintiffs, as well as prior Ninth Circuit authority addressing transgender military policy (Karnoski v. Trump, 926 F.3d 1180 (9th Cir. 2019)). No class has been certified, no trial date has been set, and no settlement has been reached. The preliminary injunction (now stayed) was nationwide in scope and would have maintained the pre‑January 2025 status quo; its duration was “pending a trial on the merits.”

On January 28, 2025, a group of transgender service members and prospective enlistees filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia challenging new federal policies that exclude transgender people from military service. The suit names the United States, the Secretary of Defense Peter B. Hegseth, the service secretaries and their departments (Army, Navy/Marine Corps, Air Force/Space Force), and the Director and agency of the Defense Health Agency in their official capacities. Plaintiffs are current Army, Navy, Air Force, and Space Force personnel (including a basic trainee), and transgender applicants whose enlistments or accessions were halted. Plaintiffs are represented by civil-rights nonprofit counsel and pro bono/private counsel; the government is represented by the Department of Justice. The case is before Judge Ana C. Reyes.

Plaintiffs challenge two presidential orders issued at the start of 2025 and the Department of Defense’s implementation. On January 20, 2025, the Administration issued Executive Order 14168, “Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government,” defining “sex” exclusively by biological classification at conception. On January 27, 2025, Executive Order 14183, “Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness,” revoked the prior open-service policy (EO 14004), stated that adopting a gender identity inconsistent with birth sex is incompatible with military values (honesty, humility, integrity), directed DoD to end “identification‑based pronoun usage,” prohibited males and females from sharing sex‑segregated facilities, and required revisions to DoD medical standards. On February 7, 2025, DoD paused new accessions for individuals with a history of gender dysphoria and paused transition‑related medical procedures for service members. On February 26, 2025, DoD issued “Additional Guidance on Prioritizing Military Excellence and Readiness,” declaring service by people with a current or past diagnosis of, or “symptoms consistent with,” gender dysphoria incompatible with service; directing the services to identify such members within 30 days and initiate separations within 30 days thereafter; canceling transition‑related surgeries; requiring service in birth sex for purposes of pronouns, housing, facilities, and standards; and creating narrow “waivers” available only to individuals who had never attempted transition, had 36 months of “stability” in their birth sex, and agreed to serve in their birth sex. A Navy recruiting memo (Jan. 28) halted processing of applicants who identify as transgender, and service‑specific guidance followed. Plaintiffs alleged concrete harms including canceled surgeries, removal from female barracks and latrines for a basic trainee, blocked accessions and graduations, and adverse duty status changes.

Plaintiffs’ operative pleadings (most recently a Fourth Amended Complaint filed March 24, 2025) assert that these actions violate the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause; they also plead procedural due process and estoppel claims. Plaintiffs seek declaratory relief and temporary, preliminary, and permanent injunctions restoring the prior open-service policy and barring enforcement of EO 14183, aspects of EO 14168 as applied to the military, and DoD’s implementing directives.

Key proceedings followed rapidly. Plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on February 3, 2025, and sought a temporary restraining order on February 4. The court required immediate notice of any implementing guidance and held status and scheduling conferences. Plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint adding a basic trainee. The government opposed preliminary relief. After hearings on February 18 and 19, the court requested additional briefing (including on immutability) and awaited DoD’s final policy. DoD issued its February 26 implementation memo; Plaintiffs then filed a Third Amended Complaint and a renewed preliminary injunction motion on March 7. The court held further argument on March 12.

On March 18, 2025, Judge Reyes granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining EO 14183 and DoD’s February 26 implementation and “any other memorandums, guidance, policies, or actions” issued pursuant to that order, and ordering the government to maintain the pre‑January 27, 2025 status quo (the 2021–2024 “Austin” policy permitting open service under DoDI 6130.03 Vols. 1 & 2 and DoDI 1300.28). The court found Plaintiffs likely to succeed on their Fifth Amendment equal protection claim, concluding the policy facially classifies based on sex and transgender status and fails intermediate scrutiny; that the challenged actions also likely fail even rational basis review because they were animated by animus toward transgender persons; that plaintiffs face irreparable constitutional and career harms; and that the balance of equities and public interest favor injunctive relief. The court stayed its order until March 21 to allow the government to seek appellate relief.

On March 21, DoD issued “Military Department Identification” guidance clarifying that “exhibit symptoms consistent with gender dysphoria” refers to DSM‑5 criteria (marked incongruence with clinically significant distress for at least six months), required annual attestations during the Periodic Health Assessment, mandated non‑deployable status for those identified, and directed separation processing. The government moved to dissolve the injunction, arguing the policy targets a medical condition and mirrors the 2018 Mattis policy. On March 26, the district court denied dissolution and a stay pending appeal, finding the new guidance confirmed the policy’s focus on transgender people and did not alter the court’s conclusions; the court stayed its order until March 28 at 7:00 p.m. for possible emergency relief from the D.C. Circuit.

Meanwhile, Plaintiffs filed a targeted TRO application on March 24 for several individuals facing immediate adverse actions (administrative absence, removal from classes, blocked graduation), seeking to preserve their status pending resolution of the government’s dissolution motion. On March 27, 2025, the D.C. Circuit issued an administrative stay of the district court’s March 18 preliminary injunction “pending further order of the court” to consider the government’s motion for a stay pending appeal. The appeal is docketed as No. 25‑5087, and briefing is underway; the government argues for military deference, contends the policy is a medical‑standards regulation requiring only rational basis review, challenges the injunction’s scope, and asserts the equities favor a stay.

No settlement has been reached. The preliminary injunction remains administratively stayed by the D.C. Circuit while it considers a stay pending appeal.

On January 21, 2025, the States of Washington, Arizona, Illinois, and Oregon filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington to stop enforcement of Executive Order 14160, issued on January 20, 2025 and titled “Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship.” The Order directs federal agencies, effective 30 days after issuance, not to recognize U.S. citizenship for persons born in the United States if (1) the mother was unlawfully present and the father was not a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident at birth, or (2) the mother’s presence was lawful but temporary and the father was not a citizen or lawful permanent resident. It also directs agencies to align regulations and issue implementation guidance within 30 days. Plaintiffs alleged the Order violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and 8 U.S.C. § 1401, and (in the later-consolidated action) the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief. The States were represented by their attorneys general; individual plaintiffs (pregnant noncitizens) later joined and were represented by the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project. The United States, the President in his official capacity, and multiple federal departments and officers were named defendants.

Judge John C. Coughenour (W.D. Wash.) granted a temporary restraining order on January 23, 2025, enjoining implementation and enforcement nationwide. On January 27, 2025, the court consolidated a related individual action (No. 2:25-cv-0163) with the States’ case and set an expedited schedule. On February 6, 2025, the court granted a preliminary injunction, again enjoining enforcement and implementation nationwide. The court held the States had standing based on impending loss of federal reimbursements for programs like Medicaid, CHIP, Title IV‑E foster care, and SSA “Enumeration at Birth” payments, and significant administrative burdens to rework eligibility verification systems if the Order took effect. The court found the States likely to succeed on the merits because the Order conflicts with the Fourteenth Amendment’s plain text and Supreme Court precedent—particularly United States v. Wong Kim Ark, 169 U.S. 649 (1898)—which affirms birthright citizenship for nearly all persons born on U.S. soil and “subject to the jurisdiction” of the United States, with narrow exceptions (e.g., children of foreign diplomats, enemy occupiers, and historically, tribal members). The court also found irreparable harm, that the equities favored plaintiffs, and that a nationwide injunction was necessary to prevent piecemeal disruption and to afford complete relief to the States.

The government appealed and sought a stay. On February 19, 2025, a Ninth Circuit motions panel denied a partial stay and calendared the appeal. In parallel cases, other district courts issued similar injunctions, and on June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court addressed “universal” (nationwide) injunctions in Trump v. CASA, Inc., granting partial stays to limit such injunctions to relief necessary to provide complete relief to plaintiffs and allowing agencies to issue guidance during the injunctions. The Court left to lower courts whether broader relief was needed to afford complete relief to State plaintiffs.

On July 23, 2025, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction. It held the State plaintiffs had Article III standing because the Order would directly reduce federal reimbursements and administrative fees and impose immediate, unrecoverable administrative costs; these were not indirect or self-inflicted harms. The panel dismissed the individual plaintiffs’ claims in deference to a certified nationwide class in “Barbara v. Trump” in the District of New Hampshire, which covered their children’s claims. On the merits, the court held plaintiffs were likely to prevail because the Order contradicts the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause: the phrase “subject to the jurisdiction thereof” refers to being subject to U.S. laws and authority, not to an exclusive “primary allegiance” or parents’ permanent domicile, and Supreme Court precedent (Wong Kim Ark) and the Amendment’s history confirm that nearly all persons born in the United States are citizens at birth, except for narrow, historically recognized categories. The court likewise found a likelihood of success on the statutory claim under 8 U.S.C. § 1401, which mirrors the constitutional text. The court agreed irreparable harm was shown and the equities and public interest favored injunctive relief because the Executive Branch has no legitimate interest in enforcing an unconstitutional policy.

Addressing scope after the Supreme Court’s CASA ruling, the Ninth Circuit held the district court did not abuse its discretion in issuing relief that applies nationwide as necessary to provide complete relief to the State plaintiffs: births can occur across state lines and affected families may move among States, which would otherwise force States to overhaul eligibility verification systems and suffer ongoing administrative burdens. The court concluded a uniform application of the Citizenship Clause nationwide was required to prevent the harms identified.

Key procedural steps: complaint filed January 21, 2025; TRO granted January 23; cases consolidated January 27; preliminary injunction granted February 6; Ninth Circuit denied stay February 19; on June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court addressed universal injunctions in related litigation and permitted agency guidance; on July 23, 2025, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction and its scope and dismissed the individual plaintiffs’ claims due to overlapping class proceedings. Related litigation included CASA, Inc. v. Trump (D. Md./4th Cir.), New Jersey v. Trump (D. Mass./1st Cir.), Doe v. Trump (D. Mass.), and “Barbara v. Trump” (D.N.H.) in which a nationwide class was certified. The case remains in a preliminary injunction posture with nationwide effect, and the district court retains jurisdiction over the States’ claims for declaratory and injunctive relief.
results.45965:
On January 21, 2025, two immigrant‑rights organizations and several pregnant mothers filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland (Greenbelt Division) challenging Executive Order 14160, “Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship.” The order directs federal agencies not to recognize birthright citizenship for persons born in the United States after February 19, 2025, when the mother was either unlawfully present or lawfully but temporarily present and the father was neither a U.S. citizen nor a lawful permanent resident. The plaintiffs—CASA, Inc.; the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project (ASAP); and five individual mothers (later expanded to include additional mothers and newborns)—sued the President, the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Director of USCIS, the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, and the United States. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the order violates the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and 8 U.S.C. § 1401(a). Plaintiffs are represented by nonprofit and public‑interest counsel (including CASA counsel and Georgetown University Law Center’s Institute for Constitutional Advocacy and Protection), and the defendants by the Department of Justice.

On February 5, 2025, Judge Deborah L. Boardman granted a preliminary injunction, finding plaintiffs highly likely to succeed on their claim that the Executive Order contradicts the plain language of the Citizenship Clause and the Supreme Court’s decision in United States v. Wong Kim Ark, and also conflicts with § 1401(a). The court rejected the Government’s threshold arguments (including that 8 U.S.C. § 1503 supplied the exclusive remedy), found irreparable harm to newborns and their families, and entered a nationwide injunction enjoining implementation and enforcement of the order by the State Department, DHS/USCIS, the DOJ, the SSA, and persons in active concert with them.

The Government’s motion to stay the injunction was denied in the district court and by the Fourth Circuit. On June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court granted a partial stay in Trump v. CASA, holding that “universal” injunctions likely exceed federal courts’ equitable authority and narrowing the injunction to protect only the named plaintiffs, while expressly permitting agencies to issue guidance and delaying the order’s § 2 effective date by 30 days. The Court did not address the merits of the Executive Order’s legality, and noted that class actions under Rule 23(b)(2) can supply class‑wide injunctive relief.

Within hours, plaintiffs amended their complaint to proceed as a class action on behalf of children born in the United States after February 19, 2025, and their parents. On July 29, 2025, the Fourth Circuit dismissed the interlocutory appeal and remanded to allow the district court to conform its relief to the Supreme Court’s directions and to promptly resolve the class issues. On August 7, 2025, Judge Boardman certified a Rule 23(b)(2) class defined as: “Any child who has been born or will be born in the United States after February 19, 2025, (1) whose mother was unlawfully present in the United States and whose father was not a United States citizen or lawful permanent resident at the time of said person’s birth, or (2) whose mother’s presence in the United States at the time of said person’s birth was lawful but temporary and whose father was not a United States citizen or lawful permanent resident at the time of said person’s birth.” The court found numerosity easily met; identified a common question of law—whether the Executive Order violates the Citizenship Clause and § 1401(a)—capable of class‑wide resolution; and held that the named parents, acting as next friends for their newborns or future children, were typical and adequate representatives for the children’s claims. The court certified only the children’s claims (not the parents’ independent claims), and then issued a classwide preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of the Executive Order against the certified class pending resolution on the merits.

Key related litigation included similar district‑court injunctions in Washington v. Trump (W.D. Wash.) and Doe v. Trump (D. Mass.), with the Ninth Circuit affirming and the First Circuit denying a stay; the Supreme Court consolidated the Government’s partial‑stay applications from those cases with this one. Judge Boardman’s principal reported opinions are the February 5, 2025 preliminary‑injunction decision (763 F. Supp. 3d 723) and the February 18, 2025 decision denying a partial stay (2025 WL 545840). The Supreme Court’s partial‑stay ruling is reported at 145 S. Ct. 2540 (2025). No trial has occurred, and the case remains pending on the merits, with a classwide preliminary injunction in place enjoining enforcement of Executive Order 14160 as to all class members.
results.VR-LA-0120:
In May 2020, during the COVID‑19 pandemic, two lawsuits challenging Louisiana’s absentee and early voting rules were filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana and were later consolidated before Chief Judge Shelly D. Dick. On May 7, 2020, community organizations and voters (including Power Coalition for Equity and Justice and the Louisiana NAACP) sued the Governor and Secretary of State in Power Coalition for Equity & Justice v. Edwards. On May 19, 2020, individual voters and two civic groups (Telisa Clark, Lakeshia Barnett, Crescent City Media Group, and the League of Women Voters of Louisiana) filed a related action against the Governor, Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and two parish registrars (Lafayette and Terrebonne). The State of Louisiana, through the Attorney General, intervened. Plaintiffs were represented by public‑interest and pro bono counsel, including the Southern Poverty Law Center, Fair Elections Center, Arnold & Porter, NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, and Covington & Burling.

Plaintiffs brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, alleging that, in the context of COVID‑19, three state voting rules unconstitutionally burdened the right to vote and violated the Voting Rights Act: (1) the “Excuse Requirement,” which limits absentee‑by‑mail voting to specific categories in La. Rev. Stat. § 18:1303; (2) the absentee ballot “Witness Requirement,” which requires a witness signature on the absentee ballot certificate (La. Rev. Stat. § 18:1306(E)(2)(a)); and (3) the lack of notice and an opportunity to cure defects in absentee applications or ballots (La. Rev. Stat. § 18:1313). The Power Coalition plaintiffs also challenged limiting early voting to seven days for the November and December elections, seeking fourteen days. Plaintiffs alleged the rules, as applied during the pandemic, violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments (including Anderson‑Burdick balancing and an unconstitutional‑conditions theory) and Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act because the burden fell disproportionately on Black voters and those at higher risk from COVID‑19. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief barring enforcement of the Excuse and Witness Requirements for all 2020 elections, extending early voting for later elections, and requiring notice‑and‑cure procedures; they also moved for a preliminary injunction.

The litigation arose against the backdrop of the Secretary of State’s April 2020 emergency election planning. The Secretary’s initial proposal would have broadly expanded absentee eligibility and waived the witness requirement for the then‑postponed July and August 2020 elections, but the Legislature rejected that plan. A revised Emergency Election Plan, approved April 27, 2020, created five COVID‑related excuses for absentee voting for the July 11 and August 15 elections, extended early voting to thirteen days for those elections, but retained the witness requirement and did not cover the November and December elections. On June 11, 2020, the Governor signed SB 75, immediately limiting any one person (except an immediate family member) from witnessing more than one absentee ballot. On June 15, 2020, the Secretary, with the Attorney General’s approval, issued an emergency rule allowing limited notice‑and‑cure of absentee ballot deficiencies, but requiring voters to appear in person at the registrar’s office to cure.

Defendants moved to dismiss, arguing, among other things, that the Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because plaintiffs lacked standing (the alleged harms were caused by the pandemic, not state action), the claims presented political questions, the Purcell principle counseled against late changes to election rules, and necessary parish entities had not been joined. The parish registrars also sought dismissal on standing and Rule 19 grounds. Plaintiffs opposed and amended their complaints in mid‑June, refining allegations and, in the Clark case, naming only the Governor, Secretary, and Attorney General; the registrar defendants were terminated on June 18, 2020.

On June 22, 2020, the Court dismissed the consolidated cases for lack of subject matter jurisdiction on standing grounds, without reaching the merits or the other defenses. Plaintiffs moved to amend the judgment to reflect a dismissal without prejudice, which the Court granted; an amended judgment issued June 30, 2020. As a result, the motions for preliminary injunction were denied as moot, and no injunctive or declaratory relief issued. No appeals are reflected in the record provided. The cases centered on the application of Louisiana’s absentee and early voting laws during a public health emergency, including the state’s Emergency Election Plan limited to the July and August 2020 elections, but concluded with dismissal for lack of standing.
results.VR-SC-0078:
On April 22, 2020, several South Carolina voters and a nonprofit (later joined by the South Carolina State Conference of the NAACP) filed this federal civil‑rights action against the Executive Director and members of the South Carolina State Election Commission and the Governor, challenging two absentee‑voting provisions in light of COVID‑19: (1) the “Excuse Requirement” limiting who may vote absentee (S.C. Code Ann. § 7‑15‑320), and (2) the “Witness Requirement” mandating a witness signature on an absentee ballot envelope (S.C. Code Ann. § 7‑15‑380). Plaintiffs alleged these provisions, during the pandemic, imposed unconstitutional burdens on the right to vote in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments (42 U.S.C. § 1983), denied or abridged the right to vote in violation of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, constituted a prohibited “test or device” under Section 201 of the Voting Rights Act, and violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief eliminating the requirements for the 2020 elections and a public information campaign.

Plaintiffs supported their claims with public‑health guidance from CDC and DHEC, evidence that many voters—disproportionately Black, elderly, or disabled—live alone or must strictly quarantine, and a March 30, 2020 letter from Executive Director Marci Andino to state leaders recommending, for safety and security, temporary no‑excuse absentee voting and removal of the witness requirement. The South Carolina Republican Party intervened (permissively) to defend the challenged provisions, and the Attorney General (amicus) and United States (Statement of Interest) opposed the Section 201 “test or device” claim, noting such claims must be heard by a three‑judge court and arguing a witness signature is not a prohibited voucher. Protection & Advocacy for People with Disabilities filed an amicus brief supporting plaintiffs. Later, the Speaker of the House and the Senate President were also allowed to intervene.

After the General Assembly enacted S. 635 (Act 133) on May 13, 2020 temporarily allowing all qualified voters to vote absentee in the June primaries due to the state of emergency, the Excuse Requirement issue for those elections became moot. On May 25, 2020, Judge J. Michelle Childs granted in part plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the Witness Requirement for the June 9, 2020 primaries and any runoffs. The court found that, amid COVID‑19, requiring a witness signature forced voters—especially those living alone or at high risk—to risk exposure to vote, constituting a severe burden on the right to vote that was not justified by the State’s asserted interests, particularly given other safeguards and the SEC Director’s acknowledgment that the witness signature “offers no benefit” to election officials. The court ordered the State to inform voters that no witness was required for the June primaries.

Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on July 13, 2020 seeking relief for the remaining 2020 elections. Defendants moved for summary judgment on August 10, 2020, arguing lack of standing, that absentee voting is a privilege subject to rational‑basis review under McDonald v. Board of Election Comm’rs, that the burdens were minimal given in‑person safety measures, and that neither the VRA nor ADA claims could succeed. On September 16, 2020, the General Assembly enacted H.B. 5305 (R.149), suspending the Excuse Requirement for the November general election due to the ongoing emergency. On September 18, 2020, in a related case (Middleton v. Andino), the same court enjoined the Witness Requirement for the November 2020 general election. In light of those developments, Judge Childs stayed the Thomas proceedings and held all pending motions in abeyance, noting both challenged provisions were suspended or enjoined for November 2020. The case remains stayed.
results.JC-MD-0017:
On April 21, 2020, pretrial detainees and a post‑conviction inmate at the Prince George’s County Correctional Center filed a class action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland (Judge Paula Xinis), alleging unconstitutional jail conditions during the COVID‑19 pandemic. Plaintiffs—represented by Civil Rights Corps and WilmerHale—seek declaratory and injunctive relief under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and habeas relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 for a subclass of medically vulnerable pretrial detainees. They ask the court to remedy unsafe conditions (lack of no‑cost soap and sanitizer, poor sanitation, inadequate masking and social distancing), delays and co‑pays for medical care (including $4 sick‑call fees), failure to medically isolate and contact trace, and filthy medical isolation cells with minimal monitoring or access to hygiene. Plaintiffs also allege a policy of “overdetention” of detainees who had satisfied their release but were held solely due to COVID‑19 positivity until deemed non‑contagious. They bring class claims on behalf of pretrial and post‑conviction detainees and a medically vulnerable subclass.

Plaintiffs concurrently moved for emergency relief. After ordering an expedited response and appointing, under Fed. R. Evid. 706, infectious disease specialist Dr. Carlos Franco‑Paredes to conduct an unannounced inspection (May 6–7, 2020), the court issued a May 21, 2020 Memorandum Opinion and Order granting narrowly drawn, temporary injunctive relief. The court found Plaintiffs likely to succeed on the merits of their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment conditions claims based on a “triple‑threat” at the Facility: undertesting (including early test positivity of 90%), inadequate treatment and isolation of symptomatic detainees, and no plan to protect high‑risk detainees. The court ordered the Facility to, within five days, file a comprehensive plan for identifying, monitoring, treating, and housing CDC‑defined high‑risk detainees (including securing single‑cell housing when appropriate), to train and supervise staff on symptom identification and timely care, to ensure adequate supplies (soap, cleaning agents, PPE), and to expand testing (e.g., of affected housing units and new intakes). The order was expressly temporary (a TRO), set to be revisited in June 2020.

Defendant noticed an appeal and moved to stay the TRO. On June 3, 2020, the court denied a stay, noting the TRO was not appealable and that the record showed plaintiffs were likely to succeed and would suffer irreparable harm absent relief. The court also observed substantial evidence that the jail’s grievance process was “hobbled, if not outright broken,” bearing on PLRA exhaustion.

Defendant filed the required plans and reports. On May 26, 2020, the Facility outlined processes to identify high‑risk detainees (via Chronic Care Clinic lists, intake, and sick‑call screening), monitor and treat them, house them (favoring single‑celling where possible), and to continue training and testing. In a June 5, 2020 14‑day report, Defendant stated that by May 26, 2020, 521 of 525 detainees had been tested, with six asymptomatic positives (about 1.14%); new intakes were being tested and quarantined for 14 days.

On July 7, 2020, Plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint adding two claims challenging the jail’s prolonged, universal lockdown (confinement in cells for 22–23 hours per day with limited out‑of‑cell time often in the middle of the night, scarce reading materials, and curtailed mental health services). They allege these conditions create a substantial risk of serious psychological and physiological harm in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and that imposing such restrictive confinement without individualized process violates procedural due process. Defendant moved to dismiss (or for summary judgment), arguing mootness as to released named plaintiffs, PLRA non‑exhaustion, failure to plead Monell liability on overdetention, that § 2241 habeas cannot redress conditions claims, and that the lockdown claims fail on the merits and under the PLRA’s limits on injunctive relief. Plaintiffs opposed, invoking the “inherently transitory” exception to mootness, arguing the grievance system was unavailable, and maintaining the sufficiency of their constitutional claims. Class certification remains pending; the court initially held it in abeyance while addressing emergency relief and later set a schedule for discovery and further proceedings.

Judge: Paula Xinis.
results.IM-FL-0029:
On April 13, 2020, civil immigration detainees held by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at three South Florida facilities—Krome Service Processing Center (Miami), Broward Transitional Center (Pompano Beach), and Glades County Detention Center (Moore Haven)—filed a class action habeas and injunctive suit (28 U.S.C. § 2241) against the ICE Miami Field Office Director and the U.S. Attorney General. Represented by a coalition of private counsel (King & Spalding and others), nonprofit legal organizations (Americans for Immigrant Justice, Southern Poverty Law Center, Legal Aid Service of Broward County), and the University of Miami School of Law Immigration Clinic, the detainees alleged that ICE’s response to COVID‑19 at the facilities violated the Fifth Amendment due process right to reasonably safe, non‑punitive civil detention and, under the Accardi doctrine, ICE’s own binding detention standards requiring compliance with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including release, to address the risk of infection, the use of cohort quarantine contrary to CDC guidance, inadequate access to masks, soap, and disinfectants, and unsafe transfers that allegedly spread infection.

After expedited proceedings before U.S. Magistrate Judge Jonathan Goodman, District Judge Marcia G. Cooke entered a Temporary Restraining Order on April 30, 2020, requiring ICE to: (1) evaluate each named petitioner for release and report who could be promptly released; (2) describe how it would accelerate review and reduce each facility to roughly 75% of capacity within two weeks; (3) file weekly and twice‑weekly reports on releases and facility populations (including “mandatory detainees” and those with no convictions or pending charges); (4) immediately provide detainees with adequate soap, water, cleaning materials, and weekly mask replacement; and (5) provide staff and detainee education on COVID‑19. On May 2, 2020, the Court clarified that transfers were permitted only after ICE evaluated each detainee’s eligibility for release pursuant to ICE’s April 10, 2020 COVID‑19 Pandemic Response Requirements (PRR).

Following evidentiary hearings on June 2–3, 2020, Judge Cooke issued an Omnibus Order on June 6, 2020, granting a preliminary injunction, finding record evidence that ICE failed to protect detainees from COVID‑19 and had not adhered to CDC and ICE standards, and certifying a Rule 23(b)(2) class of “all current civil immigration detainees who are held by ICE at Krome, BTC, and Glades when this action was filed, since this action was filed, or in the future.” The Court ordered ICE to stop commingling confirmed COVID‑19 cases with unconfirmed cases; provide unrestricted access to hand soap, hand sanitizer, and hand towels; provide masks and COVID‑19 education to all detainees and staff; and perform CDC‑compliant screening before any detainee transfer. The Court further held that it would retain jurisdiction over class members transferred to other facilities, regardless of location.

Disputes over compliance led to Petitioners’ motion to compel. On July 17, 2020, the Court appointed Special Master Matthew C. Dates to inspect the facilities and report on compliance with the preliminary injunction. The Special Master’s February 19, 2021 report found, among other things, that cleaning supplies, masks, soap, and sanitizer were available and logged, but that the facilities’ physical layouts impeded full social distancing; he recommended partial relief. On March 25, 2021, the Court granted in part and denied in part Petitioners’ motion to compel, adopting aspects of the Special Master’s findings and continuing enforcement of the injunction.

On June 28, 2021, the parties entered a class‑wide Settlement Agreement, adopted as a final, court‑enforceable injunction with the Court retaining jurisdiction. The settlement requires the three facilities to comply with applicable detention standards, the ICE PRR, and CDC guidelines as they evolve; to implement ICE’s COVID‑19 Vaccination Guidelines and Protocol and provide free COVID‑19 vaccinations (and seasonal influenza vaccines), with multilingual educational materials and medical staff presentations; and to provide vaccine cards and information to those released after one vaccine dose. The facilities must maintain population density in each living area and overall at no more than 75% of capacity (as defined by PRR/CDC) with limited, reportable exceptions; post daily cohort/quarantine status and dates in every housing unit; test symptomatic detainees and close contacts within 24 hours and provide results within 12 hours; isolate positives and medically isolate exposed, test‑negative detainees for 14 days without mixing with confirmed cases; medically isolate those pending test results away from general population; and ensure unlimited, no‑cost access to soap and hand sanitizer with logged refills at specified locations. The facilities must provide new masks (disposable masks three times per week or clean cloth masks) with immediate replacement on request; require staff to wear masks; provide a new mask before any transfer; and perform a rapid COVID‑19 test within 24 hours before transfer, only transferring those who test negative. Transport vehicles must be sanitized before and after each trip and seat detainees with distancing when possible. Class members retain the right to pursue individual habeas petitions for release.

Throughout, Judge Marcia G. Cooke presided, with Magistrate Judge Jonathan Goodman handling emergency and class certification proceedings, and Special Master Dates monitoring compliance. The case concluded with a court‑enforced settlement aimed at aligning facility practices with CDC and ICE standards to mitigate COVID‑19 risks for the certified class.
